Jane Goodall, the global icon, world-renowned primatologist and conservationist, has died at 91.   Born in 1934, Goodall‚Äôs love of animals began in childhood and at just 26-years-old, led her to the forests of Tanzania with no formal training. There, she transformed science forever by showing that chimpanzees use and make tools ‚Äî a behavior once thought to belong only to humans.   Her decades of research reshaped how we understand our closest relatives in the animal kingdom and inspired generations to care more deeply about the natural world.   She was named a UN Messenger of Peace and a Dame of the British Empire and received countless honors for her lifelong dedication to conservation and hope for the planet.

The Mayflower departed from Plymouth, England, bound for the Americas, on September 16, 1620. Sailing for more than two months across some 3,000 miles of open ocean, the 102 passengers‚Äîincluding three pregnant women and more than a dozen children‚Äîwere squeezed below decks in crowded, cold and damp conditions, suffering crippling bouts of seasickness, and surviving on meager rations of hardtack biscuits, dried meat and beer. ‚úÇÔ∏è Moscow, 1698.  The city‚Äôs most powerful men gather to greet their ruler, Peter the Great. Instead, the towering Czar pulls out a razor‚Äîand begins hacking off their beards.  To Russians, beards aren‚Äôt fashion. They are sacred. A mark of piety, tied to the image of God. Shaving is considered a sin.  But Peter had just returned from Europe, where clean-shaven faces were the sign of modernity. To him, those beards represented the ‚Äúold Russia.‚Äù And he is determined to drag his nation into the future‚Äîwhether his nobles like it or not.  This is just the beginning. A beard tax. New clothes. New schools. A new calendar. And a Russia forever changed.  On HISTORY This Week: how Peter the Great‚Äôs razor helped carve a new empire.  üéß Listen now‚Äîlink in bio.  1. Major John H. "Lucky" Luckadoo, the last surviving pilot from World War II's "Bloody Hundredth" 100th Bomb Group, died on Monday, September 1, at the age of 103. Luckadoo, a B-17 Flying Fortress co-pilot, flew 25 dangerous combat missions over Nazi-occupied Europe. He had trained on the B-29 Superfortress and was preparing to return to combat in the Pacific Theater when the war ended. For decades, Luckadoo helped educate younger generations about the war. This clip is from an interview we were fortunate to do with Luckadoo in July.   For more about Luckadoo from The National WWII Museum, visit the link in our bio.

üß¨ For Stalin, science wasn‚Äôt just knowledge‚Äîit was power.  He believed that with the right theories, the Soviet Union could command nature itself: grow more wheat, feed more people, and prove that socialism could outdo the capitalist world.  So when a young agronomist named Trofim Lysenko claimed he‚Äôd found a revolutionary way to make crops adapt and thrive, Stalin made him the face of Soviet science. But behind the promises of abundance came disaster‚Äîfailed harvests, silenced scientists, and decades of lost progress.  üß™ On HISTORY This Week: how Stalin turned science into ideology, and how one man‚Äôs ‚Äúmiracle biology‚Äù reshaped the future of genetics.  üéß LISTEN at the link in our bio or wherever you get your podcasts.  1. ‚ÄúMay Our Motherland Live and Prosper!‚Äù by Petr Semyonovich Golub, 1949  2. ‚ÄúGlory To Inspired Work and Science!‚Äù by Viktor Borisovich Koretskii, 1958  3. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll Be A Chemist!‚Äù by Boris Andreevich Reshetnikov, 1964  4. ‚ÄúThrough Science and Knowledge ‚Äì To High Yields!‚Äù by Mikhail M. Solovyov, 1948  ‚Äî  #history #historypodcast #sciencehistory #Lysenkoism #Stalin #SovietHistory #genetics #pseudoscience #podcast #SovietUnion #USSR #agriculture #historylovers #newpodcast #podcasting #socialism #science

Pooh wasn‚Äôt born in a storybook. He was named after a real bear called Winnie.  August 24, 1914: On a train platform in White River, Ontario, a Canadian soldier spots an orphaned bear cub for sale. He buys her for $20 and names her Winnipeg‚ÄîWinnie for short.  Winnie sails across the Atlantic, ends up at the London Zoo, and meets a little boy named Christopher Robin Milne. That boy renames his teddy bear after her‚Ä¶ and the rest is literary history.  On HISTORY This Week: the true story behind Winnie-the-Pooh‚Äîhow a real bear and a real boy inspired some of the world‚Äôs most beloved characters, and the complicated legacy they left behind.  1. ‚ÄúWinnie the Pooh frieze‚Äù by E.H. üî≠ Breaking from NASA: The Perseverance rover may have just found signs of ancient microbial life on Mars.  üéß Check out the link in our bio to listen to our episode about humanity‚Äôs obsession with the Red Planet. From wild theories of Martian civilizations‚Ä¶ to the discoveries that are still reshaping what we know today.  Our fascination with Mars goes back centuries‚Äîfrom 19th-century astronomers sketching ‚Äúcanals,‚Äù to Orson Welles sparking panic with War of the Worlds, to NASA‚Äôs Mariner 9 battling a global dust storm in 1971 and becoming the first spacecraft to orbit another planet.  Photos:  1. NASA‚Äôs Perseverance Mars rover took this selfie, made up of 62 individual images, on July 23, 2024. A rock nicknamed ‚ÄúCheyava Falls,‚Äô‚Äô which has features that may bear on the question of whether the Red Planet was long ago home to microscopic life, is to the left of the rover near the center of the image. Credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS  2. Mariner 9 was launched successfully on May 30, 1971, and became the first artificial satellite of Mars when it arrived and went into orbit, where it functioned in Martian orbit for nearly a year. Mariner 9 complete its final transmission October 27, 1972. Credit: NASA  3. About 1000 Viking Orbiter red- and violet-filter images have been processed to provide global color coverage of Mars at a scale of 1 km/pixel. Individual image frames acquired during a single spacecraft revolution were first processed through radiometric calibration, cosmetic cleanup, geometric control, reprojection, and mosaicing. Credit: NASA  ‚Äî  #HistoryThisWeek #NASA #Mars #SpaceExploration #Perseverance #Mariner9 #HistoryPodcast

80 years ago, on #ThisDayinHistory, an official announcement of Japan‚Äôs unconditional surrender to the Allies is made public to the world. The Civil Rights Act faced tough opposition in the House of Representatives and a lengthy, heated debate in the Senate before being passed on June 19, 1964. For the signing of this historic legislation on July 2, 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson invited hundreds of guests to a nationally televised ceremony. He used more than 75 pens to sign the bill, and gave one of the first to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.   The Civil Rights Act prohibited racial discrimination in employment and education and outlawed racial segregation in public spaces. It was the most sweeping civil rights legislation passed by Congress since the post-Civil War Reconstruction era.

In 2021, Juneteenth became a federal holiday in the United States. But in some parts of the country, it was celebrated since long before then.   Juneteenth is celebrated because on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865, federal troops arrived in Galveston, Texas in 1865 to take control of the state and ensure that all enslaved people be freed. The troops‚Äô arrival came a full two and a half years after the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation. To learn more about #Juneteenth, visit the link in our bio.

The English claimed many offenses against Joan of Arc. But when they burned her at the stake in Rouen, France on May 30, 1431, they not only immortalized the 19-year-old, but made her a national symbol for the French cause during the long-fought Hundred Years‚Äô War.   Born a peasant in a small French village, the illiterate girl claimed to hear divine voices and see visions of St. Michael, St. Catherine of Alexandria and St. Margaret of Antioch from the age of 13. Their message: Help Charles VII, heir of Charles VI, be named the rightful king of France.   Convincing Charles to let her fight‚Äîand dressed as a man‚ÄîJoan led the liberation of Orleans, triumphed with other victories against the English, and soon Charles VII was crowned.   But a series of missteps, including her failure to liberate Paris, followed, and on May 23, 1430, she was captured by the Duke of Burgundy‚Äôs men, jailed for more than a year and put on trial for charges including heresy, witchcraft and violating divine law for dressing like a man.

Physicist Wilhelm Conrad R√∂ntgen was testing whether cathode rays could pass through blackened cardboard when he noticed a glow coming from a nearby chemically coated screen. He dubbed the rays that caused this glow X-rays because of their unknown nature.   The discovery on #ThisDayInHistoy in 1895 led R√∂ntgen to hole up in his lab, where he would conduct a series of experiments to better understand his discovery.   His discovery would be labeled a miracle, and X-rays soon became an important diagnostic tool in medicine. 70 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Ellis Island shut its doors after processing more than 12 million immigrants since opening in 1892.   During the late 19th and early 20th centuries, many immigrants from Southern and Eastern Europe passed through Ellis Island to enter the United States.    Augustus Sherman, the Chief Registry Clerk at Ellis Island and an amateur photographer, captured the diverse cultures of those arriving from 1904 to 1924.    His photos, some of which are shown here, provide a unique perspective on the immigration experience during this period.

Brick-throwing mobs. Mass arrests. Torched synagogues. Broken glass.   Beginning in the evening on #ThisDayInHistory in 1938, the pogrom now known as Kristallnacht resulted in the destruction of over 7,500 Jewish businesses, 1,000 synagogues and Jewish homes in Germany and Austria. Nearly 100 Jews were murdered during the violence and approximately 30,000 more were arrested and sent to concentration camps.   After the destruction, the Nazis made their victims pay for the damage. The German Jewish community was collectively fined $400 million (US dollars in 1938 rates) and the German government confiscated insurance payouts to Jews for damaged homes and businesses.   Kristallnacht marked a turning point toward more violent and repressive treatment of Jews by the Nazis. By the end of 1938, Jews were prohibited from schools and most public places in Germany.  To read more, visit the link in our bio.

This Presidents‚Äô Day, we are highlighting the United States‚Äô third president - Thomas Jefferson. Born in 1743, he was a leading figure in America‚Äôs early development.  He was the primary author of the Declaration of Independence and served as Secretary of State followed by two terms as president. He nearly doubled the size of the country through the Louisiana Purchase and helped found the University of Virginia. Jefferson enslaved more than 600 people over the course of his life. In recent decades, scholars have shed light on the roles of enslaved people in Jefferson‚Äôs life, and the many ways slavery shaped his legacy. To learn more about the contributions and contradictions of #ThomasJefferson, don‚Äôt miss the 3-night docuseries, premiering TONIGHT.

Beginning on October 26, 1948, a heavy fog settled in a Western Pennsylvania valley near the Monongahela River and the towns of Donora and Webster, PA. This fog trapped airborne pollutants, including sulphuric acid and carbon monoxide, emitted from the area‚Äôs zinc smelting plant and steel mills close to the ground, where they were inhaled by residents. Many residents attempted to flee but the low visibility conditions and increased traffic made leaving difficult, leading hospitals to be flooded with patients experiencing difficulty breathing. It was not until October 31 that Zinc Works shut down operations and rain finally fell, easing the crisis. By the end of the smog, which became known as the worst air pollution disaster in American history, 20 people died and thousands more became seriously ill. To learn more about the Donora Smog, visit the link in our bio.

The woman seen here is Mata Hari, one of World War I‚Äôs most notorious spies. Once Europe‚Äôs most prominent striptease performer, Mata Hari was executed by a French firing squad on #ThisDayInHistroy in 1917 after she was found guilty of spying for Germany. Though her military trial was riddled with bias and circumstantial evidence, French authorities likely trumpeted her as ‚Äúthe greatest woman spy of the century‚Äù as a distraction from the huge losses the French army was suffering on World War I‚Äôs Western Front. The woman pictured here is Belva Lockwood. In 1884, she was a lawyer and a woman running for president of the United States, when women did not have the right to vote in national elections.   Lockwood was an iconic woman in the late 1800s: She was famous for riding her bike through Washington, D.C., which was considered scandalously unladylike. In 1879, she had become the first female lawyer admitted to the Supreme Court bar and in her private practice, she represented all races and sexes.   Though she did not win the presidential race in 1884, or when she ran again in 1888, she still established a legacy. To learn more about #BelvaLockwood, visit the link in our bio.
Diana, Princess of Wales, was one of the most popular public figures in the world. Her death, on #ThisDayInHistory in 1997, was met with a massive outpouring of grief.

Eight terrorists- associated with the militant Palestinian group Black September-reached the Olympic Village at the Summer Games in Munich before dawn on #ThisDayInHistory in 1972. Their goal was to hold the Israeli athletes hostage and demand the release of more than 200 prisoners. The terrorists entered the apartment complex where Israeli athletes were staying, murdered an Israeli Olympic coach and an athlete, and took nine others hostage. An estimated 900 million people around the world watched in horror as the international nightmare unfolded on live TV. When authorities attempted a ruse to rescue the hostages after a 23-hour standoff, all the hostages, one West German police officer and five Black September members were killed.    Following the attack, the Games were suspended for 34 hours, and a memorial service was held the following day in the Olympic Stadium. It would not be until the 2020 Summer Olympics, held in 2021 due to the Covid-19 pandemic, when a moment of silence was observed in the opening ceremony.

London in 1666 was a city primed for disaster: Its medieval houses were made mostly of oak timber. Some had walls covered in tar, which kept the rain out but made the structure more vulnerable to fire. Streets were narrow, houses were crowded together, and the firefighting methods of the day consisted of neighborhood bucket brigades.   In the early hours of #ThisDayInHistory in 1666, the Great Fire of London broke out. Over the next few days, more than four-fifths of the city were destroyed.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

This is a picture of Romualdo Pacheco, one of the first-ever Latinos to serve in the U.S. Congress. By 1877, the wealthy Mexican American sailor, hunter, and rancher was a familiar face in California politics. He then set his sights on a national office, but he was far from a shoo-in.   Pacheco ran to represent a large Southern California district against incumbent Democrat Peter D. Wigginton and eked out a hard-fought victory by only one vote. But Wigginton contested the election and accused a county clerk of tampering with ballots.  Pacheco petitioned the California Supreme Court, which investigated and ruled in Pacheco‚Äôs favor, and he set out for Washington, D.C. But three months after he took office, it was stripped from him by the House‚Äôs Committee on Elections. Pacheco, however, was undaunted, and when Wigginton declined to run for re-election, Pacheco ran again and won.  Though other Hispanic men had served as Congressional territorial delegates before him, he was the first state representative to the U.S. House of Representatives of Latino heritage and he remains the only Latino to have served as governor of the state of California.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1998, University of Wyoming student Matthew Shepard died of injuries sustained in a brutal attack six days earlier. The attack sparked national outrage and renewed calls for extending hate crime laws to cover violence based on a person‚Äôs sexual orientation. The attackers, Russell Henderson and Aaron McKinney, were sentenced to life in prison and their girlfriends, who had helped the men dispose of evidence, were charged as accessories to the murder. In the aftermath of Shepard‚Äôs death, his parents established the Matthew Shepard Foundation to inspire the world to embrace the dignity of all people. This photo shows Emmett Till‚Äôs mother, Mamie Till-Mobley, as she watches her son‚Äôs burial.   Emmett Till, a 14-year-old boy from Chicago, was murdered for allegedly flirting with a white woman while visiting his family in Mississippi. The white woman, Carolyn Bryant, who with her husband owned a store Till and his cousins visited, claimed Till grabbed her, made lewd advances and whistled at her as he walked out of the store. Her husband Roy Bryant and his brother-in-law J.W. Milam kidnapped and brutally, murdered Emmett Till on #ThisDayInHistory in 1955. It was not until an interview in 2008  that Carolyn Bryant recanted her testimony.   To learn more about how Emmett Till‚Äôs death galvanized the Civil Rights Movement, visit the link in our bio.

At 10:51 pm ET on July 20, 1969, five hours ahead of the original schedule, Neil Armstrong began his descent from the lunar module and became the first human to walk on the surface of the moon. While Michael Collins remained in the module, Buzz Aldrin joined Armstrong on the moon‚Äôs surface and together they took photographs of the terrain, planted a U.S. flag, ran a few simple scientific tests and spoke with President Nixon in the Oval Office via telephone-radio transmission. Nixon later called it ‚Äúthe most historic telephone call ever made.‚Äù To learn more about what happened on #ThisDayInHistory, visit the link in our bio.

A U.S. military plane crashed into the Empire State Building on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Read more below:   Thick fog blanketed New York City as a B-25 Mitchell bomber flew into the area on July 28, 1945. Air-traffic controllers diverted the plane to fly to Newark Airport instead of LaGuardia and as it flew over Manhattan, the crew was specifically warned that the Empire State Building, the world‚Äôs tallest building at the time, was not visible. Flying low for better visibility, the plane swerved to avoid the Chrysler Building, sending it straight into the 79th floor of the Empire State Building. Since it was a Saturday, fewer workers than normal were in the building but 11 people inside were killed, as well as 3 on the plane. The plane‚Äôs fuel exploded, causing a massive fire and leaving an enormous hole in the side of the building.

The influential American literacy icon Ernest Hemingway was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1899. With this trademark direct and straightforward style, the author‚Äôs work covered travel, war, love and loss and he became equally famous for both his rugged outdoor pursuits and his hard-partying lifestyle and romantic affairs.

Rosa Parks was born on February 4, 1913. #DidYouKnow when she refused to give up her bus seat in 1955, it wasn‚Äôt the first time she‚Äôd clashed with the driver, James Blake? On a chilly day twelve years earlier, Parks had stepped onto a crowded bus driven by Blake, paid her fare and resisted the rule in place for Black people to disembark and re-enter through the back door. She stood her ground until Blake pulled her coat sleeve, enraged, to demand her cooperation. On that earlier occasion, Parks chose to leave the bus rather than give in.  To learn more about #rosaparks, visit the link in our bio.

In May 1925, John Thomas Scopes, a young high school science teacher in Tennessee, was accused of teaching evolution in violation of a Tennessee state law. The law, which had been passed March of 1925, made it a misdemeanor punishable by fine for instructors in state-funded schools to ‚Äúteach any theory that denies the story of the Divine Creation of man as taught in the Bible, and to teach instead that man has descended from a lower order of animals.‚Äù On #ThisDayInHistory in 1925, the trial of John Thomas Scopes began. The trial featured two of the best-known orators of the era, William Jennings Bryan and Clarence Darrow, as opposing attorneys, and is one of the most famous trials in American history, but it all started as a kind of publicity stunt for the small town of Dayton, Tennessee. To find out what happened in the case, visit the link in our bio.

A 2,800-mile cross-country trek to advocate for Native American rights ended on #ThisDayInHistory in 1978. The intent of the ‚ÄúLongest Walk,‚Äù which went from San Francisco to Washington, D.C. and was organized by the American Indian Movement (AIM), was to call attention to issues affecting Native Americans, including a lack of jobs and housing, as well as proposed legislation that would have eliminated federal treaties with Native Americans, the reservation system, and federal programs for Native American schools, hospitals, and housing. Ultimately, none of the bills passed. To learn more about AIM visit the link in our bio.

Juneteenth marks the day in 1865 when federal troops publicly read the Emancipation Proclamation in Galveston, Texas. The troops had arrived in Texas several days earlier to take control of the state and ensure that all enslaved people were freed. The troops‚Äô arrival came a full two and a half years after the signing of the Emancipation Proclamation. #Juneteenth honors the end to slavery in the U.S. and is considered the longest-running African American holiday. https://www.history.com/news/what-is-juneteenth

John Fitzgerald Kennedy, Jr., son of the 35th U.S. President John F. Kennedy, was born on November 25, 1960, just weeks after his father was elected. He became an assistant district attorney, was the founder of the political magazine George, and in 1988, he was named the "Sexiest Man Alive" by People magazine. In September 1996, Kennedy married fashion publicist, Carolyn Bessette.    On #ThisDayInHistory in 1999, Kennedy took off from Essex County, New Jersey, bound for Hyannis Port, Massachusetts, by way of Martha‚Äôs Vineyard, with his wife and sister-in-law on board. It was a hazy, nearly moonless night with reduced visibility‚Äînear the threshold for having to fly using instruments rather than by visual rules. While he had some 300 hours of flight experience, Kennedy was a relatively inexperienced pilot and was not yet fully licensed for instrument landings.    Kennedy's plane disappeared from radar around 9:30pm and the Coast Guard began searching for the missing plane at about 4am. On July 21, Navy divers recovered the bodies of JFK Jr., Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, and Lauren Bessette from the plane crash wreckage, located some 100 feet underwater and nearly 8 miles off the shore of Martha‚Äôs Vineyard. The next morning, their cremated remains were scattered at sea off Martha‚Äôs Vineyard.

Willie Mays, one of the greatest baseball players in history, has died at the age of 93.  He began his career in baseball at the age of 16 when he joined the Negro League and a few years later, after graduating high school, he signed with the New York Giants. Mays was a 24-time All Star, two-time MVP and was elected to the Hall of Fame in 1979. His iconic catch in Game 1 of the 1954 World Series is known as one of the most famous plays in history.  In addition to being the top all-around player in his time, he was a hero to his local community in Harlem. He would play stickball with the children and his joyful aura earned him the nickname ‚ÄúSay Hey Kid.‚Äù

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1967, President Lyndon B. Johnson nominated Thurgood Marshall, a longtime civil rights attorney for the NAACP, to fill the U.S. Supreme Court seat of retiring justice Tom C. Clark. Marshall became the first African American in history to sit on America‚Äôs highest court when his nomination was confirmed by the U.S. Senate on August 30, 1967.   During his 24 years on the Supreme Court, Associate Justice Marshall consistently challenged discrimination based on race or sex, opposed the death penalty, and supported the rights of criminal defendants. He also defended affirmative action and women‚Äôs rights to reproductive freedom.

When the compact disc hit America in the 1980s, it changed how we listened to music on the go. But long before the CD‚Äôs major mainstream moment, two huge tech companies battled back and forth for decades‚Äîand eventually joined forces‚Äîto make waves in the growing personal audio market: Sony and Philips. Robert F. Kennedy served as attorney general in his brother John F. Kennedy‚Äôs presidential administration and played key roles in helping shape JFK‚Äôs policies and vision. RFK was then elected to the U.S. Senate from New York and in March 1968 announced his candidacy for the presidency. Many know the story of what happened pictured above on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969. But if you don‚Äôt, please read more below.   By the late 1960s, the Stonewall Inn was an important institution for New York‚Äôs LGBTQ+ community.  At a time when bars serving the LGBTQ+ community were frequently harassed by the police, Stonewall welcomed everyone from drag queens to runaway LGBTQ+ youth. Further, the bar was owned by organized crime figures who paid off crooked police to tip them off to impending raids. But when the police raided the crowded Stonewall Inn in the early morning on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969, there was no warning. Within minutes, a full-blown riot involving hundreds of people began. Though the Stonewall Riots did not start the gay rights movement, it was a galvanizing force for LGBTQ+ political activism, leading to the formation of numerous gay rights organizations.

60 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, President Lyndon B. Johnson signed the historic Civil Rights Act of 1964. The act prohibited racial discrimination in employment and education and outlawed racial segregation in public places such as schools, buses, parks and swimming pools. Johnson used 75 pens to sign the bill and gave them away as mementoes of the historic occasion. One of the first pens went to Martin Luther King, Jr.

Today marks the 80th anniversary of D-Day, when Allied forces landed some 156,000 soldiers on the beaches of Normandy on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944. D-Day was the largest amphibious invasion in history and by the end of August 1944, most of Northern France had been liberated. Historians often refer to D-Day as the beginning of the end of World War II. Tonight, relive the Allied invasion through the voices and words of those who were there, from all sides. D-Day: The Unheard Tapes premieres tonight at 8/7c. #DDayUnheardTapes

Speaking from near the western side of the Berlin Wall at a ceremony to commemorate the 750th anniversary of Berlin‚Äôs founding, President Ronald Reagan famously declared, ‚ÄúMr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall,‚Äù on #ThisDayInHistory in 1987. Although the speech initially received little press coverage, it became one of the most well-known of Reagan‚Äôs career and served as a dramatic appeal to Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev to reunify the city of Berlin, which had been divided by the wall for 26 years at the time of Reagan‚Äôs speech. The wall finally was opened and then torn down by city residents in November 1989.

This video shows NAACP field secretary and civil rights activist Medgar Evers speaking at a rally. After growing up under segregation in Mississippi, Evers volunteered for the U.S. Army and participated in the Normandy invasion during World War II. In the 1950s, he became active in the burgeoning civil rights movement, working to protest segregation and encouraging African Americans to register to vote. In 1954, he was named as the NAACP‚Äôs first field secretary for Mississippi and participated in the successful effort to desegregate the University of Mississippi.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1963, Evers was fatally shot in the driveway outside his home by white supremacist Byron De La Beckwith.

Six months after shocking the world by abdicating the British throne, the Duke of Windsor‚Äîformerly King Edward VIII‚Äî married Wallis Simpson on #ThisDayInHistory in 1937. The Duke claimed he could not carry out his duties as king ‚Äúwithout the help and support‚Äù of the woman he loved, a 41-year-old American who had been married, divorced, and married again by the time she met Edward. With the British government, the Church of England, and his family all opposing their marriage, even after she divorced her second husband, Edward chose to abdicate rather than give up a life with Simpson.

The man picture here, Fred Korematsu, was arrested for resisting internment under President Franklin D. Roosevelt‚Äôs controversial Executive Order 9066. This order led to the incarceration of some 120,000 Japanese Americans in the wake of Japan‚Äôs attack on Pearl Harbor.  Following his conviction and incarceration, Korematsu filed suit in federal court. His case made its way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which upheld the government‚Äôs claim that the incarceration of Japanese Americans was a matter of ‚Äúmilitary urgency.‚Äù But in 1983, a judge overturned Korematsu‚Äôs conviction and he was later awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Some 250,000 people were imprisoned at the Buchenwald concentration camp, and more than 56,000 died, from disease, malnutrition, beatings and executions. Doctors and scientists also performed medical experiments on inmates, testing the effects of vaccines against contagious disease. On April 11, 1945, anticipating the arrival of Allied troops, the prisoners assumed control of Buchenwald, and the American Third Army liberated the camp later that day. Among those rescued by the Americans was future activist and author Elie Wiesel. At the outbreak of World War I in 1914, the United States remained on the sidelines, adopting the policy of neutrality, while continuing to engage in commerce and shipping with European countries on both sides of the conflict. However, it was increasingly difficult to maintain neutrality after several U.S. ships were damaged or sunk by German mines. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1917, two days after the U.S. Senate voted to declare war against Germany, the U.S. House of Representatives endorsed the declaration and America formally entered the Great War. To read more about #WorldWarI, visit the link in our bio.

The Falkland Islands, located about 300 miles off the southern tip of Argentina, had long been controlled by Great Britain but also claimed by Argentina . But on #ThisDayInHistory in 1982, Argentina invaded the Falkland Islands. Under orders from their commanders, Argentine troops inflicted no British casualties, and Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher assembled a naval task force of 30 warships to retake the islands. As Britain is 8,000 miles away, it took several weeks for the British warships to arrive. By June 14, the Argentine troops surrendered, effectively ending the conflict.   Humiliated in the Falkland Wars, the Argentine military was swept from power in 1983 and civilian rule was restored. In Britain, Margaret Thatcher‚Äôs popularity soared after the conflict.   To read more about the Falkland Wars, visit the link in our bio.

The photos here show the Terracotta warriors that were unearthed on March 29, 1974.   While digging a well near Xi‚Äôan, China, farmers discovered a filled-in pit containing 6,000 life-size terracotta soldiers. The site was soon identified as the burial place of Emperor Qin. In addition to the large pit containing the soldiers, three more pits were discovered.   The army of life-size soldiers, archers, horses, and chariots was stationed in military formation to protect the emperor in the afterlife. The restoration of the figures revealed that the workers used molds and assembly lines to complete each one.   Even after 50 years after its discovery, less than 1% of Emperor Qin‚Äôs tomb has been excavated. To read more about the discovery on #ThisDayInHistory, visit the link in our bio.

The danger of fire in factories like the Triangle Shirtwaist was well-know, but high levels of corruption in both the garment industry and city government generally ensured that no useful precautions were taken to prevent fires.   On March 25, 1911, with over 500 workers ‚Äì the majority girls and young women - present in the factory, a fire began in a rag bin. Workers and managers attempted to use the firehouse to extinguish it but was unsuccessful. The young workers tried to exit by the elevator, but it was only able to make four trips before it broke down. Workers resorted to fleeing through the stairwells but found themselves locked out of the only accessible one. Those working in floors above were able to escape to the roof and jump to adjoining buildings. And girls who did not make it to the other options began to jump from the windows to escape. Once the firefighters arrived, it took 18 minutes to bring the fire under control. But a total of 146 people were killed in the fire.   The fire helped unite organized labor and reform-minded politicians and the workers union set up a march to protest the conditions that led to the fire.   To read more about the Triangle Shirtwaist Factory fire on #ThisDayInHistory, visit the link in our bio.   üì∏  This photo shows the gutted remains of the tenth floor, with only the floors and walls intact üì∏ Triangle Shirtwaist Company Fire Aftermath üì∏ Fire Engines On Way to Triangle Shirtwaist Fire

After her husband was incapacitated in an accident, Emily Warren Roebling (pictured) took over supervising the construction of the Brooklyn Bridge. Learn more below.   The construction of the Brooklyn Bridge began with a freak accident. In 1869, bridge designer John Augustus Roebling was hit by an approaching ferry. He died three weeks later, and the job of chief engineer went to his eldest son, Washington Roebling.   Three years later, Washington himself was incapacitated by ‚Äúcaisson disease‚Äù (now known as decompression sickness or ‚Äúthe bends‚Äù). With the chief engineer confined to his bed, his wife, Emily Warren Roebling, stepped up and steered the completion of one of the 19th century‚Äôs most impressive achievements. She served as both nurse and private secretary, taking over his letters, keeping his notebooks, reviewing construction plans and more. And he never failed to give credit to his wife for her contributions to the bridge.   Engineer or not, Emily‚Äôs influence on one of the world‚Äôs most famous architectural icons remains undeniable. To learn more about #EmilyRoebling and the #BrooklynBridge, visit the link in our bio.

Although they engaged in lighthearted socializing in living rooms, Tupperware party organizers were running thriving, women-owned businesses. And the women who participated in them weren‚Äôt just stocking their homes; they were experimenting with cutting-edge technology that helped food stay fresh for longer. While traveling home from school, Claudette Colvin and her three Black friends were ordered to give up their row on a bus to a white passenger. Her friends obliged but 15-year-old Colvin refused. In refusing to move, she cited that she paid her fare and that staying seated was her constitutional right. She was forcibly removed from the bus by two police officers, handcuffed, arrested, and booked in a local adult jail on #ThisDayInHistory in 1955.   She was charged with violating segregation law, disorderly conduct and assaulting a police officer. The former two charges were dropped, but the latter stayed on her record until 2021.   Nine months later, the Montgomery Bus Boycott began.   Explore more her story and more the link in our bio.

Civil rights leader Malcolm X took the stage at the Audubon Ballroom in Washington Heights on #ThisDayInHistory in 1965. Just moments later, the former prominent Nation of Islam figure was gunned down by three men as his wife, Betty Shabazz, pregnant with twins and four daughters took cover in the front row. All three men were members of the Nation of Islam and were indicted on first-degree murder chargers.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1993, a terrorist bomb exploded in a parking garage of the World Trade Center leaving a massive, multi-story crater and causing the collapse of several steel-reinforced concrete floors. Six people were killed and more than 1,000 were injured. City authorities and the FBI undertook a massive manhunt for suspects, and within days several radical Islamic fundamentalists were arrested but the mastermind of the attacked remained at large until February 1995. Albert Einstein, born on March 14, 1879, developed the first of his groundbreaking theories while working in the Swiss patent office. After making his name with four scientific articles in 1905, he went on to win worldwide fame for his general theory of relativity and a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect. To learn more about the events on #ThisDayInHistory and #AlbertEinstein, visit the link in our bio.

The executive order signed on #ThisDayInHistory in 1942 initiated a controversial World War II policy with lasting consequences for Japanese Americans.   Japanese immigrants and their descendants, regardless of American citizenship status or length of residence, were systematically rounded up and placed in prison camps. Evacuees could take only as many possessions as they could carry and were forcibly placed in crude, cramped quarters.   The last Japanese internment camp closed in March 1946. President Gerald Ford officially repealed the order in 1976 and in 1988, Congress issued a formal apology and passed the Civil Liberties Act awarding $20,000 each to over 80,000 Japanese Americans as reparations for their treatment. To learn more about the #JapaneseInternmentCamps, visit the link in our bio.

Have you heard of the White Rose (Weisse Rose) resistance group? The White Rose was composed of university students who spoke out against Adolf Hitler and his regime.  The Weisse Rose co-founder, Hans Scholl, was a former member of Hitler Youth who grew disenchanted with Nazi ideology once its real aims became evident. As a student of the University of Munich in 1940-1941, he met two Roman Catholic men of letters who redirected his life. Scholl gathered like-minded friends who also despised the Nazis, and the White Rose was born.   During the summer of 1942, Scholl and a friend composed four leaflets, which exposed and denounced Nazi and SS atrocities, including the extermination of Jews and Polish nobility, and called for resistance to the regime.   The risks involved were enormous and on #ThisDayInHistory in 1943, Hans and his sister Sophie, were arrested and, four days later, sentenced to death. To learn more about the White Rose and other resistance groups, visit the link in our bio.  The photos above feature members of the White Rose resistance group.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1928, a woman calling herself Anastasia Tchaikovsky and claiming to be the youngest daughter of the murdered Russian czar Nicholas II, arrived in New York City. Between 1918 and 1928, more than half a dozen other woman had come forward claiming to be a lost heir to the Romanov fortune, so many American reporters were understandingly skeptical of her claims.  She was welcomed to New York by Gleb Botkin, the son of the Romanov family doctor and claimed that she was without a doubt the Grand Duchess Anastasia with whom he played as a child.   The woman took on an alias, Anna Anderson, but continued her fight for recognition.  To learn more about the Romanovs and Anastasia, visit the link in our bio.   üì∏ circa 1915: Grand Duchess Anastasia üì∏ Anna Anderson; 1955

Did you know Coretta Scott King took an interest in activism before she married the man who would become the nation‚Äôs foremost civil rights leader?   Born in Alabama, she experienced racism from a young age. Her family‚Äôs landownership made them a target for white racists who burned down their home. She attended a segregated school where she graduated top of her class. From there, she headed to an integrated school in Ohio where she joined the NAACP and college committees focused on racial equality.   She would later meet King in 1952 and together, they became involved in the Montgomery Bus Boycott. She even helped King as he developed talks and sermons, offering suggestions on his speeches and strategy.    Throughout her 13-year marriage to King and in the decades after his death, she worked for justice, standing against racism and war. To learn more about #CorettaScottKing, visit the link in our bio.

When four young men sat down at a ‚Äúwhites-only‚Äù lunch counter, they drew national attention. By simply remaining in their seats peacefully and quietly, they baffled the staff and left them unsure how to enforce their ‚Äúwhites-only‚Äù rule. The students, Ezell Blair, Jr., Franklin McCain, Joseph McNeil and David Richmond, sat until the store closed and promised they would be back the next day. By the end of the week, more than 200 protested at the store.   The demonstration that began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1960 continued for nearly six months, until Woolworth gave in and integrated the lunch counter.   To learn more about the #GreensboroSitIns, visit the link in our bio.  üì∏ This view shows Black youths gathered at a downtown lunch counter today staging a sit-down strike for the third time in 5 days. At the San Diego Open on January 17, 1952, former boxing champion and talent amateur golfer Joe Louis competed in the PGA-sanctioned event as an invited amateur. But professional Bill Spiller, a Black golfer, was denied entry. (Louis‚Äô entry as an amateur was not governed by PGA rules.)  Because of Joe Louis‚Äô criticism and pressure after Spiller‚Äôs rejection, the PGA announced on #ThisDayInHistory in 1952 that Black golfers would be allowed to compete ‚Äì if invited - in PGA co-sponsored events.   Alongside Louis and Spiller, Ted Rhodes and Eural Clark would go onto to break the PGA‚Äôs color barrier at the Phoenix Open.   But it would take years for the sport to approach full integration. The PGA would not remove the ‚ÄúCaucasian-only clause‚Äô from its bylaws until 1961. In March 1960, President Dwight D. Eisenhower ordered the CIA to train and arm a force of Cuban exiles for an attack on Cuba in an attempt to topple the Communist government led by Fidel Castro. John F. Kennedy inherited this program when he became president and on #ThisDayInHistory in 1961, around 1,200 exiles, armed with American weapons and using American landing craft, waded ashore at the Bay of Pigs in Cuba. The plan immediately fell apart and the failure helped Castro to solidify his power and attract new military aid from the Soviet Union. United States Surgeon General Luther Terry knew his report was a bombshell and intentionally released it on #ThisDayInHistory in 1964, a Saturday, to limit the immediate effects on the stock market. The link had long been suspected and the first medical studies that raised serious concerns were published in the late 1940s. During this time, sex work was a major part of the backstage of the world of the Paris Opera Ballet, the world‚Äôs first professional ballet company. Wealthy men preyed on the exploited dancers, buying sexual favors from the woman they watched on stage. In fact, this was a part of the Opera‚Äôs very architecture, designed with a separate entrance for season ticket holders, and a foyer for male patrons to socialize with‚Äîand proposition‚Äîballet dancers. Subscribers‚Äô power influenced who made it into coveted roles or was fired from the ballet, making it difficult for ballerinas to turn down the advances of the men. Even dancers who were able to succeed independently of a rich patron were looked down upon as suspected prostitutes. To learn more, visit the link in our bio. #BallerinaHistory #WomensHistoryMonth

An explosion rocked the Sago Mine in Sago, West Virginia on #ThisDayInHistory in 2006 trapping 13 coal miners. As crews above tried and failed to locate the miners, those trapped took emergency action to shield themselves from the fumes but were eventually overcome. The survivor, Randal McCloy, Jr. recalled the group praying together and writing letters to their loved ones. Rescuers finally reached the miners over 40 hours later. In the wake of this tragedy, West Virginia quickly passes a law mandating multiple escapeways.

Henry Kissinger, the 56th U.S. Secretary of State, died at the age of 100.  Born in Germany, his family fled to America in 1938 to escape the Nazi regime. Following his military service where he was awarded a Bronze Star, he attended Harvard University, where he later taught and consulted with the Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson administrations on national security issues. As Secretary of State under Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford, he gained recognition for his strong, pragmatic influence in international diplomacy. Kissinger was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1973 for his part in helping negotiate an end to the Vietnam War.  Kissinger also drew controversy, with critics arguing that some of his decisions led to human rights violations and that he was too accepting of the authoritarian policies of U.S. allies. Kissinger also received the Presidential Medal of Freedom and the Medal of Liberty.

American screenwriter and producer, Norman Lear, has died at the age of 101. Known for "All in the Family," "The Jeffersons," "Sanford and Son," and more, he developed over 100 shows. The Battle of the Somme began as an Allied offensive against German forces along the Western Front of World War I. The battle turned into one of the most bitter, deadly, and costly battles. By the time it ended on #ThisDayInHistory in 1916, more than 3 million solders on both sides had fought in the battle and more than 1 million had been killed or wounded. Why was it so deadly? While traveling through Dallas, Texas, in an open-top convertible, President John F. Kennedy was assassinated on #ThisDayInHistory in 1963. Recently sworn in, President Lyndon B. Johnson declared November 25 a day of mourning as a nation grieved its slain leader. His funeral procession was viewed by hundreds of thousands of people in the streets of Washington, D.C., as they solemnly paid their respects to the nation‚Äôs 35th president.    #Kennedy revealed the legacy left behind by one of the most well-known American presidents. As America‚Äôs First Lady from 1977-1981, Rosalynn Carter was a humanitarian who advocated for mental health and other important issues. Throughout Jimmy Carter‚Äôs political career, she was one of his biggest assets and supporters, and as lifelong companions they were inseparable. In 1978, the Office of the First Lady was established, and she helped shape the role of the modern first lady. Along with her vital work for the mentally ill, she helped revamp federal programs for the elderly and advocated for the Equal Rights Amendment. She was instrumental in leading the Carter Center in Atlanta, which is dedicated to peace and human rights worldwide. Carter has died at the age of 96.

On November 7, 1938, Ernst vom Rath was shot inside the German embassy in Paris by Herschel Grynszpan, who wanted revenge for his parents‚Äô sudden deportation from Germany to Poland.   Following vom Rath‚Äôs death, Nazi propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels ordered German storm troopers to carry out violent riots disguised as ‚Äúspontaneous demonstrations‚Äù against Jewish citizens. This campaign of terror began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1938 and is known as Kristallnacht.   In the aftermath of Kristallnacht, the Nazis blamed the Jews and fined them 1 billion marks for vom Rath‚Äôs death. As repayment, the government seized Jewish property and kept insurance money owed to Jewish people.   Over 100,000 Jews fled Germany for other countries after Kristallnacht. D.B. Cooper commandeered an aircraft from Northwest Orient Airlines shortly after takeoff, showing a flight attendant something that looked like a bomb. He informed the crew that he wanted $200,000, four parachutes and ‚Äúno funny stuff.‚Äù Once the plane landed at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, where authorities met his demands, he then demanded that the plane fly towards Mexico.  Around 8:13pm, on #ThisDayInHistory in 1971, D.B. Cooper jumped from the aircraft, wearing only wraparound sunglasses, a thin suit, and a raincoat. He parachuted into a thunderstorm which prevented an immediate capture. No trace of Cooper was found, and his fate remains a mystery.   Who was D.B. Cooper? Link in bio.

When Jane Goodall was a 26-year-old, she was conducting research at Gombe Stream National Park in Northern Tanganyika, what is now as Northern Tanzania, where she closely studied a group of approximately 150 chimpanzees in their natural habitat. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1960, she spotted one of the chimps, whom she named David Greybeard, engaging in tool-use by stripping leaves from a straw stick and then inserting it into a termite mound to extract the insects.   The pivotal discovery, along with Goodall‚Äôs meticulous documentation of chimpanzees‚Äô cognitive abilities and capability for problem-solving, shattered long-held assumptions about animal intelligence.

If you had a nickel on #ThisDayInHistory in 1904, you would have had the chance to take your first ride on the New York City subway.   Mayor George McClellan took the controls on the inaugural run of the city‚Äôs subway and later more than 100,000 people would take their first ride under Manhattan.

Photographer Edward S. Curtis set out on an epic mission: to capture the experiences of Native Americans throughout the American West. When Curtis approached various tribes, their way of life had already been forcibly changed by the U.S. government policies, so he staged many of the photos. He paid his subjects to dress in traditional clothing that most no longer wore. The photographs commanded respect for a group of people that had been marginalized over the span of the 19th century. But the work was also met with criticism.

Congress put forth the National Prohibition Act, commonly known as the Volstead Act, on #ThisDayInHistory in 1919, which provided guidelines for the federal enforcement of Prohibition.   Despite very early signs of success, including a decline in arrests for drunkenness and a reported 30% drop in alcohol consumption, those who wanted to keep drinking found ever more inventive ways to do it. Beginning sometime on October 26, 1948, weather conditions in the valley brought a heavy fog into Donora, PA. This fog appeared to trap airborne pollutants emitted from the zinc smelting plant and steel mills close to the ground, where they were inhaled by the local residents.   Many residents attempted to evacuate, but the heavy smog and increased traffic made leaving difficult. It was not until October 31 that the zinc workers shut down operations and rain came to disperse the pollutants.  Over the five-day period, the smog killed about 20 people and made thousands seriously ill. In the aftermath, air pollution finally became a matter of public concern; the incident led to the passage of the 1955 Air Pollution Control Act and the 1963 Clean Air Act. To learn more about this, visit the link in our bio.

Ralph Lazo (pictured on the right) was one of the only known persons of non-Japanese ancestry who volunteered to live in an internment camp. World War II was a defining moment for both Mexican American and Japanese American communities. To learn more about Ralph Lazo and the Japanese Internment Camps, visit the link in our bio.

In a televised speech, President John F. Kennedy announced on #ThisDayInHistory in 1962 that U.S. spy planes have discovered Soviet missile bases in Cuba.   He explained his decision to enact a naval blockade around Cuba and made it clear the U.S. was prepared to use military force if necessary to neutralize this perceived threat to national security.   However, the disaster was avoided when the U.S. agreed to Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev‚Äôs offer to remove the Cuban missiles in exchange for the U.S. removing missiles it had stationed in Turkey.  #Kennedy #CubanMissileCrisis #PresidentialHistory ‚Äú

Movie star Richard Burton bought Elizabeth Taylor a 69-carat diamond ring on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969. The couple‚Äôs stormy private life often drew more attention than their movie roles and their extravagance was legendary. During the 1960s, they earned a combined $88 million and spent more than $65 million. Taylor and Burton became estranged in 1970, formally separated in 1973, divorced in 1974. They remarried in 1975 then divorced for the second and last time a year later. The diamond went up for auction and Elizabeth Taylor would go on to have two more husbands, both of whom she‚Äôd divorce.   #ElizabethTaylor #EngagementRing

When Frida Kahlo was 18 years old, she seemed on the verge of claiming the life she‚Äôd imagined. But in September 1924, all of that changed.   When the bus Kahlo was riding hit a trolley car, she suffered serious internal injuries as a long metal rod tore through her midsection. Her injuries were so severe that she had to be encased in a full-body plaster case. The carefree years of her childhood ended abruptly. But what sustained her throughout her days in bed was painting.   As she gained confidence and self-assurance as a painter, she began alluding to a range of traumas she endured. Her depiction of her suffering was groundbreaking.  To learn more about Frida Kahlo, visit the link in our bio.

For the first time in U.S. history, a debate between major party presidential candidates was broadcast on live television on #ThisDayInHIstory in 1960. Vice President of the United States, Richard Nixon and a Democratic senator from Massachusetts, John F. Kennedy, met in a Chicago studio to debate the ways they would lead the nation if elected president. An audience of over 70 million viewers watched Nixon and Kennedy square off. The political landscape was changed forever as television became a key way that voters learned about and assessed political candidates.  Visit the link in our bio to learn more about Nixon and Kennedy‚Äôs first televised debate.

The notorious Red Scare kicked into high gear as a Congressional committee began investigating Communist influencer in Hollywood on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. The committee grilled several prominent witnesses including Elia Kazan, Gary Cooper and Jack Warner who gave names of colleagues they suspected of being communists.   A small group known as the ‚ÄúHollywood Ten‚Äù resisted, complaining that the hearings were illegal and violated their First Amendment rights. The Hollywood Ten were all convicted of obstructing the investigation and served jail times.   Pressured by Congress, many Hollywood establishments started a blacklist policy, banning the work of more than 300 screenwriters, actors and directors. Some of the blacklisted writers used pseudonyms to continue working. And in 1997, the Writers‚Äô Guild of America unanimously voted to change the writing credits made during this period, reversing ‚Äì not erasing ‚Äì some of the damage done during the Red Scare.

There were many legal and procedural difficulties to overcome in setting up the Nuremberg Trials. First, there was no precedent for an international trial of war criminals. But the Allies eventually established the laws and procedures.   Twenty-four individuals were indicted, along with six Nazi organizations determined to be criminal (such as the ‚ÄúGestapo,‚Äù or secret state police). Few were unable to make it to trial. But in the end, the international tribunal found all but three of the defendants guilty. Twelve were sentenced to death, one in absentia, and the rest were given prison sentences ranging from 10 years to life behind bars.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1995, an estimated 140 million Americans listened in as the verdict of The People of the State of California vs. Orenthal James Simpson was read. In the epic 252-day trial, OJ‚Äôs ‚Äúdream team‚Äù of lawyers employed creative and controversial methods to convince the jurors that Simpson‚Äôs guilt had not been proved ‚Äúbeyond a reasonable doubt.‚Äù   Two years later, Simpson was found liable for several charges related to the murders in a civil trial and was forced to award $33.6 million in compensatory and punitive damages to Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman‚Äôs families.   To learn more about this trial, visit the link in our bio.

It was never just music, or the passion Janis Joplin displayed in performing it that made her an icon. It was the no-holds-barred gusto with which she lived every other aspect of her life as well.   Far from being an empty clich√©, ‚Äúsex, drugs and rock and roll‚Äù was a revolutionary philosophy to many in the late 1960s, and Janis was its leading female exponent.  In the autumn of 1970, Janis was putting the finishing touches on the album that would prove to be the biggest hit of her career, but she did not live to see its release.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1970, she died of an accidental overdose.

The last execution by guillotine occurred on #ThisDayInHistory in 1977, only 46 years ago.   The guillotine was first used widely during the French Revolution when physician and revolutionary Joseph-Ignace Guillotin helped win passage of a law requiring all death sentences to be carried out by ‚Äúmeans of a machine.‚Äù   Decapitating machines had been used earlier in Ireland and England and Guillotin and his supporters viewed these devices as more humane than other execution techniques.   In September 1981, France outlawed capital punishment altogether, thus ending the use of the guillotine.   Interested in reading more, visit the link in our bio.   üì∏ Guillotine en France; 1920

Did you know in the late 1960s, grapes grabbed national attention...   #ThisDayInHistory in 1965 marked the beginning of one of the most important strikes in American history. When over 2,000 Filipino-American farm workers refused to go to work picking grapes, they set into motion a chain of events that would extend over the next five years.   When the strike was declared, labor organizer Larry Itliong asked for the support of the National Farmers Workers Association and its Mexican-American founders, Cesar Chavez and Dolores Huerta.   It took time, but their efforts paid off: in 1970, farm workers won a contract promising better pay and benefits. And a few years later, their efforts led to the passage of the California Agricultural Labor Relations Act of 1975.   To learn more about the #DelanoGrapeStrike, visit the link in our bio.   üì∏ Picketers gather at edge of grape field here to urge workers to join strike

Mount Rushmore was the brainchild of a South Dakota historian named Doane Robinson, who was looking for a way to attract more tourists to his state. He hired a sculptor named Gutzon Borglum to carve the faces into the mountain. Though the Lakota Sioux people, who considered the Black Hills to be sacred ground, strongly opposed the project. The mountain was previously part of the Great Sioux Reservation before being taken away from them by the U.S. government.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1927, sculpting began. Washington‚Äôs face was the first to be completed in 1934. Jefferson‚Äôs was dedicated in 1936 ‚Äì with then-president Franklin Roosevelt in attendance ‚Äì and Lincoln‚Äôs was completed a year later. In 1939, Teddy Roosevelt‚Äôs face was completed.

It was on #ThisDayInHistory in 1666 when Thomas Farriner, the king‚Äôs baker, failed to properly extinguish his oven, sparking the Great Fire of London. He would go to bed only to be awoken by his house in flames. The sparks leapt across the street and set fire to straw and fodder in the stables. Then would go on to engulf 13,000 houses and an estimated 100,000 people were left homeless. Within days, King Charles II set about rebuilding his capital.   To prevent future fires, most new houses were built of brick or stone and separated by thicker walls. Narrow alleyways were forbidden, and streets were made wider. Permanent fire departments, however, did not become a fixture in London until the mid-18th century.

Saundra Williams walked across the Miss Black America pageant stage ready to be crowned as pageant royalty on #ThisDayInHistory in 1968. Though it was the same night as the Miss America pageant, Williams‚Äô crowning wasn‚Äôt just about beauty. It was about protest. She was the first Miss Black America, and her message was clear: Black is beautiful too.  Phillip H. Savage, then director of the Tri-State NAACP, helped the groundbreaking pageant get national coverage. They decided to hold it the same night, and in the same city, as the Miss America pageant. They chose to start their pageant at midnight, in hopes that newsmen would drop by when they left Convention Hall after the conclusion of the other pageant. Would you trade your home for a pearl necklace? The building you see here, was formerly the home of Morton F. Plant...    After inheriting his father‚Äôs railway company and fortune in 1899, Morton Plant married the recently divorced socialite Mae ‚ÄúMaisie‚Äù Cadwell Manwaring, that you see in the second photo. It was said Plant paid Mae‚Äôs previous husband $8,000,000 to agree to a divorce.    Plant built his mansion in 1905 on the east side of 5th Avenue alongside a string of other wealthy family homes, like the Vanderbilt‚Äôs and Astor‚Äôs.    But why did Plant sell his house for a pearl necklace? Maisie Plant had fallen in love with a double strand of 128 pearls with a diamond clasp, said to be worth $1,000,000 made by Cartier. (The jewelry in slide 4 is similar to the necklace Maisie loved)   Cartier offered to trade the necklace, plus $100, for the Plant Mansion. So, for the love of Maisie, Plant accepted.    Soon after the trade, harvested pearls were created and the price of authentic pearls dropped, making the necklace plummet in value. And the iconic necklace has yet to resurface. üì∏: Cartier store on 5th Avenue; 1987 üì∏: Portrait of Sarah Mae "Maisie" Cadwell Plant Rovensky; 1987 üì∏: Pedestrians, cars and coaches passing in front of Vanderbilt Mansion, on Fifth Avenue; 1900 üì∏: Jewelry and a Cartier Baignoire wristwatch in a display case at a Cartier; 2021 üì∏: The exterior of the Cartier mansion on 5th Avenue; 2008

The ‚ÄúLongest Walk‚Äù, a 2,800-mile trek for Native American justice, ended in Washington, D.C. on #ThisDayInHistory in 1978. The intent was to call attention to issues affecting Native Americans, such as lack of jobs and housing, and legislation before Congress that could dramatically change their rights.   üì∏: Actor Marlon Brando addressing a rally after the completed "Longest Walk" from San Francisco to Washington DC.

The Harlem Riot of 1943 began on #ThisDayInHistory‚Ä¶   In the evening, years of racial oppression in Harlem erupted in the lobby of the Braddock Hotel. A rumor rapidly spread that a white police officer shot and killed a Black soldier, Robert Bandy, when in fact, he was treated for a superficial wound.   Crowds of Harlem residents, unaware of the truth, gathered around the neighborhood, enraged that a white patrolman had killed a black soldier.   People took to the streets, looting and vandalizing property.   Damages from the riot were estimated to be upwards of $5 million in today‚Äôs dollars.   The rioting lasted for 12 hours. Six Black residents were killed by police and approximately 200 people were injured.   To read more, visit the link in our bio.   üì∑: Burning Car In Harlem; 1943 üì∑: Suspects in a Harlem "race riot" are herded to the front of a truck by a troupe of police as they are driven to jail; 1943 üì∑: After Harlem Riot of 1943; 1943

This is Mata Hari when she was arrested in Paris in February 1917. When under interrogation by French military intelligence, she admitted that she had passed outdated information to a German intelligence officer, yet she claimed she had also been paid to act as a French spy in Belgium. She had apparently been acting as a double agent, though the Germans had seemingly written her off as an ineffective agent whose activities had produced little intelligence of value. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1917, she was tried in a military court. The next day she was found guilty and sentenced to execution. The question of her guilt continues to fascinate historians and she remains one of the most glamourous figures to come out of the shadowy world of espionage.

Legendary journalist and author Barbara Walters has passed away at the age of 93. Walters was known for her probing-yet-casual interviewing technique, making a name for herself at the Today Show, where she won her first Daytime Emmy Award for Outstanding Talk Show Host. In 1976, she became the first female co-anchor of a network evening news program when she joined the ABC Evening News. In 1997, Walters premiered The View, a morning talk-show where she served as co-executive producer and co-host.    Her brand of ‚Äúpersonality journalism,‚Äù committed to asking the questions her audience most wanted to hear without alienating her interviewees, which allowed her to conduct exclusive interviews from a range of high-profile people and open doors for women in journalism.

Days after a blizzard buried Springfield, Massachusetts, a case of cabin fever tore through the International Young Men‚Äôs Christian Association (YMCA) Training School. The unruly students roughhoused in the halls and wouldn‚Äôt quiet down. That is when James Naismith took up a teacher‚Äôs challenge to develop a game that would keep the pupils active in the winter months. The 30-year-old Canadian native drew on his knowledge of rugby, lacrosse and a childhood game known as ‚Äúduck on a rock,‚Äù which combined tag with throwing, to dream up a new sport.  Naismith cleared the athletic equipment off the gym floor and picked up a soccer ball. He asked a janitor for two square boxes, but the best the custodian could do was a pair of peach baskets, which Naismith mounted to the lower rail of the gym‚Äôs balcony, about 10 feet off the ground. And on #ThisDayInHistory in 1891, the first game of basketball was introduced.

Nelson Mandela, the first Black president of South Africa, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 2013. Known as a freedom fighters, prisoner, civil rights leader, political leader and symbol of integrity not only for South Africa, but for the world.

According to Montgomery city ordinance in 1955, African Americans were required to sit at the back of public buses and were also obligated to give up those seats to white riders if the front of the bus was filled up.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1955, Rosa Parks was in the first row of the Black section when the white driver demanded that she give up her seat to a white man. Rosa refused. Her refusal was spontaneous but was not merely brought on by her tired feet, as is the popular legend. In fact, local civil rights leaders had been planning a challenge to Montgomery‚Äôs racist bus laws for several months, and Parks had been privy to this discussion. She was arrested and fined $10, plus $4 in court fees.   To learn more about the Montgomery Bus Boycott, visit the link in our bio.   üé• Rosa Parks talking in interview; 1955

#DidYouKnow the Chunnel was suggested to Napoleon Bonaparte as early as 1802? But it was not until 1986 that Britain and France signed a treaty authorizing the construction. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1883, as noon arrived in each four new continental time zones, American and Canadian railroads synchronized their clocks to end the confusion of dealing with thousands of local times.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1906, President Theodore Roosevelt embarked on a 17-day trip to Panama and Puerto Rico. He became the first president to make an official diplomatic tour outside of the continental United States. Although presidents before Roosevelt had traveled outside of the U.S. after they left office, he was the first sitting president to head abroad. During his visit to Panama, he checked on the progress of the Panama Canal. His tenacious demands for improvements in health care and better working conditions pushed the canal project forward just when it appeared doomed to failure. This trip to the construction site helped to boost flagging morale.

German Nazis launched a campaign of terror against Jewish people, their homes and businesses in Germany and Austria on #ThisDayInHistory in 1938. Nazi mobs, SS troops and ordinary citizens torched and vandalized synagogues, destroyed, if not completely destroyed, thousands of Jewish homes, schools, business, hospitals and cemeteries. Kristallnacht marked a turning point toward more violence and repressive treatment of Jews by the Nazis. By the end of 1938, Jews were prohibited from school and most public places in Germany ‚Äì and the conditions only worsened from there.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1895, physicist Wilhelm Conrad Rontgen became the first person to observe X-rays. The discovery occurred accidentally in his lab where he was testing whether cathode rays could pass through glass. Rontgen holed up in his lab and conducted a series of experiments to better understand his discovery. Scientists were quick to realize the benefits of x-rays, but slower to comprehend the harmful effects of radiation. Wilhelm Rontgen received numerous accolades for his work, yet he remained modest and never tried to patent his discovery.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1888, Vincent Van Gogh, suffering from severe depression, cut off the lower part of his left ear. Afterward, he allegedly wrapped up the ear and gave it to a cleaner at a nearby brothel. Following that incident, Van Gogh was hospitalized and then checked himself into a mental institution for a year.

Ellis Island, the gateway to America, shut its doors on #ThisDayInHistory in 1954. Before its opening in 1892, the processing of immigrants had been handled by individual states. During its busiest year of operation, 1907, over 1 million people were processed at Ellis Island.

Winston Churchill was one of the best-known, and some say one of the greatest, statesmen of the 20th century. Though he was born into a life of privilege, he dedicated himself to public service. Churchill was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1874.

100 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, British archaeologist Howard Carter and his workmen discovered a step leading to the tomb of King Tutankhamen. At this time, archaeologists believed that all royal tombs in the Valley of the Kings had already been cleared. Excitement about the new tomb ‚Äì the most intact ever found ‚Äì quickly spread worldwide, igniting a global fascination with the boy pharaoh and the powerful civilization of ancient Egypt. It took Carter and his team a decade to catalogue and empty the tomb. If you‚Äôre interested in seeing more about what was found in his tomb, visit the link in our bio.

While London boasts the world‚Äôs oldest underground train network (1863) and Boston built the first subway in the United States (1897), the New York City subway soon became the largest American system. Ruby Bridges walked into William Frantz Elementary School on #ThisDayInHistory in 1960 after a court order mandated the desegregation of schools went into effect. But she did not attend any classes due to the chaos outside the school. No other students attended and all but one teacher stayed home in protest of desegregation. It was several days until a white father finally broke the boycott and brought his daughter to school. Even when the white students returned, they were kept separate from the school‚Äôs lone Black student. Today, Ruby Bridges is an icon of the civil rights movement.

Eliezer ‚ÄúElie‚Äù Wiesel, the human rights activist, and Nobel Peace Prize-winning author, was born in Romania on #ThisDayInHistory in 1928. The book was shortened and published as Night for English readers in 1960. The memoir would eventually become an acclaimed bestseller and is considered a seminal work on the terrors of the Holocaust.

When Frida Kahlo was 18 years old, she seemed on the verge of creating the life she‚Äôd imagined. Kahlo wanted to be a doctor since she was a child. Though she was clearly a very talented artist, art remained at the periphery of her life. But on September 17, 1925, after a trolly car collided with a bus she was on, all of that changed. As her body healed, her views of life and art radically transformed. While confined to bed, seeing very few visitors, she began painting more and more. As her career progressed, themes of pain and recovery emerged at the heart of her work. That uncompromising honesty became one of her signature artistic qualities. To read more about Frida Kahlo, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1957, a mob of furious white people assembled to prevent nine Black students from entering Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas. The Black students had trained for this moment. But nothing could prepare them for the screaming, taunting crowd that surrounded the school. The nine students did not make it to school that day.   Later that month, President Dwight Eisenhower intervened and the nine students - Minnijean Brown, Elizabeth Eckford, Ernest Green, Thelma Mothershed, Melba Patillo, Gloria Ray, Terrence Roberts, Jefferson Thomas and Carlotta Walls - were escorted by members of the 101st Airborne and finally let in.

55 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Thurgood Marshall became the first African American to be confirmed as a Supreme Court justice. He would remain on the Supreme Court for 24 years, leaving a legacy of upholding the rights of the individual as guaranteed by the U.S. Constitution.  Thurgood Marshall opened the door for a new generation of Black jurists, visit the link in our bio to learn more.

The terrorist attacks on #ThisDayInHistory in 2001 killed almost 3,000 people, shocked the world and forever seared 9/11 into memory as a date filled with tragedy, loss and heroism. Artifacts recovered from the attacks, meanwhile, became ingrained with solemn significance.  Over the years, the 9/11 Memorial Museum has worked to document the events of 9/11 with oral histories and over 11,000 artifacts collected from Ground Zero, donated from survivors and victims‚Äô loved ones. Here are some of the items in their collection.   üì∏ A postcard picture of the twin towers lies amid the rubble  üì∏ American Airlines flight attendant wings lapel pin belonged to Karyn Ramsey who was working aboard Flight 11 üì∏ Police badge that belonged to John William Perry. He was another off-duty officer who responded to the attacks.  üì∏  This pair of women‚Äôs heels belonged Linda Raisch-Lopez, a survivor of the attacks on the World Trade Center.  üì∏ This pager, recovered from Ground Zero, belonged to Andrea Lyn Haberman. Haberman, who lived in Chicago, was in New York City on September 11, 2001 for a meeting. üì∏  A year after the attacks, the wallet and wedding ring of Robert Joseph Gschaar were recovered. He and his wife, Myrta, carried around $2 bills during their 11-year marriage to remind each other that they were two of a kind. üì∏ David Halderman's helmet was found crushed on September 12, 2001 üì∏ This baseball cap belonged to James Francis Lynch. At the time of the attacks, James was off duty and recovering from surgery, but felt the need to respond. üì∏ This gold link bracelet belonged to Yvette Nicole Moreno. After the North Tower was hit, she called her mother to let her know she was heading home. However, on her way out of the office she was struck by debris from the South Tower, dying at the young age of 24.  To read more of their stories and other items in the collection, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1955, while visiting family in Money, Mississippi, 14-year-old Emmett Till was brutally beaten and lynched, just days after he allegedly whistled at a white woman in a local store. By the time his remains were found three days later, his body was so disfigured he was only identified by a family ring he was wearing. The brutality of the murder of Emmett Till ‚Äì and the subsequent acquittals of his killers ‚Äì galvanized the civil rights movements.   In 2017, Carolyn Bryant, the woman who accused Emmett Till, recanted her testimony, admitting that Till had never touched, threatened or harassed her.

50 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, an armed band of Palestinian terrorists attacked the Israeli compound at the Olympic Village in Munich, Germany, killing two Israeli athletes and taking another nine hostage. In the ensuring standoff, all nine remaining Israeli athletes were murdered. After a memorial service was held for the athletes at the main Olympic stadium, International Olympic Committee President ordered that the games continue, to show that the terrorists hadn‚Äôt won. To learn more about when world events disrupted the Olympics, visit the link in our bio.

On June 10, 1752, Benjamin Franklin took a kite out during a storm to see if a key attached to the string would draw an electrical charge. Or so the story goes. In fact, some historians have questioned whether it took place at all.   Even if Franklin‚Äôs kite and key experiment did happen, it didn‚Äôt play out the way many people think. Contrary to popular myths, Franklin didn‚Äôt conduct the experiment to prove the existence of electricity. In addition, it‚Äôs very unlikely that lightning struck a key while he was flying a kite ‚Äì because if it had, Franklin probably would have died.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.
