Founded at Jamestown in 1607, the Virginia Colony was home to about 700 people by 1619. The first enslaved Africans to arrive in Jamestown, Virginia on #ThisDayInHistory in 1619 disembarked at Point Comfort, which is now known as Fort Monroe. Most of their names, as well as the exact number who remained at Point Comfort, have been lost to history, but much is known about their journey. Their arrival marked a new chapter in the history of the transatlantic slave trade.

After more than four years of Nazi occupation, Paris was liberated on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944. German resistance was light, and General Dietrich von Choltitz, commander of the German garrison, defied an order by Hitler to blow up Paris‚Äô landmarks and burn the city to the ground before its liberation. Choltitz signed a formal surrender that afternoon and on August 26, Charles de Gaulle led a joyous liberation march down the Champs d‚ÄôElysees.   üé• General Charles de Gaulle marching at front of parade at Liberation of Paris; 1944

On #ThisDayInHistory in 79 A.D, after centuries of dormancy, Mount Vesuvius erupted, devastating the prosperous Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum, and killing thousands. The cities, buried under a thick layer of volcanic material and mud, were never rebuilt, and largely forgotten in the course of history. In the 18th century, Pompeii and Herculaneum were rediscovered and excavated, providing an unprecedented archaeological record of the everyday life of an ancient civilization, startlingly preserved in sudden death.  üì∏ Casting of Pompeii Victim; 1973

Mikhail Gorbachev, the first and only president of the Soviet Union, died at the age of 91. During his presidency, Gorbachev promoted more peaceful international relations. He was also instrumental in ending the Cold War. He is credited for his crucial role in the fall of the Berlin Wall and subsequent reunification of Germany. For his excellent leadership and his contributions to the overall betterment of world development, Gorbachev was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1990.

The Titanic departed Southampton, England on April 10, 1912.   After four days of uneventful sailing, on April 14, Titanic received sporadic reports of ice from other ships, but she was sailing on calm seas under a moonless, clear sky. At about 11:30 pm, a lookout saw an iceberg coming out of a slight haze dead ahead, then rang the warning bell and telephoned the bridge. The engines were quickly reversed, and the ship was turned sharply ‚Äì instead of making direct impact, Titanic seemed to graze along the size of the berg. Sensing no collision, the lookouts were relieved. They had no idea that the iceberg had a jagged underwater spur, which slashed the hull below the ship‚Äôs waterline.   A little more than an hour after contact with the iceberg, a largely disorganized and haphazard evacuation began. And finally, at 2:20 AM on April 15, 1912, the Titanic dove beneath the ocean‚Äôs surface.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1985, a joint U.S.-French expedition located the wreck of the RMS Titanic.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1961, just two days after sealing off free passage between East and West Berlin with barbed wire, East German authorities began building a wall ‚Äì the Berlin Wall ‚Äì to permanently close off access to the West. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1911, American historian Hiram Bingham saw the ruins of Machu Picchu for the first time. Tucked away in the mountainous countryside northwest of Cuzco, Machu Picchu is believed to have been a summer retreat for Inca leaders, whose empire was virtually wiped out by Spanish invaders in the 16th century. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, The United States became the first and only nation to use atomic weaponry during wartime when it dropped an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima. A blast equivalent to the power of 15,000 tons of TNT reduced four square miles of the city to ruins and immediately killed 80,000 people. Three days later, another bomb was dropped on the city of Nagasaki, killing tens of thousands more. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1940, 300 German bombers raided London in the first of 57 consecutive nights of bombing. By the end of the day, German planes had dropped 337 tons of bombs on London. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1957, John Lennon was scheduled to perform at the annual Woolton Parish Church Garden Fete, a parade and outdoor fair at which John and his Quarrymen Skiffle Group had been invited to play. With the famine crisis continuing in Ethiopia and the neighboring Sudan, Bob Geldof proposed Live Aid, an ambitious global concert aimed at raising funds and increasing awareness of the plight of many Africans. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, U.S. President Harry Truman, Soviet leader Joseph Stalin and British Prime Minister Winston Churchill, met in the Berlin suburb of Potsdam to discuss the issues relating to postwar Europe and plans to deal with the ongoing conflict with Japan. The conference soon bogged down to the issue of postwar Germany.   The leaders of the United States, Great Britain, and the Soviet Union ‚Äì the Big Three powers who had defeated Nazi Germany ‚Äì met at the Potsdam Conference on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. The Big Three worked out many of the details of the postwar order in the Potsdam Agreement, signed on August 1. This would be the final time that leaders, who had maintained a tense alliance despite their difference during the war, would meet to discuss postwar cooperation.

#Juneteenth marks the day when federal troops arrived in Galveston, Texas in 1865 to take control of the state and ensure that all enslaved people be freed. On this day, 250,000 enslaved people were free, and despite the message to stay and work for their owners, many left the state immediately and headed north or to nearby states in search of family members. For many Black Americans, June 19th is considered an Independence Day. To learn more about #Juneteenth, visit the link in our bio.

On June 24, 1948, outraged by the currency reform introduced by the United States and Britain into their occupied zones of Germany, the Soviets blocked all roads, rail, and water routes to the Allied-controlled sectors of Berlin. The blockade cut off the city‚Äôs electricity, food, and coal supply, as well as its access to the outside world. President Harry Truman authorized a massive airlift operation also known as the Berlin Airlift. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1948, the first planes took off from England and western Germany loaded with food, clothing, water, medicine, and fuel. To learn more about the #BerlinAirlift, visit the link in our bio.

U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signed into law the historic Civil Rights Act on #ThisDayInHistory in 1964. The most sweeping civil rights legislation passed by Congress since the post-Civil War Reconstruction era, the Civil Rights Act prohibited racial discrimination in employment and education and outlawed racial segregation in public places such as schools, buses, parks and swimming pools. In addition, the bill laid important groundwork for a number of other pieces of legislation.

Jackie Robinson‚Äôs legacy went far beyond baseball. He used his voice to support the fight for civil rights, advocating for equality across the country. The HISTORY Channel is proud to support the @jrfoundation. #AfterJackie premieres on June 18 at 8/7c.

Medgar Evers, a Black civil rights activist, joined the NAACP in 1952 as a field worker. He traveled through his home state encouraging poor Black Americans to register to vote and recruit them into the civil rights movement. He was instrumental in getting witnesses and evidence for the Emmett Till murder case, which brought national attention to the plight of Black Americans in the South. On #ThisDayInHistory, Evers was killed by a white supremacist. To learn more about Medgar Evers, visit the link in our bio.

Beginning on #ThisDayInHistory in 1921, thousands of white citizens in Tulsa, Oklahoma descended on the city‚Äôs predominately Black Greenwood District, burning homes and businesses to the ground and killing hundreds of people. Long mischaracterized as a race riot, rather than a mass murder, the Tulsa Race Massacre stands as one of the worst incidents of racial violence in the nation‚Äôs history. Queen Elizabeth II was formally crowned monarch of the United Kingdom on #ThisDayInHistory in 1953. The ceremony at Westminster was one of pomp and pageantry, and the characteristically poised Elizabeth delivered in a solemn and clear voice the coronation oath that bound her to the service of the people of Great Britain and the British Commonwealth. In nearly seven decades of rule, Queen Elizabeth II‚Äôs popularity has hardly subsided. To learn more about her reign, visit the link in our bio.

Shortly after midnight on #ThisDayInHistory in 1968, Senator Robert Kennedy was shot after winning the California presidential primary. Kennedy was perceived by many to be the only person in American politics capable of uniting the people. He was beloved by the minority community for his integrity and devotion to the civil rights cause.  Visit the link in our bio to read more.

Codenamed Operation Overlord, the battle began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944, also known as D-Day, when some 156,000 American, British, and Canadian forces landed on five beaches along a 50-mile stretch of the heavily fortified coast of France‚Äôs Normandy region. The invasion was one of the largest amphibious military assaults in history. By late August 1944, all of northern France had been liberated, and by the following spring the Allies had defeated the Germans. Visit the link in our bio to read more facts on the epic 1944 invasion.
Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated during his presidential campaign in 1968. #Kennedys #PoliticalHistory #UnseenHistory

Theodore Roosevelt‚Äôs unexpected presidency reshaped U.S. foreign policy, business practices, landscapes, and wildlife. This #MemorialDay we honor the many men and women who died while serving in the U.S. military. Originally known as Decoration Day, it originated in the years following the Civil War and became an official federal holiday in its current form in 1971.

Theodore Roosevelt‚Äôs conservation efforts were celebrated for protecting over 200 million acres of land and wildlife from development. 50 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory several burglars were arrested in the office of the Democratic National Committee, located in the Watergate complex of buildings in Washington, D.C. This was no ordinary robbery: the prowlers were connected to President Richard Nixon‚Äôs reelection campaign, and they had been caught wiretapping phones and stealing documents. President Nixon took aggressive steps to cover up the crimes. Reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein revealed his role in the conspiracy, leading to Nixon‚Äôs eventual resignation in  August 1974. The Watergate scandal changed American politics forever.    Tonight, The HISTORY Channel‚Äôs original documentary, Watergate, tells the full story of the conspiracy led by Nixon and his White House staff, and how they were brought to justice. Tune in TONIGHT at 6pm ET/PT. #Watergate

Notorious criminals Bonnie Parker and Clyde Barrow were shot to death by Texas and Louisiana police officers while driving a stolen car on #ThisDayInHistory in 1934. Among the public, Parker and Barrow‚Äôs reputation as dangerous outlaws were mixed with a romantic view of the couple as ‚ÄúRobin Hood‚Äù- like folk heroes.

On #ThisDayInHistory, two historic individuals took flight.   In 1927, American pilot Charles A. Lindbergh landed in Paris, successfully completing the first solo, nonstop transatlantic flight and the first ever nonstop flight between New York and Paris.   Five years later in 1932, Amelia Earhart became the first pilot to repeat the feat, landing her plane in Ireland after flying cross the North Atlantic.

Theodore Roosevelt yearned for adventure, but found more than he may have bargained for when he embarked on a treacherous expedition to the Amazon in 1913. He described the trip as ‚Äúhis last chance to be a boy,‚Äù following his 1912 election loss. Discover his incredible journey, and join HISTORY for the first night of  #TheodoreRoosevelt, starting Monday at 8/7c.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1953, Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing Norgay, a Sherpa from Nepal, became the first explorers to reach the summit of Mount Everest. The two, part of a British expedition, made their final assault on the summit after spending a fitful night at 27,900 feet. News of their achievements broke around the world on June 2, the day of Queen Elizabeth II‚Äôs coronation. To learn more about Mount Everest, visit the link in our bio.

For all the adversity they suffered, the Union Pacific and Central Pacific workers were able to finish the transcontinental railroad on #ThisDayInHistory in 1869, ahead of schedule and under budget. Journeys that had taken months by wagon train or weeks by boat now only took days. Their work had immediate impact: the years following construction of the railway were years of rapid growth and expansion for the United States, due in large part to the speed and ease of travel that the railroad provided.

Even before the U.S. government concluded purchase negotiations with France, President Thomas Jefferson commissioned his private secretary Meriwether Lewis and army captain, William Clark, to lead an expedition into what is now the U.S. Northwest. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1804, the ‚ÄúCorps of Discovery‚Äù left Camp Dubois in present-day Illinois. Visit the link in our bio to take a look at the timeline of their expedition.

Theodore Roosevelt hosted a menagerie both in and out of the White House. Discover a few of the unique pets Roosevelt and his family shared before #TheodoreRoosevelt, a documentary diving into the president's life this Memorial Day at 8/7c on HISTORY.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1954, the U.S. Supreme Court made a unanimous decision in the Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka. The decision ruled racial segregation in public education facilities unconstitutional. This was one of the cornerstones of the civil rights movement and helped establish the precedent that ‚Äúseparate-but-equal‚Äù educations and other services were not, in fact, equal.

#DidYouKnow the first annual Cannes Film Festival was in 1946? The festival had intended to make its debut in September 1939 but the outbreak of World War II forced the cancellation of the inaugural Cannes.

Shortly after the German occupation of Poland began, the Nazis forced the city‚Äôs Jewish citizens into a ‚Äúghetto‚Äù surrounded by barbed wire and armed SS guards. The Warsaw Ghetto soon held almost 450,000 Jews in deplorable conditions and beginning in July 1942, 6,000 Jews a day were transferred to the Treblinka extermination camp. Although remaining Jews were assured that their relatives and friends were being sent to work camps, word soon reached the ghetto that deportation meant extermination. An underground resistance group was established in the ghetto ‚Äì the Jewish Combat Organization ‚Äì and limited arms were acquired at great cost.   In January 1943 when the Nazis entered to the ghetto to prepare a group for transfer, the resistance group ambushed them. But on #ThisDayInHistory in 1943, the Nazis gained control of the ghetto and mass deportation of the last Warsaw Jews to Treblinka resumed.   How did the uprising inspire a rebellion in Treblinka? Visit the link in our bio to learn more.

Nine-year-old Martha Lum and her older sister Berda were students at the Rosedale consolidated high school in 1924 when the superintendent told Martha that they were no longer allowed to be there.   The Lum family sued. By the time the case moved on the highest court in the country ‚Äì the Lums lost in a unanimous decision against them, in essence giving the school permission to exclude the Asian American students.   Though their case seemed groundbreaking at the time ‚Äì and gave some hope that it could open a door to integrated schooling, it wasn‚Äôt even the first case of its kind in the country.   To read more about how the Lums fought to desegregate southern schools, visit the link in our bio.

A group of thirteen young individuals departed Washington, D.C.‚Äôs Greyhound Bus terminal, bound for the South, on #ThisDayInHistory in 1961. Their journey was peaceful at first, but the riders would be met with shocking violence on their way to New Orleans, eventually being forced to evacuate from Birmingham, Alabama but earning a place in history as the first Freedom Riders.

James Brown worked his way to the top of the funk and R&B music industry earning the moniker, ‚ÄúThe Godfather of Soul.‚Äù Born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1933, James Brown is unquestionably one of the most influential musical pioneers of the last half-century. He was also known for his turbulent personal life, as well as his social activism, both in his songwriting and advocating the benefits of education to schoolchildren.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1929, Audrey Kathleen Ruston ‚Äì who will be better known as Audrey Hepburn ‚Äì was born. It is broadly known that she was the designer Givenchy‚Äôs muse, that she retired from acting to do relief work for UNICEF and that women still show up at Tiffany‚Äôs with a bag of pastries thanks to her iconic performance in Breakfast at Tiffany‚Äôs. But while seemingly every moment of her adult life was documented, there is still a lot that most people don‚Äôt know about the glamorous movie star. Prince, the polymathic musician who released more than 30 albums and won seven Grammy Awards over a 40-year career, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 2016. Throughout his career, Prince defied and transcended genre. His music fused elements of funk, R&B, rock, and pop into what later became known as Minneapolis Sound. To learn more about Prince, visit the link in our bio.

The New York World‚Äôs Fair opened in New York City on #ThisDayInHistory in 1939. Spanning 1,200 acres at Flushing Meadow Park in Queens, the fairground was marked by two iconic Trylon and Perisphere structures and exhibited new technology such as FM radio, robotics, fluorescent lighting and a crude fax machine. Sixty nations participated in the fair, which enjoyed large crowds before the outbreak of World War II interrupted many of its scheduled events.

The modern legend of the Loch Ness Monster was born when a sighting made local news on #ThisDayInHistory in 1933. The story of the ‚Äúmonster‚Äù became a media phenomenon, with London newspapers sending correspondents to Scotland and a circus offering a 20,000-pound reward for capture of the beast. If the Loch Ness Monster did exist, it has DNA. Visit the link in our bio to learn more.

Surfing was a communal activity in Hawaii and other Polynesian Islands for men, women, and children of all social classes dating back at least to the 17th century. But the arrival of American missionaries in the 19th century disrupted the mixed-gender sport as they disapproved of baring skin and gambling during surf contests. Visit the link in our bio to learn more about how a Hawaiian princess helped revive the ancient sport.

Norway‚Äôs most famous painting, ‚ÄúThe Scream,‚Äù by Edvard Munch, was recovered on #ThisDayInHistory in 1994, almost three months after it was stolen. The iconic 1893 painting of a waiflike figure on a bridge was stolen only 50 seconds during a break-in on February 12, the opening day of the 1994 Winter Olympics. Two thieves broke through a window of the National Gallery, cut a wire holding the painting to the wall and left a note reading, ‚ÄúThanks for the poor security.‚Äù   Read more about history‚Äôs biggest art heists by visiting the link in our bio.

A bar crawl in New York‚Äôs West Village on #ThisDayInHistory in 1966, leads to an important early moment in the gay liberation movement. In what will be dubbed the ‚ÄúSip-In‚Äù Dick Leitsch, Craig Rodwell and John Timmons publicly identify themselves as gay and demand to be served anyway, challenging the widespread practice of banning gay customers from bars. To learn more about the ‚ÄúSip-In‚Äù, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1977, a crowd gathered outside 254 West 54th Street in New York City, hoping for a chance to enter what would soon become the global epicenter of the disco craze and the most famous nightclub in the world: Studio 54, which opened its doors for the very first time. To learn more about Studio 54, visit the link in our bio.

Conservationist, Rough-Rider, Author, Nobel Prize Winner, President. The History Channel presents a 2-part documentary event spanning the life of the 26th President of the United States. ‚ÄòTheodore Roosevelt‚Äô unveils the legacy of a man who grew from a fragile child into a world leader who epitomized strength. At 2:20 am on #ThisDayInHistory in 1912, The British ocean liner, Titanic, sunk into the North Atlantic Ocean about 400 miles south of Newfoundland, Canada. Because of the shortage of lifeboats and lack of satisfactory emergency procedures, more than 1,500 people went down in the sinking ship or froze in the icy waters. More than half of the 700 or so survivors were women and children. To read more about the Titanic, visit the link in our bio.

In his decade as a professional actor, 26-year-old John Wilkes Booth played some of the most prestigious theaters in the United States. But the assassin of Abraham Lincoln delivered his final performance in a tobacco-curing barn in Virginia, where he was killed by Union soldiers. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Benjamin Franklin, one of the leading figures of early American history, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1790. Born into a family of modest means, he had little formal education. He went on to start a successful printing business in Philadelphia and was deeply active in the city. During the American Revolution, he served in the Second Continental Congress and helped draft the Declaration of Independence. To read more about Benjamin Franklin, visit the link in our bio.

During the Hundred Years‚Äô War, 17-year-old Joan of Arc led the French force in relieving the city of Orleans, besieged by the English since October. On May 8, the siege was broken, and the English retreated. During the next five weeks, Joan led French forces into several stunning victories. To learn more about Joan of Arc, visit the link in our bio.

Just after 6pm on #ThisDayInHistory in 1968, Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. was fatally shot while standing on the balcony outside his second-story room at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee. The civil rights leader was in Memphis to support a sanitation workers‚Äô strike and was on his way to dinner when a bullet struck him. He was pronounced dead after his arrival at a Memphis hospital.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1992, a jury in New York found mobster John Gotti, nicknamed the Teflon Don for his ability to elude conviction, guilty on 13 counts, including murder and racketeering.

Two days after the U.S. Senate voted to declare war against Germany, the U.S. House of Representatives endorsed the declaration and America formally entered World War I on #ThisDayInHistory in 1917.   When the war erupted in 1914, President Woodrow Wilson pledged neutrality for the United States, a position many Americans favored. Britain, however, was one of America‚Äôs closest trading partners, and tension soon arose between the United States and Germany over the latter‚Äôs attempted quarantine of the British Isles.   Should the U.S. have entered World War I? Visit the link in our bio to explore this historical debate.

Madeleine Albright was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1937 in Prague. In her post as U.S. Ambassador to the United Nation, she earned a reputation as a straight-talking defender of American interests and an advocate for an increased role for the U.S. in U.N. operations. She would then become America‚Äôs first female secretary of state where she pursued an active foreign policy. To learn more about Madeleine Albright, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, the American Third Army liberated the Buchenwald concentration camp, a camp later judged by some as second only to Auschwitz in the horrors it imposed on its prisoners.   Later this month on April 29, 1945, The U.S. Seventh Army‚Äôs 45th Infantry Division liberated Dachau, the first concentration camp established by Germany‚Äôs Nazi regime.   To read more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Sidney Poitier became the first Black American to win the Academy Award for Best Actor on #ThisDayInHistory in 1964. By constantly refusing to play the stereotypical roles that were offered to him as a Black actor, Poitier blazed a trail for himself and the performers who followed him.

75 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Jackie Robinson, age 28, became the first Black American player in Major League Baseball. On this day, he broke the color barrier in a sport that had been segregated for more than 50 years.   In 1949, the right-hander was named the National League‚Äôs Most Valuable Player and the league batting champ. He played on the National League All-Star team from 1949 through 1954 and led the Dodgers to six National League pennants and one World Series victory, in 1955. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1962, his first year of eligibility.   Despite his talent and success as a player, Robinson faced tremendous racial discrimination throughout his career, from baseball fans and some fellow players. In 1997, his groundbreaking career was honored and his uniform number, 42, was retired from Major League Baseball.   To read more about Jackie Robinson, visit the link in our bio.

President Abraham Lincoln was shot at Ford‚Äôs Theatre in Washington, D.C. on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865. Witnesses reported the assassin, actor John Wilkes Booth, shouted, ‚ÄúSic semper tyrannis! (Ever thus to tyrants!) The South is avenged,‚Äù as he jumped onto the stage before fleeing on horseback. Lincoln died the next morning.

On #ThisDayInHistory, more than one historic moment in Major League Baseball occurred.  In 1974, Hank Aaron hit his 715th career home run, breaking Babe Ruth‚Äôs legendary record of 714 homers.  In 1975, Indians‚Äô Frank Robinson became the first Black American to manage a Major League Baseball team,  In 1989, California Angels rookie pitcher Jim Abbott, who was born without a right hand, made his Major League Baseball debut   Who invented baseball? And what is baseball's origin? Visit the link in our bio to find out.

The legendary rock band, The Beatles, spent the better part of three years breaking up in the late 1960s, and even longer than that hashing out who did what and why. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1970, an ambiguous Paul McCartney ‚Äúself-interview‚Äù was seized by the international media as an official announcement of a Beatles break up. Nothing Paul said constituted a definitive statement, but these statements drove a further wedge between himself and the bandmates. By the year‚Äôs end, Paul would file suit to dissolve the Beatles‚Äô business partnership. To read more about Beatlemania, visit the link in our bio.
Today is #AprilFoolsDay. From a Swiss ‚Äúspaghetti harvest‚Äù to a rhino on a city council, some pranks went above and beyond. Visit the link in our bio to learn about 9 outrageous pranks in history.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1973, two months after the signing of the Vietnam peace agreement, the last U.S. combat troops left South Vietnam as Hanoi freed the remaining American prisoners of war held in North Vietnam. America‚Äôs direct eight-year intervention in the Vietnam War was at an end.
President Abraham Lincoln met with Union generals Ulysses S. Grant and William T. Sherman to plot the last stages of the Civil War on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865.

Mahalia Jackson began singing as a child and went on to become one of the most revered gospel figures in the United States. She is remembered and loved for her impassioned delivery, her deep commitment to spirituality and her lasting inspiration to listeners. Did you know Mahalia prompted Martin Luther King, Jr. to improvise his ‚ÄúI Have A Dream Speech?‚Äù To learn more about #HerStory, visit the link in our bio.

Asian American women played a critical part in America‚Äôs war effort during World War II. They served in important roles ranging from pilots and translators to factory workers and guerrilla fighters. Yet they worked on behalf of a country that was far from welcoming. Visit the link in our bio to read more about the Asian American women who fought to make their mark in World War II.

In an effort to raise funds to pay off debts and defend the vast new American territories, the British government passes the Stamp Act on #ThisDayInHistory in 1765. The colonists‚Äô grumbling finally became an articulated response to what they saw as the mother country‚Äôs attempt to undermine their economic strength and independence. They raised the issue of taxation without representation and formed societies throughout the colonies to rally against the British government.

Henry Ossian Flipper, born into slavery in 1856, became the first Black American cadet to graduate from the United States Military Academy at West Point on #ThisDayInHistory in 1877.    After graduation, Flipper was appointed to serve as second lieutenant in the all-African American 10thCavalry and stationed at Fort Sill in Oklahoma. The 9th and 10th Cavalry were regiments of Black enlisted men who became known as the Buffalo Soldiers.    To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

The Eiffel Tower was dedicated in Paris in a ceremony on #ThisDayInHistory in 1889. The tower was greeted with skepticism from critics who argued that it would be structurally unsound, and indignation from others who thought it would be an eyesore in the heart of Paris.

Olympian Florence Griffith Joyner, known widely as ‚ÄúFlo Jo,‚Äù began running at the age of 7 and her gift for speed became apparent. She made her Olympic debut in 1984 where she won a silver medal for the 200-meter run and became known for her world-record speed, form-fitting bodysuits and six-inch fingernails. She returned to the 1988 Olympics where she won three gold medals and a silver. In 1995, she was honored with an induction into the Track and Field Hall of Fame. To learn more about #HerStory, visit the link in our bio.

Madeleine Albright, the first female U.S. Secretary of State, has died at the age of 84. As U.S. Ambassador to the U.N. and later as Secretary of State, she played key roles in U.S. foreign policy and advocated for human rights, diplomacy and democracy globally.   She received numerous honors for her contributions to world affairs, and in 2012 was awarded with the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1965, in the name of Black American voting rights, 3,200 civil rights demonstrators in Alabama, led by Martin Luther King, Jr. began a historic march from Selma to Montgomery. Federalized Alabama National Guardsmen and FBI agents were on hand to provide safe passage for the march, which had previously been turned back by Alabama state police at Selma‚Äôs Edmund Pettus Bridge.

Ernest Shackleton led a crew of 28 men into Antarctica on an incredible polar expedition. His ship, the HMS Endurance, would become stuck for months in the icy sea, eventually plunging to the bottom of the frigid waters. Shockingly, the entire crew survived despite brutal conditions, but many believed the ship would never be found.  107 years after the magnificent ship was crushed by ice near the Antarctic Peninsula, a team of modern-day explorers have announced she has been found. The gold name plate of the 144-foot wooden ship remains intact, a relic from another century frozen in time.   Frank Hurley, the expedition‚Äôs photographer, was able to capture nearly 100 photos of the ship prior to its wreck. Today‚Äôs images are reminiscent of his work, showing the wreck miraculously preserved and intact despite years in frozen conditions. Go back in time with us, and discover the incredible survival story behind this expedition at the link in our bio.

The eighth of May spelled the day when German troops throughout Europe were ordered to lay down their arms. Both Great Britain and the United States celebrated Victory in Europe on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Cities around both nations, as well as formerly occupied cities in Western Europe, put out flags and banners, rejoicing in the defeat of the Nazi war machine during World War II.

Marsha P. Johnson, a Black American transgender woman, was an LGBTQ+ rights activist and an outspoken advocate for trans people of color. She spearheaded the Stonewall uprising in 1969 and along with Sylvia Rivera, she established a group committed to helping homeless transgender youth in New York City. To learn more about #HerStory, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1911, there were about 500 workers at the Triangle Shirtwaist Company factory when a fire broke out in a rag bin on the eighth floor. The fire was out within half an hour, but not before 146 workers died. The tragedy led to the development of a series of laws and regulations that better protected the safety of factory workers. To learn more about the Triangle Shirtwaist fire, visit the link in our bio.

Albert Einstein, born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1879, developed the first of his groundbreaking theories while working as a clerk in the Swiss patent office. After making his name with four scientific articles published in 1905, he went on to win worldwide fame for his general theory of relativity and a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the phenomenon known as the photoelectric effect. To learn more about Albert Einstein, visit the link in our bio.

May is Jewish American Heritage Month (JAHM), and we are proud to be official partners of this national celebration!  Established by the presidential proclamation in 2006 and renewed every year since, JAHM provides an opportunity for all Americans to celebrate and draw inspiration from the contributions that Jewish Americans have made to the fabric of our nation‚Äôs history and culture.   120+ organizations across the country have joined with the @weitzmanmuseum to ensure JAHM reaches every corner of the US. Visit JewishAmericanHeritage.org and join the celebration by using the hashtags #OurSharedHeritage and #JewishAmericanHeritageMonth!

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1959, a doll named ‚ÄúBarbie‚Äù launched into the American toy market, sporting a black-and-white striped bathing suit. The leggy, 11-inch plastic figure ‚Äì full name: Barbara Millicent Roberts ‚Äì was the first mass-produced toy doll in the U.S. with adult features. She would go on to become one of the most iconic playthings in history. For decades to come, Barbie continued to evolve with the changing times.   To see Barbie through the ages, visit the link in our bio.

Before the American Civil War, the majority of hospital nurses ‚Äì or ‚Äústewards‚Äù ‚Äì were men. But the war created a medical crisis that demanded more volunteers, and a lot of the people who took up the call were women. After the war, women continued to work in medicine; and by 1900 they represented 91% of U.S. nurses. To learn more about how the U.S. Civil War inspired women to enter nursing, visit the link in our bio.

American actress Grace Kelly married Prince Rainier of Monaco on #ThisDayInHistory in 1956. The two-day event included a small legal ceremony at the palace followed by a 600-guest ceremony at Monaco‚Äôs Cathedral of St. Nicholas. As soon as she officially became a royal, Kelly became fully dedicated and gave up her Hollywood career. Even though she only made 11 films, she cemented her reputation as a leading actress of Hollywood‚Äôs Golden era. To learn more about their love story, visit the link in our bio.

Best known for her role in the discovery of the structure of DNA and for her pioneering use of X-ray diffraction, Rosalind Franklin displayed exceptional intelligence from early childhood, knowing from the age of 15 that she wanted to be a scientist. She earned her Ph.D. in physical chemistry from Cambridge University. She learned crystallography and X-ray diffraction, techniques that she applied to DNA fibers. One of her photographs provided key insights into DNA structure. But other scientists used it as evidence to support their DNA model and, without crediting her discovery, took credit for her discovery. Read more of #HerStory by visiting the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1876, the first discernible speech was transmitted over a telephone system when inventor Alexander Graham Bell summoned his assistant, ‚ÄúMr. Watson, come here; I want you.‚Äù Bell had received a comprehensive telephone patent just three days before.

More than 130 winters have come and gone since the so-called ‚ÄúGreat White Hurricane,‚Äù but this whopper of a storm still lives in infamy. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1888, a blizzard dumped as much as 55 inches of snow immobilizing New York, Boston, and other major cities, blocking roads, and wiping out telephone, telegraph and rail service for several days. In the decade to follow, partly in response to the 1888 storm and the massive gridlock it wrought, New York and Boston broke ground on the country‚Äôs first underground subway systems.
Happy #StPatricksDay. While St. Patrick‚Äôs Day is now associated with wearing green, parades, and beer, the holiday is grounded in history that dates back more than 1,500 years.

An actress during MGM‚Äôs ‚ÄúGolden Age,‚Äù Hedy Lamarr starred in films such as ‚ÄòTortilla Flat,‚Äô ‚ÄòLady of the Tropics,‚Äô and ‚ÄòBoom Town.‚Äô But in the height of her career in 1942, Lamarr earned recognition in a field quite different from entertainment. She was a scientist who co-invented an early technique for spread spectrum communications ‚Äì the key to many wireless communications of our present day.   To learn more about Hedy Lamarr, visit the link in our bio.

While Kurt Cobain dealt with personal struggles, professionally he was at the top of his game. In 1993, Nirvana released In Utero, which soared to #1 on the music charters. But after Cobain fell into a coma in 1994, his psychological state worsened. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1994, Kurt Cobain died.

Sybil Ludington is known as the female Paul Revere.   According to family traditions first documented over a century later, on the night of April 26, 1777, 16-year-old Sybil rode nearly 40 miles to warn some 400 militiamen that the British troops were coming. Much like Paul Revere, Ludington‚Äôs message helped Patriot leaders prepare for battle‚Ä¶ but Ludington was less than half Revere‚Äôs age and rode more than twice as far to carry her warning. #WomensHistoryMonth  Learn more about Sybil Ludington by visiting the link in our bio.

The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, color, religion, sex or national origin. When it was signed into law on July 2, 1964, it was a major victory for the civil rights movement in its battle against unjust Jim Crow laws that marginalized Black Americans. It took years of activism, courage, and the leadership of Civil Rights icons from Martin Luther King, Jr. to the Little Rock Nine to bring the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to fruition. Here are some of the key steps that ultimately led to the Act‚Äôs adoption.   The 1954 Supreme Court decision in Brown v. Board of Education declared that segregating children in public schools was unconstitutional, setting a critical precedent that ‚Äúseparate but equal‚Äù facilities were not equal in the eyes of the law.   The Little Rock Nine was a group of Black students sent to integrate the all-white Central High School in Little Rock, Arkansas in September 1957. Their enrollment was a test to the Brown v. Board of Education.   In 1961, Freedom Riders, a group of Black and white protestors organized by the Congress on Racial Equality, attempted to use white-only restrooms, lunch counters and waiting rooms, testing the 1960 Supreme Court decision in Boynton v. Virginia that ruled segregation of interstate transportation facilities unconstitutional.   The Freedom Summer of 1964 was a voter registration drive for Black voters across Mississippi who faced harassment and intimidation at the polls.   To read more about the key steps that led to the Act‚Äôs adoption, visit the link in our bio.

Anthony, Sojourner Truth to Rosa Parks, the timeline of women‚Äôs history milestones is full of important stories that need to be told.

It was an unlikely partnership. But between New York‚Äôs LGBTQ community in the 1960s being forced to live on the outskirts of society and the Mafia‚Äôs disregard for the law, the two made a profitable, if uneasy, match.   A member of the Genovese family, Tony Lauria, aka ‚ÄúFat Tony,‚Äù purchased the Stonewall Inn in 1966 and transformed it from a bar and restaurant that attracted straight clientele into a gay bar and night club. To operate its gay bars, the Mafia greased the palms of the NYPD. ‚ÄúFat Tony,‚Äù for one, paid New York‚Äôs 6th Precinct approximately $1,200 a month, in exchange for the police agreeing to turn a blind eye.   To read more about how the Mob helped establish NYC‚Äôs Gay bar scene, visit the link in our bio.

Today is #PresidentsDay. Did you know? Presidents' Day never falls on the actual birthday of any American president. George Washington, William Henry Harrison, Abraham Lincoln, and Ronald Reagan were born in February, but their birthdays all come either too early or late.

Anne Sullivan began teaching six-year-old Helen Keller on #ThisDayInHistory in 1887. Under Sullivan‚Äôs guidance, Keller flourished, eventually graduating from college, and becoming an international lecturer and activist. Sullivan, later dubbed ‚Äúthe miracle worker,‚Äù remained Keller‚Äôs interpreter and constant companion.

In Birmingham, Alabama, on #ThisDayInHistory in 1963, more than 1,000 Black school children marched through the city in a demonstration against segregation in what became known as the ‚ÄúChildren‚Äôs Crusade‚Äù and ‚ÄúChildren‚Äôs March.‚Äù  Although the police were mostly restrained the first day, that did not continue. Law enforcement brought out water hoses and police dogs.   To learn more about the Children‚Äôs Crusade, visit the link in our bio.

One of the greatest of the Italian Renaissance artists, Michelangelo Buonarroti, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1475. Demonstrating obvious talent as an apprentice at 13, he was taken under the wing of Lorenzo de‚Äô Medici, the ruler of the Florence republic and a great patron of the arts. To learn more about Michelangelo, visit the link in our bio.

Anna May Wong, an Asian American actress, found success in both Hollywood and Europe. Though as a Chinese American, she was often limited to smaller roles that fit the Asian stereotype expected by white producers and audiences, Wong still managed to put her own stamp on the parts she was allotted. She built a career that spanned silent films, talkies, the theater, and television. She helped blaze a trail for subsequent generations of performers. To learn more about #HerStory, visit the link in our bio.

Calculating ballistic trajectories by hand during World War II took a long time, and two male engineers thought they could design a special machine that would calculate them faster. They called the machine the ENIAC (Electronic Numerical Integrator And Computer) and hired six women to perform calculations with them as a ‚Äúcomputer.‚Äù   The team included Jean Bartik, Betty Holberton, Frances Spence, Marlyn Meltzer, Kay Mauchly Antonelli, and Ruth Teitelbaum. They laid the groundwork for future programmers and software engineers.   And, since they were the first modern coders, they were instrumental in teaching others to program after the war.   To learn more about these women and when computer code was a ‚Äúwoman‚Äôs‚Äù job, visit the link in our bio.

Cassius Clay, later known as Muhammad Ali, shocked the odds-makers by dethroning world heavyweight boxing champ Sonny Liston in a seventh-round technical knockout on #ThisDayInHistory in 1964. He would go on to become one of the 20th century‚Äôs greatest sporting figures, as much for his social and political influence as his prowess in his chosen sport.   To read more about Muhammad Ali, visit the link in our bio.

29 men, including Captain Ernest Shackleton, spent years enduring the harsh Antarctic environment after their magnificent ship found itself trapped in the polar ice. The entire crew would survive, but many believed their vessel, the Endurance, would remain at the bottom of the frigid sea. Amazingly, a team of adventurers and experts have located the ship.   Tonight, HISTORY has a special feature that will remind viewers of the power of exploration. Read more about this incredible discovery, then join us for Shackleton's Endurance: The Lost Ice Ship Found starting at 10/9c.

In the evening on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, a series of Allied firebombing raids began against the German city of Dresden. Despite the horrendous scale of destruction, it arguably accomplished little strategically, since the Germans were already on the verge of surrender. Why was Dresden so heavily bombed? Read more by visiting the link in our bio.

Frederick Douglass, a leader in the abolitionist movement, chose for his birthday to be celebrated on #ThisDayInHistory. Born into slavery around 1818, the exact year and date of his birth are unknown. He was one of the most famous intellectuals of his time, advising the presidents, and lecturing to thousands on a range of causes including women‚Äôs rights. Douglass‚Äô legacy as an author and leader lives on. His work served as an inspiration to the civil rights movement of the 1960s and beyond.   To learn more about what Frederick Douglass revealed ‚Äì and omitted from his autobiographies, visit the link in our bio.

Feb. 13, 1920. For over thirty years, Black baseball players have been locked out of the major leagues. So on this day in Kansas City, Rube Foster, a former pitcher and now a team owner, is trying to make his own league just for Black players. He has gathered owners of other Black baseball teams, who currently play each other in one-off matchups or face independent teams in random games around the country. But Foster wants them to get organized, and soon, the Negro National League would be born. But up to this point, how did Black baseball survive after segregation became the unofficial policy of the major leagues? And how did Black players, owners, and managers join together to create something that no baseball fan could ignore? Find out on the #HISTORYThisWeek podcast. link in bio
Bill Johnson became the first American to win an Olympic gold medal in downhill skiing on #ThisDayInHistory in 1984.

Despite the severe racial, social and economic barriers that African American athletes have been subjected to throughout history, there have been notable individuals who have risen above the challenges and shattered all expectations. Not only did these athletes achieve ‚Äúfirsts‚Äù in their sport, but many also felt a heavy responsibility to stand up for their communities and use their fame to push for more inclusion both on and off the field.   Jackie Robinson, the first Black baseball player in Major League Baseball‚Äôs modern era.  Wilma Rudolph, the first Black American woman to win three gold medals in Olympic track and field.  Charlie Sifford, the first Black golfer in the PGA tour.  Gabby Douglas, the first Black gymnast to become the Olympic individual All-Around Champion.   To learn more about these (and more) pioneers in sports, visit the link in our bio.

Most people have heard about famous inventions like the light bulb and the cotton gin. But there are other, often overlooked inventions that make our daily lives easier. From the traffic light to the ironing board, here are some products that have sprung from the minds of Black inventors.   Black inventor Garrett Morgan came up with several significant inventions, one of the most influential inventions was the improved traffic light. Morgan‚Äôs was one of the first three-signal systems invented in the 1920s.   In the late 19th century, the ironing board was improved upon by Sarah Boone, an African American woman who was born enslaved. One of the first Black women in the U.S. to receive a patent, she expanded upon the original ironing board.   The central heating furnace design that Alice H. Parker patented in December 1919 used a unique system of individually controlled gas burners to keep homes warm and toasty.  Frederick McKinley Jones took out more than 60 patents throughout his life, including a patent for the roof-mounted cooling system that‚Äôs used to refrigerate goods on trucks during extended transportation. He received a patent for his invention in 1942 and co-founded the U.S. Thermo Control Company (Thermo King).   To learn more about the Black inventors who made daily life easier, visit the link in our bio.

Regarded as one of America‚Äôs greatest heroes, Abraham Lincoln, rose from humble beginnings to achieve the highest office in the United States.   A definitive biography of the 16th president, Abraham Lincoln, premieres TONIGHT on The HISTORY Channel at 8pm.

President Abraham Lincoln, a self-taught lawyer, legislator, and vocal opponent of slavery, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1809.   Lincoln proved to be a shrewd military strategist and savvy leader: his Emancipation Proclamation paved the way for slavery‚Äôs abolition, while his Gettysburg Address stands as one of the most famous pieces of oratory in American history.   On Sunday, February 20, a three-part documentary series, Abraham Lincoln, premieres to tell the story of America‚Äôs iconic 16th president.

In Thebes, Egypt on #ThisDayInHistory in 1923, English archaeologist Howard Carter entered the sealed burial chamber of the ancient Egyptian ruler King Tutankhamen.   Inside lay a sarcophagus with three coffins nested inside one another. The last coffin, made of solid gold, contained the mummified body of King Tut. Among the riches found in the tomb: golden shrines, jewelry, statues, a chariot, weapons, clothing. The mummy in its coffin was the most valuable, as it was the only such burial found perfectly preserved in modern times.   Visit the link in our bio to see more stunning photos of King Tut‚Äôs tomb.
Ratified on #ThisDayInHistory in 1870, the 15th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution sought to protect the voting rights of Black men after the Civil War.

After a long illness, King George VI of Great Britain, Ireland, and the British dominions beyond the sea died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1952. Princess Elizabeth, the oldest of the king‚Äôs two daughters, next in line to succeed him, was crowned Queen Elizabeth II on June 2, 1953.

Nelson Mandela, leader of the movement to end South African apartheid, was released from prison after 27 years on #ThisDayInHistory in 1990. Four years later he was elected as South Africa‚Äôs president.

Rosa Louise McCauley, known to history as Rosa Parks, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1913. A lifelong civil rights activist, Parks‚Äô name has become synonymous with her refusal to give up her seat to a white man on a segregated bus, a defining moment of the civil rights movement.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1960, four students sat down at the lunch counter at the Woolworth‚Äôs in downtown Greensboro, NC, where the official policy was to refuse service to anyone but white people. Denied service, the four young men refused to give up their seats.   The Greensboro sit-ins made an immediate and lasting impact, forcing Woolworth‚Äôs and other establishments to change their segregationist policies.  #BlackHistoryMonth

The words of Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. are well-known and often quoted. Most remember the speech he gave at the March on Washington in 1963, when he uttered those iconic words of American aspiration: ‚ÄúI have a dream‚Ä¶‚Äù He is remembered for his tireless work to bring about equality and civil rights for African Americans and his urging that nonviolence was the most effective form of protest. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1929, Martin Luther King, Jr. was born.

The Zen Buddhist monk Thich Nhat Hanh, one of the world's most influential spiritual leaders, has passed away at the age of 95. Thich Nhat Hanh began his vocation as a monk when he was 16, joining a Zen monastery in Vietnam before his official ordination in 1949.   The author, poet, and teacher gained prominence with his belief in ‚Äúengaged Buddhism,‚Äù taking the principles of the religion and applying them to societal issues and reform.   The late Reverend Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. nominated Thich Nhat Hanh for a Nobel Prize, writing that ‚ÄúHis ideas for peace, if applied, would build a monument to ecumenism, to world brotherhood, to humanity.‚Äù

President Theodore Roosevelt declared the massive Grand Canyon a national monument on #ThisDayInHistory in 1908. ‚ÄúLet this great wonder of nature remain as it is now,‚Äù he declared. ‚ÄúYou cannot improve on it. But what you can do is keep it for your children, your children‚Äôs children, and all who come after you, as the one great sight which every American should see.‚Äù How old is the Grant Canyon? Amid a steep decline in his musical career, Johnny Cash arrived to play for the inmates at California‚Äôs Folsom Prison on #ThisDayInHistory in 1968. The live album of the concert launched him back into the charts and re-defined his career.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio

Audrey Hepburn was only 63 years old when she died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1993, but the Hollywood legend packed a lot into her time on earth. She is one of few actresses to win an Emmy, Tony, Grammy, and Academy Award. In her later years, acting took a back seat to her work on behalf of children. She became a goodwill ambassador for UNICEF, traveling the world to raise awareness about children in need. To learn more about Audrey Hepburn, visit the link in our bio.

Joan of Arc, the ‚ÄúMaid of Orl√©ans,‚Äù was believed to have been born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1412. She lived only 19 years, but she would become a Roman Catholic saint and a national hero of France for her pivotal role in the Hundred Years‚Äô War.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1955, the curtain at the Metropolitan Opera in New York rose to reveal Marian Anderson, the first African American to perform with the Met. Her debut at the Met was a major moment in the history of integration of the arts, and the New York Times reported that her performance left many audience members in tears.

Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation on #ThisDayInHistory in 1863. The proclamation declared that as of this day all enslaved people in the states currently engaged in rebellion against the Union ‚Äúshall be then, thenceforward, and forever free.‚Äù   The Emancipation Proclamation would redefine the Civil War, turning it from a struggle to preserve the Union to one focused on ending slavery.   To learn more about Lincoln‚Äôs story, visit the link in our bio.

Theodore Roosevelt, the 26th president of the United States, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1919. A dynamic and energetic politician, Roosevelt confronted the bitter struggle between management and labor head-on and became known as the great ‚Äútrust buster‚Äù for his strenuous efforts to break up industrial combinations under the Sherman Antitrust Act. He was also a dedicated conservationist, setting aside some 200 million acres for national forests, reserves and wildlife refuges during his presidency.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1531, Pope Clement VII sent a letter to King Henry VIII of England forbidding him to remarry under penalty of excommunication. Henry, who was looking for a way out of his marriage to Catherine of Aragon, ignored the pope‚Äôs warnings. He went on to marry Anne Boleyn, leading to his excommunication and one of the most significant schisms in the history of Christianity.

At the National Gallery of Art in Washington, Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs masterpiece, the Mona Lisa, was exhibited for the first time in America on #ThisDayInHistory in 1963. Over 2,000 dignitaries, including President John F. Kennedy, came out that evening to view the famous painting. The next day, the exhibit opened to the public, and during the next three weeks an estimated 500,000 people came to see it.
Just 73 seconds after its lift-off, space shuttle Challenger exploded and broke up in a forking plume of smoke and fire on #ThisDayInHistory in 1986. There were no survivors.

On February 19, 1942, 10 weeks after the Japanese bombed Pearl Harbor, U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, calling for the internment of nearly all Japanese Americans. For the next two and a half years, many Japanese Americans endured extremely difficult living conditions and poor treatment by their military guards. But on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944, the Supreme Court put an end to the Japanese internment camps. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Jack Johnson became the first African American to win the world heavyweight title on #ThisDayInHistory in 1908 after defeating Canadian Tommy Burns. Johnson is remembered as the greatest defensive boxer in heavyweight history. To learn more about Jack Johnson‚Äôs career, visit the link in our bio.
Merry Christmas. We hope you have a joyous holiday.

When prohibitionist Carry Nation stepped into a bar in Wichita, Kansas on #ThisDayInHistory in 1900, nobody saw what was coming. She began to smash up the bar with a hatchet, causing several thousand dollars in damage. She was arrested soon after. She became famous for carrying a hatchet and wrecking saloons as part of her anti-alcohol crusade.   Though she died nine years before Prohibition began, Nation‚Äôs loud voice echoed in the United States‚Äô prohibition of what she saw as a dangerous scourge. Vincent van Gogh, who was suffering from severe depression, cut off the lower part of his left ear on #ThisDayInHistory in 1888. Afterward, he allegedly wrapped up the ear and gave it to a woman at a nearby brothel. Following that, he checked himself into a mental hospital.
2021 will be a year for the history books.

Iconic American actress, Betty White, has passed away at the age of 99.  The eight-time Emmy winner held the record for the longest TV career of any entertainer ‚Äî making her debut in the late 1930s. She maintained her popularity across decades starring on Life With Elizabeth, The Mary Tyler Moore Show and The Golden Girls.  In addition to her work as an actress and an advocate for animals, White wrote several books during the 1980s and 1990s.

Archbishop Desmond Tutu, the renowned Anglican cleric known for his opposition to the policies of apartheid, South Africa‚Äôs system of racial segregation, has died at the age of 90. During the 1980s, he drew national and international attention to the inequities of apartheid and in 1984, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize for his efforts. He helped transform South Africa's anti-apartheid movement into a truly international force. After apartheid‚Äôs end in the 1990‚Äôs, he was chosen to lead South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

Bob Dole, former U.S House and Senate member, has passed away at the age of 98.   Dole was awarded two Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star for his service in the military.  In the years after his presidential run in 1996, he dedicated his time and energy to his law firm, political activism, speaking engagements and philanthropic endeavors.

20 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Italy‚Äôs Leaning Tower of Pisa reopened after a team of experts spent 11 years to fortify the tower without eliminating its famous lean.   #DidYouKnow by the time the tower was completed in 1372, modern-day engineers say it was a miracle it didn‚Äôt fall completely. Why does the Leaning Tower of Pisa lean? Visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1980, John Lennon was shot and killed as he was entering his Manhattan apartment building. His death had, and continues to have, a profound impact on pop culture. To learn more about John Lennon, visit the link in our bio.

The first president of the United States, George Washington, died at his estate in Mount Vernon, Virginia on #ThisDayInHistory in 1799. Washington could have been king. Instead, he chose to be a citizen. He set many precedents for the national government and the presidency. His most important legacy may be that he insisted he was dispensable, asserting that the cause of liberty was larger than any single individual.   To learn more about George Washington, visit the link in our bio.

January 8, 1964. In his State of the Union address, Lyndon Johnson unveils his War on Poverty, an effort to tackle subpar living conditions and create jobs across the United States. Johnson discovers that declaring war‚Äîeven one on an idea‚Äîalways comes with great costs. In this podcast episode, #HISTORYThisWeek talks to presidential historian Doris Kearns Goodwin about the notorious war on poverty. Why did LBJ pick poverty as one of his major initiatives? And what issues did he face in waging this war?  Link in bio for more.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1933, the 21st Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was ratified, repealing the 18th Amendment, and bringing an end to the era of national prohibition of alcohol in America. Later this day, President Franklin D. Roosevelt issued a proclamation declaring the end of Prohibition while admonishing the country to drink responsibility and not abuse ‚Äúthis return of individual freedom.‚Äù

A group of Massachusetts colonists boarded three British tea ships and dumped 342 chests of tea into the harbor on #ThisDayInHistory in 1773. The nighttime raid, known as the Boston Tea Party, was in protest of the British Parliament‚Äôs Tea Act of 1773.   #Did you know‚Ä¶ It took nearly three hours for more than 100 colonists to empty the tea into Boston Harbor. The chests held more than 90,000 lbs. (45 tons) of tea, which would cost nearly $1,000,000 dollars today. To learn more about the Boston Tea Party, visit the link in our bio.

The Red Army had been advancing deeper into Poland since mid-January. Having liberated Warsaw and Krakow, Soviet troops headed for Auschwitz. In anticipation of the Soviet arrival, SS officers began a desperate attempt to destroy the evidence of their crimes. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, Soviet troops entered Auschwitz, Poland, freeing the survivors remaining in the camps ‚Äì and finally revealing to the world the depth of horror perpetrated there. #HolocaustRemembranceDay

80 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Pearl Harbor and other U.S. bases on Oahu, Hawaii were attacked by Japanese forces. The next day, Congress approved President Franklin D. Roosevelt‚Äôs declaration of war on Japan.   Today, we remember and honor the thousands of United States citizens who were killed in this attack.   To learn more about Pearl Harbor, visit the link in our bio. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1934, a young would-be dancer took to the stage of Harlem‚Äôs Apollo Theater to participate in a tradition known as Amateur Night. Although she had auditioned a dancer, at the last minute she was asked to sing. The performer in question was Ella Fitzgerald, whose decision to sing rather than dance set her on a course to becoming a musical legend. It also led to her victory at Amateur Night at the Apollo. To learn more about Ella Fitzgerald, visit the link in our bio.

Amidst the Civil War, President Abraham Lincoln delivered his State of the Union address on #ThisDayInHistory in 1862. Just weeks after he issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, Lincoln asserted that enslaved people liberated during the Civil War would remain forever free. To learn more about this annual presidential tradition, visit the link in our bio.

In Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte was crowned Napoleon 1 on #ThisDayInHistory in 1804. He became the first French ruler in 880 years to hold the title of emperor. Pope Pius VII handed Napoleon the crown that the 35-year-old conqueror of Europe placed on his own head. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Hollywood icon and civil rights activist, Sidney Poitier, has passed away at the age of 94. Poitier was the first Black actor to win an Academy Award for Best Actor in 1964 for his performance in ‚ÄòLilies of the Field.‚Äô Best known for his performance as Detective Virgil Tibbs in ‚ÄòThe Heat of the Night‚Äô in 1967, he helped break down color barrier in film and brought dignity to the portrayal of noble and intelligent characters.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1955, Rosa Parks was commuting home from a long day of work at the Montgomery Fair department store by bus. In 1955, Montgomery city ordinances required African Americans to sit at the back of public buses and were also obligated to give up those seats to white riders if the front of the bus filled up. The bus driver demanded that she and three others give up their seats, but Parks refused. She was arrested and jailed. Although her refusal was spontaneous, local civil rights leaders had been planning a challenge to Montgomery‚Äôs racial bus laws for several months. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Winston Leonard Spencer Churchill , the British leader who guided Great Britain and the Allies through World War II, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1874. He was one of the best-known, and some say one of the greatest, statesmen of the 20th century. Though he was born into a life of privilege, he dedicated himself to public service. To learn more about Winston Churchill, visit the link in our bio.

Lee Elder, the first Black golfer to play in the Masters tournament, has died at the age of 87. He would go on to play in the Masters six times, win four PGA Tour events and pave the way for many to follow.

The classic toys many of us grew up with have surprising backstories. Inspiration stemmed from failed inventions, parent‚Äôs unique jobs, and attempts to skirt school rules. Various mishaps and coincidences led to the creation of iconic toys that defined the childhood of generations.   Learn more about these stories at the link in our bio, and tune into #ToysThatBuiltAmerica TONIGHT at 9/8c to discover the astonishing stories behind the toys, games, and playthings that inspired you, only on The HISTORY Channel.

#DidYouKnow Black Friday was not tied to post-Thanksgiving shopping until the late 1950s? In fact, Black Friday didn‚Äôt take on its current more positive significance as America‚Äôs most popular holiday shopping day until the 1980s.

Jimi Hendrix, remembered as one of the greatest electric guitarists in history, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1942. He revolutionized rock and roll as both an artist and a producer during his brief four-year career.   To learn more about Jimi Hendrix, visit the link in our bio.

Three months after a new French constitution was approved, Charles de Gaulle was elected the first president of the Fifth Republic on #ThisDayInHistory in 1958. He dedicated himself to improving the country‚Äôs economic situation and maintaining its independence. To learn more about Charles de Gaulle, visit the link in our bio.

The Nuremberg Trials were a series of 13 military tribunals in which nearly 200 German government, military, medical and business leaders were tried for war crimes. The trials began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. In addition to bringing some of Nazi Germany‚Äôs most monstrous figures to justice, the trials broke new ground in international law. To learn more about the Nuremberg Trials, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1916, British Commander in Chief Sir Douglas Haig called a halt to his army‚Äôs offensive near the Somme River in northwestern France, ending the epic Battle of the Somme after more than four months of bloody conflict.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1960, a court order mandated the desegregation of schools came into effect in New Orleans, Louisiana. Then, six-year-old Ruby Bridges walked into William Frantz Elementary School accompanied by her mother and federal marshals. When she arrived, large crowds of people were gathered in front yelling and throwing objects. Bridges, in her innocence, first believed it was like a Mardi Gras celebration. She instantly became a symbol of the civil rights movement and an icon for the cause of racial equality. To learn more about Ruby Bridges, visit the link in our bio.

British Prime Minister John Major announced the formal separation of Charles, Prince of Wales and his wife, Princess Diana on #ThisDayInHistory in 1992. Major explained that the royal couple were separating ‚Äúamicably.‚Äù This report came after several years of speculation by the tabloid press that the marriage was in peril. Read more about Charles and Diana‚Äôs relationship by visiting the link in our bio.

We're proud to honor our nation's veterans along with our sponsor, @wwp , this Veterans Day. At WWP every day is Veterans Day and their impactful work is helping countless warriors heal from the visible and invisible wounds of war. We are honored to help tell their story, check it out.

Spanish explorer and conquistador, Francisco Pizarro, sprung a trap on the Inca emperor, Atahualpa. Pizarro lured Atahualpa to a feast in the emperor‚Äôs honor and then opened fire on the unarmed Incas. Pizarro‚Äôs men killed 5,000 Incas soldiers and captured Atahualpa, forcing him to convert to Christianity before eventually killing him. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.
Sometime in the early morning of #ThisDayInHistory in 1916, Grigory Efimovich Rasputin, a self-proclaimed holy man, was murdered by Russian nobles eager to end his influence over the royal family.

In a lavish wedding ceremony at Westminster Abbey in London, Princess Elizabeth married Philip Mountbatten on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. The celebrations surrounding the wedding of the popular princess lifted the spirits of the people of Britain, who were enduring economic difficulties in the aftermath of World War II. To learn more about their wedding, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1938, in an incident known as ‚ÄúKristallnacht,‚Äù Nazis in Germany torched synagogues, vandalized Jewish homes, schools and businesses and killed close to 100 Jews. In the aftermath of Kristallnacht, also called ‚ÄúThe Night of Broken Glass,‚Äù some 30,000 Jewish men were arrested and sent to Nazi concentration camps. After the horrific event, conditions for German Jews grew increasingly worse. To learn more about Kristallnacht, visit the link in our bio.

The gateway to America, Ellis Island, closed on #ThisDayInHistory in 1954 after processing more than 12 million immigrants since opening in 1892.   President Benjamin Harrison designated Ellis Island as America‚Äôs first federal immigration center in 1890. Before that time, the processing of immigrants had been handled by individual states.   To learn more about Ellis Island, visit the link in our bio.

The Hughes Flying Boat ‚Äì at one time the largest aircraft ever built ‚Äì was piloted by designer Howard Hughes on its first and only flight on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. Nicknamed the Spruce Goose, it never went into production, primarily because critics alleged that its wooden framework was insufficient to support its weight during long flights. To learn more about Howard Hughes, visit the link in our bio.

President Abraham Lincoln delivered one of the most memorable speeches in American history on #ThisDayInHistory in 1863. Lincoln‚Äôs address lasted just two or three minutes. The speech reflected his redefined belief that the Civil War was not just a fight to save the Union, but a struggle for freedom and equality for all, an idea Lincoln had not championed in the years leading up to the war. To read more about the Gettysburg Address, visit the link in our bio.

Veterans Day is a day for all of us to honor those who have served. Share a photo and story of a veteran in your life using #HonorAVet and @HISTORY and WE will donate $1 to @teamrubicon: a veteran-led disaster response organization. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1989, Manhattan borough president David Dinkins is elected New York City‚Äôs first Black mayor, while in Virginia, Lieutenant Governor Douglas Wilder became the first elected Black state governor in American history. To learn more about these two moments in history, visit the link in our bio.

Opening in 1934, Alcatraz Federal Penitentiary, the desolate island prison in the middle of San Francisco bay, was referred to by officials as ‚ÄúAmerica‚Äôs most secure prison.‚Äù Throughout its thirty year operation, 36 inmates chose to test that moniker, making bold attempts at escapes from the maximum security lockup. These attempted breakouts from ‚ÄúThe Rock‚Äù helped to turn the prison into a historical legend.   TONIGHT, @MorganFreeman goes behind the bars of Alcatraz in a unique virtual experience uncovering the story behind one of the most unbelievable escapes. Read more about Alcatraz‚Äôs escapes, Join us at 10/9c for the premiere of #GreatEscapes, only on The HISTORY Channel.

Charles Dickens began to write what would become ‚ÄòA Christmas Carol in October of 1843. He was determined to get the book out in time for Christmas that year. And he did. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1843, ‚ÄòA Christmas Carol‚Äô was published. He was certain the book would sell well ‚Äì but he could not have foreseen how the tale would be embraced by the public, or that it would evolve into a beloved classic. How did he write ‚ÄòA Christmas Carol‚Äô in only six weeks? Visit the link in our bio.

When British archaeologist Howard Carter first arrived in Egypt in 1891, most of the ancient Egyptian tombs had been discovered, though the little-known King Tutankhamen, who had died when he was 18, was still unaccounted for. After World War I, Carter began an intensive search for ‚ÄúKing Tut‚Äôs Tomb,‚Äù finally finding the steps to the tomb‚Äôs antechamber on #ThisDayInHistory in 1922. On November 26, 1922, Carter and fellow archaeologist Lord Carnavon entered the interior chambers of the tomb, finding them miraculously intact. To learn more about King Tut‚Äôs tomb, visit the link in our bio.

Heavy smog began to hover over London, England on #ThisDayInHistory in 1952. After five days, the Great Smog finally lifted on December 9, when a brisk wind from the west swept the toxic cloud away from London and out to the North Sea.

Hear the lesser-known, inspiring story of the Japanese American soldiers of WWII who fought for the ideals of American democracy in the one-hour documentary, Hidden Heroes: The Nisei Soldiers of WWII, tomorrow at 8 pm ET/PT. #HiddenHeroes
