Native American warriors like Sitting Bull, Tecumseh and Geronimo have long been celebrated as defenders of Indigenous territories. One lesser-known warrior was Lozen, an Apache, or Nde, woman who also resisted European domination. Known for her bravery, military prowess and dedications to her people‚Äôs safety during a tumultuous period in Apache history, Lozen was a warrior shaman and humanitarian who fought against Mexican and American forces for 30 years, earning the nickname ‚ÄúApache Joan of Arc.‚Äù   Lozen is pictured third from the right on the top sitting row. This image is the only verified photo showing her.   To learn more about Lozen, visit the link in our bio.   #NativeAmericanHeritageMonth

Son of a government administrator, Michelangelo Buonarroti, grew up in Florence, a center of the early Renaissance movement. Showing obvious talent, he was taken under the wing of Lorenzo de‚Äô Medici, the ruler of Florentine republic and a great patron of the arts. After demonstrating his mastery of sculpture, he was called to Rome in 1508 to paint the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. The ceiling was viewed by the public for the first time on #ThisDayInHistory in 1512. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Killer smog continued to hover over Donora, PA on #ThisDayInHistory in 1948. Over a five-day period, the smog killed about 20 people and made thousands more seriously ill.   Donora, a town in Pennsylvania, was the home to steel mills and a zinc smelting plant that had released excessive amounts of sulphuric acid, carbon monoxide and other pollutants into the atmosphere for years prior to the disaster. But there was little, or no regulation of the air pollution caused by the industries of Donora. In the aftermath, air pollution finally became a matter of public concern; the incident led to the passage of the 1963 Clean Air Act.

October 28, 1895. It‚Äôs the first day of a murder trial in Philadelphia, and H.H. Holmes has been left to represent himself. His lawyers say they haven‚Äôt had time to prepare for his case, although they may just want to avoid defending the man some newspapers are already saying is ‚Äúsure to grace a gallows.‚Äù Holmes has been accused of murdering his business associate, but rumors swirl that he may have killed dozens, even hundreds more. And even a century later, some still call him "America's first serial killer." But how did H.H. Holmes earn this reputation? And why is it so hard to learn the truth about this legendary fiend? Find out more on the #HistoryThisWeek podcast. Link in bio

While London boasts the world‚Äôs oldest underground train network (opened in 1863) and Boston built the first subway in the United States in 1897, the New York City subway soon became the largest American system. Opened on #ThisDayInHistory in 1904, more than 100,000 people paid a nickel to take their first ride under Manhattan. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 42 B.C., Brutus‚Äô army was crushed by Octavian and Antony at a second encounter at Philippi, and Brutus took his own life. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

The Statue of Liberty, a gift of friendship from the people of France to the people to the United States, was dedicated on #ThisDayInHistory in 1886. #DidYouKnow the statue was originally known as, ‚ÄúLiberty Enlightening the World.‚Äù To learn more about that making of the Statue of Liberty, visit the link in our bio

A 63-year-old former schoolteacher named Annie Edson Taylor became the first person to successfully take the plunge over Niagara Falls in a barrel on #ThisDayInHistory in 1901.   She was not the first person to attempt the plunge over the famous falls. But she was the first in a barrel. With the help of two assistants, Taylor strapped herself into a leather harness inside an old wooden pickle barrel. With cushions lining the barrel to break her fall, Taylor was towed by a small boat into the middle of the fast-flowing Niagara Falls and cut loose. She was knocked violently from side to side by the rapids but reached the shore alive.   After a brief flurry of photo-ops and speaking engagements, her fame cooled, and she was unable to make the fortune she had hoped. But she did inspire several copy-cat daredevils.   No matter the method, going over Niagara Falls is illegal, and survivors face charges and stiff fines on either side of the border.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Happy Halloween!    Did you know? Although it is unknown precisely where and when the phrase ‚Äútrick or treat‚Äù was coined, the custom had been firmly established in American popular culture by 1951, when trick-or-treating was depicted in the Peanuts comic strip.

When the Johnson administration announced that it would ask for a 10% increase in taxes to fund the Vietnam War, the public‚Äôs skepticism increased. The peace movement began to push harder for an end to the war. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1967, nearly 100,000 people gathered in Washington, D.C., to protest the American war effort in Vietnam. More than 50,000 of the protesters marched to the Pentagon to ask for an end to the conflict. The protest was the most dramatic sign of waning U.S. support for President Johnson‚Äôs war. To learn more about how the Vietnam War empowered the hippie movement, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1960, John F. Kennedy was elected president, narrowly beating Republican Vice President Richard Nixon. As president, Kennedy confronted mounting Cold War tensions in Cuba, Vietnam and elsewhere. He also led a renewed drive for public service and eventually provided federal support for the growing civil rights movement. To this day, many continue to rank him among the best-loved presidents in American history. To learn more about JFK, visit the link in our bio.

After the execution of her husband, the former King Louis XVI of France, Marie Antoinette was arrested and tried for trumped-up crimes against the French republic. Nine months late on #ThisDayInHistory in 1793, she was convicted and sent to the guillotine.   #DidYouKnow there is no evidence that Marie Antoinette ever said that starving peasants should ‚Äúeat cake‚Äù if they had no bread? In fact, the story of the fatuous noblewoman who said, ‚ÄúLet them eat cake!‚Äù appears in the philosopher Jean-Jacques Rousseau‚Äôs Confessions, which was written around 1766 ‚Äì when Marie Antoinette was just 11 years old. To learn more about Marie Antoinette, visit the link in our bio

140 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Pablo Picasso, one of the greatest and most influential artists of the 20th century, was born. He produced fantastical works, experimented with ceramics, and painted variations on the works of other masters in the history or art. He continued to produce art with undiminished forces until his death in 1973. To learn more about Picasso, visit the link in our bio.

Hopelessly trapped at Yorktown, Virginia, British General Lord Cornwallis surrendered 8,000 British soldiers to a larger Franco-American force, effectively bringing an end to the American Revolution on #ThisDayInHistory in 1781. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Al Capone was convicted of five counts of tax evasion on #ThisDayInHistory in 1931. A week later, Capone was sentenced to 11 years in prison plus a $50,000 fine. He began serving his time at the U.S. Penitentiary in Atlanta, but amid accusations that he was manipulating the system and receiving cushy treatment, he was transferred to the maximum-security prison at Alcatraz. To learn more about Al Capone, visit the link in our bio.

Colin Powell, the first Black U.S. Secretary of State and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has died at the age of 84 from complications of COVID-19. After serving two tours in Vietnam, Powell ascended to the top of the military ranks and helped influence American foreign policy throughout his career. Powell spoke frequently about his views on leadership and American democracy, dedicating his life to public service.

This episode of the #HistoryThisWeek podcast is sponsored by our partner, @wwp. November 11, 1918. At exactly 11 AM local time, the shooting stops. It‚Äôs eerily quiet for the first time in a long time. World War I has finally come to an end today after Germany and the Allied nations sign an armistice. The final battle of the war, known today as the Meuse-Argonne Offensive, saw an unexpected turn of events and surprising victory. How did a very untrained American army help bring this deadly battle to an end? And how did this final battle of World War I change the way we fight wars? Learn more by clicking the link in bio.

There was a time when traveling from the East Coast to the West Coast meant riding for months in a horse-drawn wagon or stagecoach, or sailing southward to Panama and then crossing the Isthmus to board another ship for a journey up the other coast. But that all changed on May 10, 1869, when the tracks of the Central Pacific Railroad and the Union Pacific Railroad joined together to form the transcontinental railroad. The new rail connection eventually made it possible to travel in a train car from New York to San Francisco in just a week‚Äôs time.   While the railroad's construction was a mammoth undertaking, its effects on the country were equally profound.

While this day has long been celebrated as Columbus Day, today we honor the indigenous peoples who were in the Americas long before his journey. #IndigenousPeoplesDay #ColumbusDay

It was on #ThisDayInHistory in 1957 that Bible-school dropout Jerry Lee Lewis laid down the definitive version of ‚ÄúGreat Balls of Fire.‚Äù At the peak of his powers following the smash-hit, he was a figure as magnetic as any in rock-and-roll history.

Margaret Thatcher, the first female Prime Minister in British history, announced her resignation on #ThisDayInHistory in 1990. During her time in office, she reduced the influence of trade union, privatized certain industries, scaled back public benefits and changed the terms of political debate. Nicknamed the ‚ÄúIron Lady,‚Äù she opposed Soviet communism and fought a war to maintain control of the Falkland Islands. How did the ‚ÄúIron Lady‚Äù nickname come about? Visit the link in our bio to learn more.

In 1921, a time of both gender and racial discrimination, Bessie Coleman broke barriers and became the world‚Äôs first Black woman to earn a pilot‚Äôs license in 1921. Because flying schools in the United States denied her entry, she took it upon herself to learn French and move to France to achieve her goal.   Though she wanted to start a flying school for Black Americans when she returned to the U.S., Coleman specialized in stunt flying and parachuting and earned a living barnstorming and performing aerial tricks. In 1922, she became the first Black woman in America to make a public flight.   To learn more about #HerStory, visit the link in our bio.

Despite losing much of his prime to World War II, Bobby Riggs was once considered the best tennis player in the world. Craving a return to the spotlight, Riggs decided to challenge some of tennis‚Äô top women players. Billie Jean King, who at that point in time had already won 10 major singles titles, repeatedly turned him down. Riggs, a self-proclaimed chauvinist, had boasted that women were inferior, that they couldn‚Äôt handle the pressure of the game and that even at his age he could beat any female player. In July of 1973, King agreed to play against Riggs.   In a highly publicized ‚ÄúBattle of the Sexes‚Äù tennis match, King beat Riggs on #ThisDayInHistory in 1973. King‚Äôs achievements not only help legitimize women‚Äôs professional tennis and female athletes, but were also seen as a victory for women‚Äôs rights in general.

Do you know the origin of #Oktoberfest?   On #ThisDayInHistory in 1810, Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig, later King Ludwig I of Bavaria, married Princess Therese von Sachsen-Hildburghausen. The Bavarian royalty invited the citizens of Munich to attend the festivities, held on the fields in front of the city gates.   The decision to repeat the festivities in the subsequent year gave rise to the tradition of the annual Oktoberfest.   To learn more about the annual festival, visit the link in our bio.

The first annual Cannes Film Festival opened at the resort city of Cannes on the French Riviera on #ThisDayInHistory in 1946. The festival intended to make its debut in September 1939, but the outbreak of World War II forced the cancellation. Over the years, the festival has been a forum to showcase the most powerful and accomplished new films.

If you ask people to name victorious Allied Powers in World War II, Mexico isn‚Äôt usually a name that comes to mind. But after declaring war against the Axis in mid-1942, Mexico did contribute to the Allied victory in important ways. Despite long standing tensions with the U.S., Mexico would become a valuable ally to its northern neighbors, ramping up its industrial production and contributing vital resources to the Allied war effort.   In addition, thousands of Mexican nationals living in the U.S. registered for military services during World War II. Mexico‚Äôs own elite air squadron, known as the Aztec Eagles, flew dozens of missions alongside the U.S. Air Force during the liberation of the Philippines in 1945.  To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1928, Elie Wiesel pursued Jewish religious studies before his family was forced into Nazi death camps during World War II. Wiesel survived and later wrote the memoir, Night, in which he recounted his experiences during the Holocaust. He became an international activists, orator, and figure of peace of the years, speaking out against injustices perpetrated in an array of countries. He was honored with several awards from around the world, including the U.S. Presidential Medal of Freedom.  In the second image, Elie Wiesel is the 7th from the left on the middle bunk.

October 1, 1904. If you showed up at a newsstand on this morning, you would have seen that the October issue of McClure's magazine had hit the shelves. Alongside it, newspapers advertised what was inside: "Ida M. Tarbell renders her final judgment of Rockefeller's Trust." It was the 19th and last installment in a series that had made people sit up and take notice of a powerful monopoly and the man behind it. How did a scrappy reporter take on the richest man in the country? And how, in the process, did she change corporate America and investigative journalism itself? Find out on the #HistoryThisWeek.  link in bio

Sculpting began on the faces of Mount Rushmore in the Black Hills National Forest of South Dakota on #ThisDayInHistory in 1927. It would take another 14 years until the faces of four of America‚Äôs most revered presidents were completed. According to the National Park Service, the first face to be chiseled was George Washington‚Äôs.

Yosemite National Park was established on #ThisDayInHistory in 1890 by an act of Congress. #DidYouKnow sheep were once among the primary threat to Yosemite‚Äôs national landscape?  To learn more about Yosemite National Park, visit the link in our bio.

In the 1920s, the major European nations competed to build larger and larger airships to gain control over the fledgling air-travel industry. The R-101 was Great Britain‚Äôs latest model as the decade came to an end. Powered by five Beardmore Tornado engines, it was 777 feet long, weighed 115 tons and could carry 100 passengers. The dirigible took off on a trip to British India but crashed hours later near Beauvais, France on #ThisDayInHistory in 1930.

Mexican American singer Selena Quintanilla was a Tejano superstar and was on the verge of an even higher level of fame when she was shot and killed in March of 1995. In her final days, Selena got to enjoy her ongoing success and make plans for the future ‚Äì but she also had to deal with frustrating encounters with Yolanda Sald√≠var, the woman who had managed Selena‚Äôs fan club and fashion boutiques before becoming her killer. To read more about Selena‚Äôs final days, visit the link in our bio.

The trial for eight antiwar activists charged with inciting violent demonstrations at the August 1968 Democratic National Convention began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969. Initially there were eight defendants, but Bobby Seale of the Black Panthers denounced the judge overseeing the case as a racist and demanded a separate trial.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1961, President John F. Kennedy advised American families to build bomb shelters to protect themselves from atomic fallout in the event of a nuclear exchange with the Soviet Union.

September 24, 1902. A new cooking school was set to open at Boston‚Äôs 30 Huntington Avenue. The rooms would be filled with trainee cooks, who watched in awe as the school‚Äôs namesake and principal, Fannie Farmer, lectured on everything from boning meats to baking the perfect reception rolls. Farmer was an innovative cook, and a pioneer in a thriving women's culinary movement known as "domestic science." But her school stood at a crossroads of that very movement and begged the question, what is the purpose of food? Who was Fannie Farmer, ‚Äúthe mother of level measurements‚Äù? And how did she shape the way we cook and eat today? Find out on the #HistoryThisWeek podcast

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1813, a New York newspaper published a new nickname for the United States, Uncle Sam. But, why? The most popular theory concerns Samuel Wilson, a New York meatpacker who provided food to the U.S. forces during the War of 1812. As the story goes, Wilson and Elbert Anderson, the contractor he supplied, stamped all their beef and pork barrels with the initials ‚ÄúE.A.-U.S.‚Äù The ‚ÄúU.S.‚Äù was shorthand for United States, but workers began joking that it stood for ‚ÄúUncle Sam,‚Äù as Wilson was locally known. Before long, soldiers had helped bring the term into common use as a nickname for the United States. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On Sept. 11, 2001, Ben Kaminow was sitting at his desk on the 25th floor of the North Tower of the World Trade Center when he suddenly was knocked out of his chair after the first plane struck. Kaminow quickly made his escape and out safely to the ground floor. Running towards the seaport, a comment from Craig Katz sparked up an unexpected connection and a beautiful act of kindness. Seeing Kaminow struggling, Katz offered him a pair of his sneakers after seeing his shoes were ruined from the shrapnel; a moment and impactful decision transforming Kaminow and Katz into lifelong friends.  Learn more about Ben Kaminow and Craig Katz‚Äôs story as part of The HISTORY Channel's #SaveOurHistory initiative and the network's continued partnership with the National September 11 Memorial & Museum @911Memorial. "Save Our History" tells the powerful stories about those who survived the September 11 attacks and highlights important artifacts in the museum's collection, including items donated by Kaminow and Katz.
The Constitution of the United States of America was signed by 38 of 41 delegates present at the conclusion of the Constitutional Convention on #ThisDayInHistory in 1787. #ConstitutionDay

September 15, 1893. About 4,000 people are intently listening to a monk on a stage in Chicago. They‚Äôre at an event called Parliament of the World‚Äôs Religions ‚Äì an unprecedented gathering of leaders from many different faiths all over the world, held at the Chicago World's Fair. The monk is Hindu from Bombay India and is telling a mostly Protestant American audience a story that is not planned and certainly not what the Protestant organizers were expecting. What happened when tension among religious leaders unfolded in front of thousands of American spectators? And how did this Parliament help broaden the country‚Äôs understanding of religion? Find out on the #HistoryThisWeek podcast. Link in bio
A special presentation of ‚ÄúDesert One,‚Äù from two time Academy Award-winning director Barbara Kopple, premieres tonight at 8/7c on The HISTORY Channel.

There isn‚Äôt an industry in which Hispanic Americans haven‚Äôt made their mark in history, with some of the most iconic politicians, singers, actors, athletes and more coming from Hispanic descent. To explore the ways that these Hispanic Americans have made their mark on the world, visit the link in our bio. #HispanicHeritageMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1967, Che Guevara was killed by the Bolivian army, which had captured him the day before. Since his death, Guevara has become a legendary political figure. His name is often equated with rebellion, revolution, and socialism. Others, however, remember that he could be ruthless and ordered prisoners executed without trial in Cuba. Guevara‚Äôs life continues to be a subject of great public interest.

On Sept. 11, 2001, Joanne Capestro arrived to her job at the May Davis Group on the 87th floor of the North Tower of the World Trade Center ready to start her day. But at 8:46 AM everything changed. After the tower was struck, she began her harrowing descent to street level just as the South Tower collapsed. Covered in dust, Capestro and her family feared for her life. But she miraculously managed to make her way home to Brooklyn later that afternoon. She saved the dust-covered shoes and clothing she was wearing as a testament to her evacuation experience and survival.   Learn more about Joanne Capestro's story as part of The HISTORY Channel's #SaveOurHistory initiative and the network's continued partnership with the National September 11 Memorial & Museum @911Memorial. "Save Our History" tells the powerful stories about those who survived the September 11 attacks and highlights important artifacts in the museum's collection, including items donated by Capestro.
On the 20th anniversary of 9/11, we honor and remember those who lost their lives. #NeverForget
Wait, THE most definitive voice of the 21st century doesn‚Äôt have all of the answers? Actually @morganfreeman is full of questions‚Ä¶and, that‚Äôs because being curious moves the world.

Carved from a single block of white Italian Carrara marble that had been rejected by other artists for being flawed, the massive statue depicts a nude David, the Biblical hero who used a slingshot to slay the giant Goliath. Michelangelo Buonarroti‚Äôs 12,000-pound masterpiece was unveiled to the public in the Piazza della Signoria on #ThisDayInHistory in 1504.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1914, with World War I approaching the end of its first month, the Women‚Äôs Defence Relief Corps was formed in Britain. Though women‚Äôs rights organizations in Britain had initially opposed the country‚Äôs entrance into the First World War, they reversed their position soon enough, recognizing the potential of the war effort to gain advancement for British women on the home front.

Massachusetts Senator John F. Kennedy married Jacqueline Bouvier in Newport, Rhode Island on #ThisDayInHistory in 1953. Seven years later, the couple would become the youngest elected president and first lady in American history. To learn more about their nuptials, visit the link in our bio.

Diana, Princess of Wales, and her boyfriend, Dodi Fayed left the Ritz Paris just after midnight on #ThisDayInHistory in 1997 intending to go to Fayed‚Äôs apartment. As soon as they departed the hotel, a swarm of paparazzi on motorcycles began aggressively tailing their car. About three minutes later, the driver, Henri Paul, lost control and crashed into a pillar at the entrance of the Pont de l‚ÄôAlma tunnel. Diana, Fayed and the driver died in the crash.   Like much of her life, her death was a full-blown media sensation. She was one of the most popular public figures in the world and her death was met with a massive outpouring of grief. To see how the People‚Äôs Princess changed the world, visit the link in our bio.

This year marks the 20th anniversary of the #September11 terrorist attacks and the historical impact that forever transformed our nation. Four new documentaries will premiere on the HISTORY Channel September 10 and 11 to commemorate the memory of those we lost and those who survived -- a reminder of a day in history we must #NeverForget.

While visiting family in Mississippi, 14-year-old Emmett Till was brutally murdered for allegedly flirting with a white woman four days earlier on #ThisDayInHistory in 1955. His assailants‚Äîthe white woman‚Äôs husband and his step-brother ‚Äì beat him severely and shot him in the head. Till‚Äôs murder and open casket funeral galvanized the emerging civil rights movement. In a 2017 book, a historian reported that Carolyn Bryant, the woman who accused Till, had recanted her testimony, admitting that he never touched her or threatened her. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

In the late 1800s at the height of the Industrial Revolution in the U.S., the average American factory worker worked 12-hour days and seven-days a week. Despite some restrictions, children as young as 5 or 6 toiled in mills, factories, and mines across the country, earning a fraction of their adult counterparts‚Äô wages. As manufacturing increasingly supplanted agriculture as the wellspring of American employment, labor unions grew more prominent and vocal.  They organized strikes and rallies, many of which turned violent.   The idea of a ‚Äúworkingmen‚Äôs holiday,‚Äù soon spread throughout the country and became a federal holiday in 1894.

Efforts to locate and salvage the Titanic began almost immediately after it sank. But technical limitations ‚Äì as well the sheer vastness of the North Atlantic search area ‚Äì made it extremely difficult. Seventy-three years after it sank, a joint U.S.-French expedition located the wreck of the RMS Titanic on #ThisDayInHistory in 1985. Swipe through to see some of the artifacts recovered. To learn more about the Titanic, visit the link in our bio.

In the 1940s, this young boy was prepping to go back to school, like most children, as the summer drew to an end. This boy would later get a C in music class but ultimately grew up to shatter records. Take a guess, who‚Äôs this back-to-schooler?

Thurgood Marshall was sworn in as the First Black justice of the U.S. Supreme Court on #ThisDayInHistory in 1967. As chief counsel for the NAACP in the 1940s and ‚Äò50s, Marshall was the architect and executor of the legal strategy that ended the era of official racial segregation.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1920, the 19th Amendment, guaranteeing white women the right to vote, was formally adopted into the U.S. Constitution. The amendment was the culmination of more than 70 years of struggle by women suffragists.

On December 5, 1945, a group of five TBM Avenger torpedo bombers known as Flight 19 took off for a routine training flight from a Naval Air Station in Ft. Lauderdale, Florida. The flight‚Äôs leader, Lieutenant Charles C. Taylor became convinced, for reasons that remain unclear, that his planes had been flying in the wrong direction. He steered Flight 19 northeast‚Äîa course that would only take them further out to sea. As the flight continued to drift from the safety of the shore, the fleet‚Äôs radio was replaced by a static buzz. The planes were never heard from again.  For decades, the whereabouts of Flight 19 have remained unknown. The return of History‚Äôs Greatest Mysteries brings a hunt for clues, and unlocks what may be the key to solving this mystery. Read more about the disappearance at the link in our bio, and tune in for answers September 7 at 8/7c, only on The HISTORY Channel.

#DidYouKnow that the word ‚Äúskyscraper‚Äù got its origin from a nautical term referring to a tall mast or sail on a ship? Since the construction of the first skyscrapers in the late 1800s, these breathtaking buildings have become expected fixtures in urban living, and have often been revered as iconic architectural landmarks.   To learn more about the Mohawk "Skywalkers" who helped build New York City's Tallest, visit the link in our bio.

In 1619 on #ThisDayInHistory, some 20 Africans, kidnapped by the Portuguese, were brought to the English colony of Virginia. Their forced arrival in the New World marked a beginning of two and a half centuries of slavery in North America.

John White, the governor of the Roanoke Island colony in present-day North Carolina, returned from a trip to England to find the settlement deserted on #ThisDayInHistory in 1590. White and his men found few traces of the 100 or so colonists he left behind, although there were no signs of violence.
The original crate challenge #cratechallenge

The ancient cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum thrived near the base of Mount Vesuvius at the Bay of Naples. But on #ThisDayInHistory in 79 A.D., this pleasure and prosperity came to an end when Mount Vesuvius exploded, propelling a 20-mile-high cloud of ash and pumice. The cities, buried under a thick layer of volcanic material and mud, were never rebuilt. To learn more about the eruption and its devastation, visit the link in our bio.

After more than four years of Nazi occupation, Paris was liberated on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944 by the French 2nd Armored Division and the U.S. 4th Infantry division. German resistance was light, and General Dietrich von Choltitz, commander of the German garrison, defied an order by Adolf Hitler to blow up Paris‚Äô landmarks and burn the city to the ground before its liberation. Choltitz signed a formal surrender that afternoon and the next day, Free French General Charles de Gaulle led a joyous liberation march down the Champs d‚ÄôElysees.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1969, the grooviest event in music history ‚Äì the Woodstock Music & Art Fair ‚Äì began the final night of its three days of peace and music in upstate New York.

August 24, 1914. A train pulled up to the lumber town of White River, Ontario, carrying a regiment of Canadian troops on board. On the tracks where they disembarked was a small black bear cub. An army veterinarian decided to buy the bear and name her Winnipeg‚ÄîWinnie for short‚Äîafter the town their train left from. When the soldiers deployed to the European front, Winnie was left at the London Zoo, where a child named Christopher Robin Milne met her. He later renamed his own teddy bear after her: Winnie the Pooh. How did a real-life boy and a real-life bear inspire some of the world's most famous literary characters? And what impact did these stories ultimately have on the people who helped bring them to life? Find out more on the #HistoryThisWeek podcast. Link in bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1909, in the first five-mile race at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, 12,000 spectators watched Austrian engineer Louis Schwitzer win with an average speed of 57.4 miles per hour. Since 1911, the Indianapolis 500 has been held every year, except for 1917-1918 and 1942-1945, when the U.S. was involved in the two World Wars.

Black History Month honors the contributions of Black Americans to U.S. history. Among prominent figures are Madam C.J. Walker, who was one of the first Black female self-made millionaires in the U.S.; John Mercer Langston, who was the first Black man to become a lawyer in Ohio when he was admitted to the state‚Äôs bar; Hattie McDaniel, the first African American performer to win an Academy Award; and Shirley Chisholm, the first African American woman elected to the U.S. House of Representatives.   Visit the link in our bio to read more.

Some of the greatest stories ever told start behind bars. @morganfreeman will unearth every step of an inmate's meticulous plans, the escape route, and the manhunt that followed. Great Escapes with Morgan Freeman premieres Tuesday, November 9, only on The HISTORY Channel.

Under the threat of Allied bombing during World War II, the German car manufacturer Volkswagen halted production of the ‚ÄúBeetle,‚Äù on #ThisDayInHistory in 1944. In the war‚Äôs aftermath, Volkswagen, then under the control of the British military, began turning out Beetles again in December 1945.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, the United States became the first and only nation to use atomic weaponry during wartime when it dropped an atomic bomb on the Japanese city of Hiroshima. Three days later, an atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki. Visit the link in our bio to read more.

August 21, 1911. On a Monday morning, a department store employee on a Paris street saw a man hurrying by. He carried a white-wrapped package, and as the employee watched, he threw something small and shiny over his shoulder...it was a doorknob. Then the man disappeared into the streets of Paris. That store employee had just witnessed a small part of what would soon become the world‚Äôs most famous crime. In that white-wrapped package was...the Mona Lisa. Why has the Mona Lisa enchanted so many people since the 1500s? And how did a struggling Italian handyman manage to steal it? Find out more on the #HistoryThisWeek Podcast (Link in bio)

It was the first day of school at Little Rock Central High School, Elizabeth Eckford and eight other Black students were recruited to the all-white school to test Arkansas‚Äô supposed intention to integrate its schools. But on #ThisDayInHistory in 1957, Arkansas governor Orval Faubus enlisted the National Guard to prevent these students from entering. The armed troops surrounded the school while an angry white crowd jeered, booed, and threatened to lynch the frightened Black teenagers, who fled shortly after arriving. Faubus took the action in violation of a federal order to integrate the schools. The conflict set the stage for the first major test of the U.S. Supreme Court‚Äôs unanimous 1954 decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka that racial segregation in educational facilities is unconstitutional.   Later that month, President Eisenhower sent in federal troops to escort the Little Rock Nine into the school.   To learn more about the story behind this iconic image, visit the link in our bio.

As war spread across Europe in 1940, the head of France‚Äôs military counterintelligence service recruited an unlikely spy: the American-born expatriate ‚Äì Josephine Baker.   Jacques Abtey, head of the French counter-military intelligence, had spent the early days of World War II recruiting spies to collect information on Nazi Germany and other Axis powers. Typically, he sought out men who could travel incognito. Then again, nothing was typical when it came to the dancer and singer, Josephine Baker.   A celebrity of Baker‚Äôs stature made for the most unlikely spy candidate since she could never travel secretly ‚Äì but that‚Äôs exactly what made her such an enticing prospect. Fame would be her cover. Abtey hoped Baker could use her charm and stardom to extract secrets from diplomats. Having found in France the freedom that sometimes eluded her in the U.S., Baker agreed to spy for her adopted country.   To read more about Josephine Baker‚Äôs double life as a spy, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1962, movie actress Marilyn Monroe was found dead from a drug overdose in her home in Los Angeles. She was only 36 years old.   Born Norma Jeane Mortenson in 1926, Monroe overcame a difficult childhood to become one of the world‚Äôs most iconic actresses.   To learn more about her final days, visit the link in our bio.
After more than two centuries as a royal palace, the Louvre was opened as a public museum in Paris on #ThisDayInHistory in 1793.
Aboard the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay, U.S. General Douglas MacArthur accepted Japan‚Äôs formal surrender, bringing an end to World War II on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945.

Cleopatra, queen of Egypt and lover of Julius Caesar and Mark Antony, took her life following the defeat of her forces against Octavian, the future first emperor of Rome. To learn more about Cleopatra, visit the link in our bio.

August 2, 1915. The poem appears in print for the first time this week, from Kentucky to Pennsylvania to Vermont. Every reader is transported to that same leafy path: ‚Äútwo roads diverged in a yellow wood.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Road Not Taken‚Äù by Robert Frost becomes an immediate hit and will go on to become one of the most popular and well-known poems in American history. For many, it's about a spirit of individualism -- forging one‚Äôs own path. And yet‚Ä¶ Robert Frost may have had a completely different meaning in mind. What‚Äîor who‚Äîinspired Frost to write this iconic poem? And what is it really telling us about how to make a choice? Listen to the #HistoryThisWeek podcast to find out.

As World War erupts in Europe, President Woodrow Wilson follows public opinion and stays out of the international conflict. But when a merchant ship carrying American passengers is attacked by a German U-boat, the United States begins to emerge from isolation and establishes itself as a source of possibility in the world. To learn more listen to the Hope, Through History Podcast. Link in bio

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1981, Prince Charles married Lady Diana Spencer in a grand ceremony at St. Paul‚Äôs Cathedral. Nicknamed ‚Äúthe wedding of the century‚Äù for its extravagance, it broke new records and set global fashion trends‚Äîwhile also breaking with tradition in refreshing ways.
Ernest Miller Hemingway was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1899. The influential American literary icon became known for his straightforward prose and use of understatement.

The systematic deportation of Jewish people from the Warsaw ghetto began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1942, as thousands were rounded up daily and transported to a newly constructed concentration/extermination camp at Treblinka, in Poland.

Tucked away in the rocky countryside northwest of Cuzco, Machu Picchu is believed to have been a summer retreat for the Inca leaders, whose empire was virtually wiped out by Spanish invaders in the 16th century. For hundreds of years until American archaeologist Hiram Bingham stumbled upon it on #ThisDayInHistory in 1911, the abandoned citadel‚Äôs existence was a secret known only to peasants living in the region.
Ending the week on a high note.   üì∏  Stuntman Evel Knievel prepares to jump Snake River Canyon, Idaho on a steam powered skycycle; 1974.

During the 1930s, America went through one of its most challenging eras, the Great Depression. President Franklin D. Roosevelt attempted to relieve the dire economic situation through a set of programs and projects known as The New Deal. During the Depression, the U.S. government employed photographers to document the suffering of those affected by unemployment and poverty. Their efforts produced some of the most iconic photographs in American history.   The team of documentary photographers included Dorothea Lange (whose iconic image is shown here), Arthur Rothstein, Walker Evans, Russell Lee, Gordon Parks, Carl Mydans, and Jack Delano.   To read more about how photography defined the Depression, visit the link in our bio.

After nearly six months of the sit-in movement, the Greensboro Woolworths quietly integrated its lunch counter. Four Black Woolworth‚Äôs employees ‚Äì Geneva Tisdale, Susie Morrison, Anetha Jones, and Charles Bess ‚Äì were the first to be served on #ThisDayInHIstory in 1960.

After nearly 15 years of construction, the Sydney Opera House was dedicated on #ThisDayInHistory in 1973 by Queen Elizabeth II. Over 230 designs were submitted for the Opera House, but J√∏rn Utzon from Denmark would be the winning architect. To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1963, in front of a crowd of nearly 250,000 people spread across the National Mall in Washington, D.C., Martin Luther King, Jr. delivered his now-famous ‚ÄúI Have a Dream‚Äù speech from the steps of the Lincoln Memorial.   #DidYouKnow King almost didn‚Äôt deliver what is now the most famous part of the speech?  He had debuted the phrase, ‚ÄúI have a dream,‚Äù in his speeches at least nine months before the March on Washington and used it several times since then. His advisers discouraged him from using the same theme again. But as he spoke that day, Mahalia Jackson prompted him to ‚ÄúTell them about the dream, Martin.‚Äù Abandoning his prepared text, King improvised the rest of his speech.

Fossil hunter Susan Hendrickson discovered three huge bones jutting out of a cliff near Faith, South Dakota on #ThisDayInHistory in 1990. They turned out to be part of one of the largest- Tyrannosaurus rex skeletons ever discovered, a 65-million-year-old specimen named Sue, after its discoverer. Sue‚Äôs skeleton was over 90% complete and the bones were extremely well-preserved.

In 1789 on #ThisDayInHistory, the French revolutionaries stormed and began dismantling the Bastille, a royal fortress and prison that had come to symbolize the tyranny of the Bourbon monarchs. This dramatic action signaled the beginning of the French Revolution, a decade of political turmoil and terror in which King Louis XVI was overthrown and tens of thousands of people, including the king and his wife, Marie Antoinette, were executed. To learn more about the French Revolution and the influence America had, visit the link in our bio.

After Orville and Wilbur Wright‚Äôs first flight, progress on the airplane was slow but steady. By the 1920s and 30s, four innovators raced to make passenger travel a reality and one emerged victorious to help make flying as accessible as it is today. See the stories unfold in The Machines That Built America. The two-hour premiere begins tonight at 9/8c only on The HISTORY Channel.

The 14th Amendment, granting citizenship to all persons born or naturalized in the United States‚Äîincluding formerly enslaved people‚Äîwas officially adopted into the U.S. Constitution on #ThisDayInHistory in 1868. The 14th Amendment was one of three amendments passed during the Reconstruction era to abolish slavery and establish civil and legal rights for Black Americans. It would become the basis for many landmark Supreme Court decisions over the years. To learn more about the ratification of the 14th Amendment, visit the link in our bio.

The final ‚ÄúBig Three‚Äù meeting between the United States, the Soviet Union and Great Britain took place on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945 in the Berlin suburb of Potsdam. The decision reached at the conference settled many of the pressing issues between the three wartime allies, but the meeting was also marked by growing suspicion and tension between the United States and the Soviet Union. To learn more the uneasiness surrounding the conference, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1985, Prince Charles and Princess Diana officially opened Live Aid, a worldwide rock concert organized to raise money for the relief of famine-stricken Ethiopians at Wembley Stadium in London. The concert continued at JFK stadium in Philadelphia and at other arenas around the world. The 16-hour show was globally linked by satellite to more than a billion viewers in 110 nations. In a triumph of technology and good will, the event raised more than $125 million in famine relief for Africa.

American astronaut Neil Armstrong became the first human to walk on the surface of the moon on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969. After speaking the words, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind,‚Äù Armstrong was joined on the moon‚Äôs surface by Buzz Aldrin.

Elizabeth Cady Stanton, an abolitionist and leader of the early women's rights movement, was determined from an early age to advocate for women's rights. Stanton worked with Lucretia Mott, Mary M'Clintock, Martha Coffin Wright and Jane Hunt to organize a convention for women's rights in Seneca Falls, NY. At the convention, the women outlined their demands in "The Declaration of Sentiments." Now known as the Seneca Falls Convention, this gathering began on #ThisDayinHistory in 1848.
Barack Obama, the 44th president of the United States and the first African American to serve as commander-in-chief was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1961 in Honolulu, Hawaii.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1940, German forces began the first in a long series of bombing raids against Great Britain. The Battle of Britain would last three and a half months. Pilots and support crews on both sides took to the skies and battled for control of airspace over Great Britain, Germany and the English Channel.

July 19, 64 AD. How did the Circus Maximus, an area teeming with life, get destroyed? What caused the city to burn and was the emperor of Rome behind it? Listen to this week‚Äôs latest episode of #HistoryThisWeek podcast to find out. Link in bio.

Princess Diana, one of the most revered members of the British royal family, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1961. She is remembered as the ‚ÄúPeople‚Äôs Princess‚Äù because of her widespread popularity and global humanitarian efforts.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1960, Senator John F. Kennedy of Massachusetts was nominated for the presidency by the Democratic National Convention. Kennedy had defeated Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas, who was named Kennedy‚Äôs running mate by a unanimous vote of the convention the next day. Four months later, on November 8, Kennedy won 49.7% of the popular vote in one of the closest presidential elections in U.S. history, surpassing by a fraction the 49.6% received by Vice President Richard M. Nixon. To learn more about JFK‚Äôs presidency, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1942, Anne Frank‚Äôs family went into hiding. Several weeks earlier, her father, Otto Frank, had approached his Austrian-born bookkeeper, Miep Gies, and asked if she would help hide his family. Otto also asked his employees Johannes Kleiman, Victor Kugler en Bep Voskuijl to help. They agreed and risked their lives to smuggle food, supplies and news of the outside world into the so-called Secret Annex, whose entrance was hidden behind a movable bookcase.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1804, in one of the most famous duels in American history, Vice President Aaron Burr shot and mortally wounded his long-time political antagonist Alexander Hamilton. To read more about the duo‚Äôs rivalry, visit the link in our bio.

When the United States entered World War II, Franklin D. Roosevelt made it clear that he thought Major League Baseball should continue. After more than 500 players left their teams to serve in the military, Philip K. Wrigley founded the All-American Girls Professional League in 1943. To find players for the women‚Äôs league, Wrigley sent scouts across the United States, Canada and Cuba. A total of 60 women made the cut for the first season.

By the end of the 19th century, many Americans still worked on farms, and getting food from farm to table was labor intensive work. But machines helped revolutionized farming --including the tractor. The race to invent the tractor is shown in the two-hour premiere of The Machines That Built America, premiering tonight at 9/8c, only on The HISTORY Channel.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1776, a 2,000-pound copper-and-tin bell now known as the Liberty Bell was said to have rung out from the tower of Pennsylvania State House, summoning citizens to the first public reading of the Declaration of Independence.

Future President Franklin Delano Roosevelt was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1882. Here are 4 things you may not know about America‚Äôs longest serving president.  1. Roosevelt was distantly related to both his wife and 11 other presidents.  2. He won all his presidential elections in landslides.  3. He tried to increase the size of the Supreme Court.  4. He was the first sitting president to fly in a plane.   To learn more about FDR, visit the link in our bio.

In September of 1984, after years of negotiation, the British and Chinese signed a formal agreement approving the 1997 turnover of the island in exchange for a Chinese pledge to preserve Hong Kong‚Äôs economic system. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1997, Hong Kong was peaceably handed over to China in a ceremony attended by numerous Chinese, British and international dignitaries. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Hope, Through History podcast is back with new episodes hosted by Jon Meacham. In this new season, we‚Äôll explore five pivotal moments of crisis in American History and how they shaped the nation. Up first, FDR, Churchill, and America‚Äôs Slow walk to war.  Link in bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1937, Amelia Earhart and Fred Noonan departed Lea, New Guinea for Howland Island. It was the last time Earhart was seen alive. She and Noonan lost radio contact with the U.S. Coast Guard cutter ‚ÄòItasca, anchored off the coast of Howland Island, and disappeared en route. President Franklin D. Roosevelt authorized a massive two-week search for the pair, but they were never found. On July 18, 1937, Earhart and Noonan were declared lost at sea.

The All England Croquet and Lawn Tennis Club began its first lawn tennis tournament at Wimbledon on #ThisDayInHistory in 1877. Twenty-one amateurs showed up to compete in the Gentlemen‚Äôs Singles tournament, the only event at the first Wimbledon. Then in 1884, the Ladies‚Äô Singles was introduced at Wimbledon. Since the first day, Wimbledon has been the stage many for historic matches.   This week in history on July 5, 1975, Arthur Ashe became the first Black man ever to win Wimbledon. That same year, he became the first Black man to be ranked No. 1 in the world.   Althea Gibson became the first Black woman to win a championship at Wimbledon on this week in history on July 6, 1957. That same year she won the U.S. Open and was named Female Athlete of the Year in 1957 and 1958 by the Associated Press.   On #ThisDayInHistory in 2000, Venus Williams won at Wimbledon for the first time making history as the first Black female Wimbledon champion since Althea Gibson‚Äôs back-to-back titles in 1957 and 1958.  To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

The dismantled Statue of Liberty, a gift of friendship from the people of France to the people of America, arrived in New York Harbor on #ThisDayInHistory in 1885. Intended to commemorate the American Revolution and a friendship between the U.S. and France, the statue was designed by French sculptor Frederic-Auguste Bartholdi (who may have modeled it after his own mother), with the assistance from engineer Gustave Eiffel. To learn more about the Statue of Liberty, visit the link in our bio.

Over 20,000 garment workers, almost all of the Asian American women, marched together in solidarity for better benefits #ThisDayInHistory in 1982. The walkout succeeded in retaining critical benefits for garment workers who toiled long workdays in often harsh conditions. The strike‚Äôs success also showed that Asian American women ‚Äì even those with a language barrier ‚Äì could amplify their voices, take action and be heard.

Newly nominated senatorial candidate Abraham Lincoln addressed the Illinois Republican Convention and warned that the nation faced a crisis that could destroy the Union. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1858, speaking to more than 1,000 delegates in an ominous tone, Lincoln paraphrased a passage from the New Testament: ‚Äúa house divided against itself cannot stand.‚Äù The issue dividing the nation was slavery‚Äôs place in the growing western territories and the extent of federal power over individual states‚Äô rights. To learn why this speech was so important, visit the link in our bio.

The Korean War began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1950 when some 75,000 soldiers from North Korea poured across the 38th parallel to South Korea. This invasion was the first military action of the Cold War.

Henry Ossian Flipper, born into slavery in Thomasville, Georgia in 1856, became the first African American cadet to graduate from the United States Military Academy at West Point on #ThisDayInHistory in 1877. After graduation, Flipper was appointed to serve as second lieutenant in the all-African American 10th Cavalry and stationed at Fort Sill in Oklahoma. The ninth and 10th Cavalry were regiments of black enlisted men who became known as the Buffalo Soldiers. To learn more about who Henry Ossian Flipper was, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1913, Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs masterpiece ‚ÄòThe Mona Lisa‚Äô was recovered inside Vincenzo Peruggia‚Äôs hotel room in Florence. Peruggia had previously worked at the Louvre and had perpetrated in the heist dressed as a Louvre worker on August 21, 1911. After the recovery, Peruggia was convicted of the robbery and spent just 7 months in jail. To learn more about the heist, visit the link in our bio.
Happy Thanksgiving! #DidYouKnow although turkeys were indigenous, there is no record of a big, roasted bird at the feast.

An official announcement of Japan‚Äôs unconditional surrender to the Allies was made public to the world on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Since then, both August 14 and August 15 have marked the anniversary of celebrations in the U.S. and U.K. marking the effective end of the war.

Happy National Selfie Day. #DidYouKnow the first selfie was said to be taken by Robert Cornelius in 1839.
