Sometime after midnight on #ThisDayInHistory in 1969, police raided the Stonewall Inn. While police raids on gay bars were common, members of the city‚Äôs gay community decided to fight back ‚Äì sparking an uprising that would launch a new era of resistance and demands for change. For a timeline of events, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1972, Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 was enacted into law. Title IX prohibits federally funded educational institutions from discriminating against students or employees based on sex. It begins: ‚ÄúNo person in the United States shall, on the basis of sex, be excluded from participation in, be denied the benefits of, or be subjected to discrimination under any education program or activity receiving Federal financial assistance.‚Äù To learn more about Title IX, visit the link in our bio.

Women's gymnastics has been an official sport in the Summer Olympics since 1928, when the first female Olympic gymnasts competed in Amsterdam. Since then, it has become one of the most popular sports in the international games. Here‚Äôs a look at some of the sport‚Äôs most memorable moments in Olympics history.   The 1948 London Olympics marked the return of the Olympic Games after World War II, and it also marked the first time the U.S. women's gymnastics team won a medal in the team competition.   In 1976, 14-year-old Nadia ComƒÉneci became the first gymnast to receive a perfect 10 in an Olympic event.   The 1996 Atlanta Olympics were a major year for U.S. women's gymnastics. Dominique Dawes won bronze in the individual floor exercise, becoming the first Black American woman to win an Olympic medal in gymnastics.   At the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Simone Biles attended and dazzled. As the winner of 30 Olympic and World Championship medals and the only woman to hold seven all-around U.S. championship titles, she is currently one of the most decorated U.S. gymnasts.   For more astonishing moments in women's Olympic gymnastics, visit the link in our bio.

Juneteenth is a commemoration holiday for #ThisDayInHistory in 1865 when Union General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas to ensure the emancipation of all enslaved people there. Granger and his troops' arrival came a full two and a half years after Lincoln had signed the Emancipation Proclamation. #Juneteenth honors the effective end of slavery in the United States and is considered the longest-running African American holiday. To learn more about the importance of Juneteenth, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1914, World War I began. After declaring war on Russia, the German army then launched an attack on Russia‚Äôs ally, France, through Belgium, violating Belgian neutrality and bringing Great Britain into the war. To learn more about the outbreak of World War I, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1776, the Continental Congress formally adopted the Declaration of Independence, which proclaimed the independence of the United States of America from Great Britain and its king.

Construction of the Hoover Dam project began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1930. Over the next five years, a total of 21,000 men would work ceaselessly to produce what would be the largest dam of its time, as well as one of the largest human-built structures in the world. The dam would provide essential flood control, which would prevent damage to downstream farming communities and allow the expansion of irrigated farming in the desert.

The rainbow flag, a universal symbol of the LGBTQ community, was created in 1978 by artist, designer, veteran, and then-drag performer, Gilbert Baker.   At the time, the most commonly used image for the gay rights movement was a pink triangle, a symbol used by the Nazis to identify homosexuals. Using a symbol with such a dark and painful past was never an option for Baker.   The different colors within the flag were meant to represent togetherness since the LGBTQ community embodies all races, ages, and genders, and rainbows are both natural and beautiful.   With the help of close to 30 volunteers, Baker was able to construct the first draft of the now world-renowned rainbow flag. It was first showcased at San Francisco‚Äôs Gay Freedom Day Parade on June 25, 1978.   Now there are 22 different Pride flags that represent the LGBTQ+ community. To learn more about the rainbow flag‚Äôs history, visit the link in our bio.

The 19th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution, granting American women the right to vote, was passed by Congress and sent to the states for ratification on #ThisDayInHistory in 1919.  Although the amendment was a huge step forward, it would take decades for many women of color to gain access to voting rights. The 19th Amendment was ratified in August of 1920.

In the early hours in 1968 on #ThisDayInHistory, shortly after delivering a speech to celebrate his win in the California primary, Senator Robert Kennedy was shot outside the ballroom of the Ambassador Hotel. He died the next day. To learn more about Robert Kennedy, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1953, Queen Elizabeth II was formally crowned monarch of the United Kingdom in a lavish ceremony steeped in traditions. A thousand dignitaries and guests attended the coronation at London‚Äôs Westminster Abbey, and hundreds of millions listened on the radio and for the first time watched the proceedings on live television.   To learn more about Queen Elizabeth II‚Äôs reign, visit the link in our bio.

When the nation was in trouble these powerful industry leaders put differences, rivalries and egos aside to do their part to help end the war. The story continues tonight on part 2 of #TitansThatBuiltAmerica 9/8c

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1777, the Continental Congress adopted the ‚ÄúStars and Stripes‚Äù as the national flag. The flag was based on the ‚ÄúGrand Union‚Äù flag, a banner carried by the Continental Army in 1776 that also consisted of 13 red and white stripes. #FlagDay

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1944, Allied forces landed on the beaches of Normandy, France, in one of the largest amphibious military invasions in history. More than 156,000 troops stormed 50 miles of Normandy's fiercely defended beaches in an operation that proved to be a critical turning point in WWII.

#DidYouKnow the first documented U.S. gay rights organization was founded in Chicago in 1924? The movement for LGBTQ+ rights in the United States has seen some huge progress in the last century and especially the last two decades. But it has been a long road for LGBTQ+ people to achieve equality, and these efforts continue.  We celebrate the LGBTQ+ community and kick off this month with #Pride.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1812, the day after the Senate followed the House of Representatives in voting to declare war against Great Britain, President James Madison signed the declaration into law ‚Äì and the War of 1812 begins. The picture above depicts the Battle of Lake Erie, which took place over a year into the war. The battle resulted in the first unqualified defeat of a British naval squadron in history, which forced the British to abandon the city of Detroit.

On an afternoon in the spring in 1966, three men set out to disrupt the political and social climate of New York City. The men entered Julius‚Äô, a cozy tavern with a bar opposite a small grill and an isolated space in the back. They approached the bartender, proclaimed they were gay and then requested a drink ‚Äì and were promptly denied service. The trio had accomplished their goal; their ‚ÄúSip-In‚Äù had begun. The men, who were part of the Mattachine Society ‚Äì an early organization dedicated to fighting for gay rights --- wanted to demonstrate that bars in the city discriminated against LGBTQ people. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1929, Anne Frank was born in Germany. Just 13 years later, she received a diary that would later be published by her father in 1947.

A sneak peek at tonight's premiere episode of #TitansThatBuiltAmerica, part of our epic 3-night miniseries event. Filled with competitive rivalries and historic backgrounds, you're not going to want to miss the story of how these titans of industry made it to the top. Tonight at 9/8c

100 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, thousands of white citizens in Tulsa, Oklahoma, descended on the city‚Äôs predominantly Black Greenwood District, burning homes and businesses to the ground and killing hundreds of people. Long mischaracterized as a race riot, rather than a mass murder, the Tulsa Race Massacre, stands as one of the worst incidents of racial violence in the nation‚Äôs history.
Today, we honor and remember the U.S. military men and women who gave their lives in service. #MemorialDay

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge over the East River opened, connecting the great cities of New York and Brooklyn for the first time in history. Designed by the late John A. Roebling, the bridge was the largest suspension bridge ever built to that date.

The historic Vernon African Methodist Episcopal Church was a refuge during the Tulsa Race Massacre. Today, it holds an important legacy that must be protected and preserved. Through the Save Our History initiative, we are helping accomplish this. Learn about the Tulsa Race Massacre on Sunday at 8/7c on The HISTORY Channel. #RememberTulsa

John F. Kennedy was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1917 in Brookline, Massachusetts. President Kennedy was the youngest person ever elected to the presidency. His youth, intelligence and worldliness ‚Äì along with his beautiful, stylish and much-admired wife ‚Äì charmed Americans and Europeans alike. After JFK‚Äôs 1963 assassination, the American public increasingly saw the Kennedy family as a kind of American royalty and the press portrayed Kennedy‚Äôs administration as a sort of modern-day Camelot, with the president himself as King Arthur presiding over an ideal society.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1927, Charles Lindbergh became the first pilot to accomplish a solo, nonstop flight across the Atlantic. Five years to the day, in 1932, Amelia Earhart became the first woman to repeat the feat.

After nearly two years of construction, Walter Chrysler commissioned the tallest building in the world, but that title was swiftly taken away after only 11 months of being on top. Which building took the title in such a short time, and why?

The History Channel‚Äôs latest epic 3-night miniseries event #TitansThatBuiltAmerica is here! Witness the story of how these iconic brands that we know, and still use today, rose to the top. Take an inside look at the history behind some of the world‚Äôs greatest innovators such as Boeing, Ford, DuPont, and Chrysler coming this Memorial Day.

The Hoover Dam is in the Black Canyon of the Colorado River, on the border between Nevada and Arizona. It was constructed between 1931 and 1936 during the Great Depression and was dedicated on September 30, 1935, by President Franklin D. Roosevelt. One of the key builders and innovators of this massive project was Henry J. Kaiser who later went on to build war ships during WWII. Dig deeper into the history of American structures, brands and figures who helped build this nation on #TitansThatBuiltAmerica this Monday at 9/8c.

‚ÄúAs far as I‚Äôm concerned, I was born here, and according to the Constitution that I studied in school, that I had a Bill of Rights that should have backed me up. And until the very minute I got onto the evacuation train, I says, ‚ÄòIt can‚Äôt be‚Äô. I says, ‚ÄòHow can they do that to an American citizen‚Äô.‚Äù ‚Äì Robert Kashiwagi, survivor of the Japanese Internment Camps   After the bombing of Pearl Harbor on December 7, 1941, the lives of Japanese Americans would change forever. On February 19, 1942 President Franklin D. Roosevelt would authorize the evacuation of over 110,000 people of Japanese descent along the Pacific Coast and incarcerate them in relocation camps.    Read the internment camp survivors‚Äô experiences in their own words. Visit the link in our bio.

Legendary singer, actor and show-business icon Frank Sinatra died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1998. Sinatra emerged from an Italian-American family to become the first modern superstar of popular music, with an entertainment career that spanned more than five decades.

In 1869 on #ThisDayInHistory, the transcontinental railroad was completed. No longer would western-bound travelers need to take the long and dangerous journey by wagon train. Despite the 15,000 to 20,000 Chinese immigrant workers‚Äô contributions to building America‚Äôs historic infrastructure project, their history is often forgotten. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

40 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, Bob Marley died. During his lifetime, Marley was a pioneer of the reggae genre, becoming a global ambassador of Jamaican music and culture. After his death, Marley‚Äôs greatest hits album sold more than 20 million copies.

The Greenwood district of Tulsa was one of the most prosperous African American communities in the United States, until the evening of May 31, 1921. More than 35 city blocks were burned and hundreds of Black city dwellers were killed. Tulsa Burning: The 1921 Race Massacre takes an in-depth look at the tragic events of a century ago.  #RememberTulsa

Women and men began surfing in Hawaii and other Polynesian islands for centuries. But the arrival of American missionaries in the 19th century disrupted the mixed-gender sport.   Near the turn of the 20th century, surfing experienced a revival. Modern sports writers often focused on men who contributed to the revival, but Princess Ka‚Äôiulani also helped revive the sport. Surfing continued to spread around the globe into the 1950s where Gidget and Moondoggie finally hit the beach.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1980, Mount St. Helens suffered a massive avalanche and eruption after an earthquake of about 5.0 magnitude shook southwestern Washington. The volcano erupted explosively five more times during the summer and fall of 1980 and remains active today.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1943, the Warsaw Ghetto uprising came to an end as Nazi soldiers gained control of Warsaw‚Äôs Jewish ghetto, blowing up the last remaining synagogue and beginning the mass deportation of the ghetto‚Äôs remaining dwellers to the Majdanek and Treblinka extermination camp.

‚ÄúIf we want to understand the Black experience of the race massacre, we have to start and end with how Black survivors narrated the terror of what occurred.‚Äù ‚Äì Scott Ellsworth, Historian. Hear the stories of survivors in the upcoming documentary, Tulsa Burning: The 1921 Race Massacre, premiering Sunday, May 30 at 8pm. #RememberTulsa

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1954, the U.S. Supreme Court handed down a unanimous decision in Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka ruling that racial segregation in public educational facilities is unconstitutional. Brown v. Board of Ed served to greatly motivate the civil rights movement of the 1950s and 1960s and ultimately led to the abolishment of racial segregation in all public facilities and accommodations.
Today is International Nurses Day. Thank you to all the healthcare workers who have helped us through every moment in history.

Both Great Britain and the United States celebrated Victory in Europe Day on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Cities in both nations, as well as formally occupied cities in Western Europe, put out flags and banners, rejoicing in the defeat of the Nazi war machine during World War II.

Soaking up those last few weeks of summer ‚òÄÔ∏è   #DidYouKnow bikinis didn't become popular in America until the mid-twentieth century. Learn more about how society made the shift from the beach style seen here in 1901 to the summer looks of today.

Nevado del Ruiz, the highest active volcano in the Andes Mountains of Colombia, suffered a mild but deadly eruption on #ThisDayInHistory in 1985. Flowing mixtures of water, ice, pumice, and other rock debris poured off the summit and sides of the volcano, forming ‚Äúlahars‚Äù that flooded into the river valleys surrounding Ruiz. Within four hours of the eruption, the lahars traveled over 60 miles, killing more than 23,000 people, injuring over 5,000 and destroying more than 5,000 homes. The volcano first began showing signs of an imminent eruption a full year before. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory at the 1936 Berlin Olympics, African American track star Jesse Owens won his fourth gold medal of the games in the 4x100-meter relay. He became the first American of any race to win four gold medals in track and field in a single Olympics, an achievement that stood unaccompanied until Carl Lewis matched him in 1984.

#DidYouKnow the perfect lawn was a symbol of the American Dream?   Europe‚Äôs historical development of lawns had largely expressed the values of elitism and power: Some medieval castle dwellers needed their tall grass hand-cut by cutters to see approaching enemies. And wealthy people with leisure time tamed nature into neatly trimmed surfaces for sporting endeavors like golf, tennis, and lawn bowling. And while early American landowners had appropriated some of those values, by the mid 20th century, the nation had grown its own, less elitist image of the lawn.   How did the perfect lawn become a symbol of the American dream? Visit the link in our bio.

Born in the Philippines, Larry Itliong immigrated to the U.S. in 1929 and began working as a laborer. By 1930, he joined striking lettuce pickers in Washington. He became a labor organizer and eventually a union leader ‚Äì including forming the Filipino Farm Labor Union in 1956.   In 1965, Itliong helped organize the Delano Grape Strike. Dolores Huerta and Cesar Chavez from National Farm Workers Association joined Itliong and the Filipino Farm Labor Union, and the two groups combined to form the United Farm Workers. The strike ended in 1970, having made major strides for agricultural workers.   From workers‚Äô rights to medical breakthroughs, Asian American innovators have made major contributions to American society. To read more of these groundbreaking contributions, visit the link in our bio.

From Kansas to Michigan, General Motors to Dodge bros., cars to skyscrapers and everything in between. Get an in depth look at the life of Walter Chrysler and many other titans of industry on The History Channel's #TitansThatBuiltAmerica premiering this Memorial Day

President Obama early on in his first term decided that he wanted to bring Osama bin Laden to justice and the mission was accomplished 10 years ago in 2011. See the events unfold in the new documentary Revealed: The Hunt for Bin Laden, airing tonight at 8/7c. #TheHuntForBinLaden

Henry and Edsel Ford were not only innovators in the automobile industry but had their hands in the aviation business as well. #DidYouKnow that the first U.S. commercial air mail flight route was from Detroit to Cleveland? Discover more about America's biggest entrepreneurs on The @HISTORY Channel's #TitansThatBuiltAmerica premiering this Memorial Day.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1916, Ferruccio Lamborghini, the founder of the company that bears his name, was born in Italy. After World War II, Lamborghini founded a business making tractors from reconfigured surplus military machines. He later expanded into other ventures, including manufacturing air-conditioning and heating systems. His success enabled him to purchase a variety of luxury sports cars, including a Ferrari, considered one of the top cars at the time. After he experienced mechanical difficulties with his Ferrari, he decided to start his own rival sports car company.  To learn more about Ferruccio Lamborghini, visit the link in our bio.

During Napoleon Bonaparte‚Äôs Egyptian campaign, a French soldier discovered a black basalt slab inscribed with ancient writing near the town of Rosetta on #ThisDayInHistory in 1799. The irregularly shaped stone contained fragments of passages writing in three different scripts: Greek, Egyptian hieroglyphics and Egyptian demotic. The ancient Greek on the Rosetta Stone told archaeologists that it was inscribed by priests honoring the king of Egypt, Ptolemy V, in the second century B.C. More startlingly, the Greek passage announced that the three scripts were all of identical meaning. The artifact thus held the key to solving the riddle of hieroglyphics, a written language that had been ‚Äúdead‚Äù for nearly 2,000 years. Visit the link in our bio to listen to the story on HISTORY This Week.

In 1900, at a time when the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882 banned most Chinese immigrants, 9-year-old Mabel Ping-Hua Lee came to America from China on a scholarship to attend school. At 16, she would cement her place in women‚Äôs suffrage history, helping to lead a storied New York City march. But while she fought for women‚Äôs voting rights, she herself would not be eligible to cast a ballot for decades after the 19th Amendment was ratified. Still, Lee continued to fight ‚Äì not only for suffrage but for education and equality ‚Äì for women on both sides of the world, while working locally to raise up her own Chinatown community. To learn more about Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, visit the link in our bio.

The U.S. Seventh Army‚Äôs 45th Infantry Division liberated Dachau on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Dachau was the first concentration camp established by Germany‚Äôs Nazi regime and one of the first to use prisoners as human guinea pigs in medical experiments.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1994, Norway‚Äôs most famous painting, ‚ÄúThe Scream‚Äù by Edvard Munch, was recovered almost three months after it was stolen from a museum in Oslo.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1929, actress and humanitarian Audrey Hepburn, was born in Belgium. She is one of the few people to win an Emmy, Grammy, Academy Award and Tony. To learn more about Audrey Hepburn, visit the link in our bio.

Tulsa‚Äôs Black district, Greenwood thrived as the epicenter of African American business and culture for the early part of the 20th century. Greenwood Avenue, commonly known as Black Wall Street featured thriving Black-owned shops, restaurants, movie theaters and other small businesses, as well as schools, a hospital and a library.    On May 31, 1921, the Greenwood district was attacked by a white mob, resulting in two days of bloodshed and destruction. The massacre left hundreds of Black residents dead and 1,000 houses destroyed. The Greenwood District still exists today but after decades of urban renewal and integration, the area‚Äôs demographics and businesses resemble little of its storied past.    Tulsa Burning: The 1921 Race Massacre premieres Sunday, May 30 at 8pm. #RememberTulsa

On #ThisDayInHistory in 2011, Osama bin Laden was killed at his compound in Pakistan. Hear about the intense moments leading up to the raid on his hideout and hear the story of the iconic photographs that captured this chapter in history by @petesouza

‚ÄúOne of the greatest things in life is that no one has the authority to tell you what you want to be. You're the one who'll decide what you want to be.‚Äù‚Äì Jaime Escalante, a Bolivian-American educator known for teaching students calculus from 1974 to 1991 at Garfield High School in East Los Angeles. Teachers are arguably some of the most important members of our society and contribute to shaping the world around us. #NationalTeacherAppreciationWeek

In what came to be known as ‚ÄúBlack Sunday,‚Äù one of the most devastating storms of the 1930s Dust Bowl era swept across the region on #ThisDayInHistory in 1935. High winds kicked up clouds of millions of tons of dirt and dust so dense and dark that some eyewitnesses believed the world was coming to an end.

At 2:20 am on #ThisDayInHistory in 1912, the Titanic sunk into the North Atlantic Ocean about 400 miles south of Newfoundland, Canada after sideswiping an iceberg during its maiden voyage. Of the 2,240 passengers and crew on board, more than 1,500 lost their lives in the disaster.

Jackie Robinson became the first African American player in Major League Baseball to compete for the Brooklyn Dodgers on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. Robinson broke the color barrier in a sport that had been segregated for more than 50 years.

President Harry S. Truman officially opened the first White House bowling alley on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. The two-lane bowling alley, situated in the West Wing, had been constructed earlier that year. Truman did not use the alley much himself but supported a group of White House employees in forming a White House Bowling League in 1950. Eisenhower closed the alley in 1955 and turned it into a mimeograph room. Later, another alley was opened next door in the Old Executive Office Building.
For his leadership during Britain‚Äôs darkest hours, prime minister Winston Churchill was knighted by Queen Elizabeth II on #ThisDayInHistory in 1953.

The Tulsa Race Massacre was one of the worst acts of racial violence in American history.  Tulsa Burning: The 1921 Race Massacre takes an in-depth sobering look at the tragic events. From the birth of Black Wall Street to its downfall. The two-hour documentary premieres Sunday, May 30 at 8pm. #RememberTulsa

Ulysses S. Grant, Civil War leader and 18th president, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1822. A primary focus of his administration was Reconstruction, and he worked to reconcile the North and South while also attempting to protect the civil rights of newly freed Black citizens.   To learn more about Grant, visit the link in our bio.

Emiliano Zapata, a leader of peasants and indigenous people during the Mexican Revolution, was ambushed and shot by government forces on #ThisDayInHistory in 1919. Zapata‚Äôs influences have endured long after his death and his agrarian reform movement, Zapatismo, remains important to many Mexicans today.   To learn more about Emiliano Zapata, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1968, just after 6 pm, Martin Luther King, Jr. was fatally shot while standing on the balcony outside his room at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tenn.  Just one year prior in 1967, he delivered a speech entitled ‚ÄúBeyond Vietnam‚Äù in front of 3,000 people in New York City. In it, he said there is a common link forming between the civil rights and peace movements and called for an end to the Vietnam War.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Sir Winston Churchill retired as Prime Minister of Great Britain on #ThisDayInHistory in 1955. He was one of the best-known statesmen of the 20th century and a defender of democracy ‚Äì especially during World War II.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1865, John Wilkes Booth was killed when  Union soldiers tracked him down 12 days after he assassinated President Lincoln.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Historians believe William Shakespeare was likely born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1564, the same day he died in 1616. Considered by many to be the greatest Western playwright of all time, he has remained an elusive figure leaving behind no letters, no manuscripts, and only six signatures, all spelled differently.

Margaret Thatcher, the first female prime minister of the United Kingdom, died at the age of 87 on #ThisDayInHistory in 2013. She was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century. She curbed the power of Britain‚Äôs labor unions, privatized state-owned industries, led her nation to victory in the Falklands War and as a close ally of U.S. President Ronald Reagan, she played a pivotal role in ending the Cold War.   To learn more about Margaret Thatcher, visit the link in our bio

Did you know that in the 1940s and 1950s, Chinese-born physicist Chien-Shiung Wu, Ph.D., was instrumental in the developing field of atomic science? And Chinese-American architect, I.M. Pei, designed many iconic buildings including the pyramid a the Louvre? Ever use a USB? You have Indian American computer architect Ajay Bhatt to thank for its invention. We celebrate the amazing achievements the AAPI community has contributed to history and will continue to shine a spotlight on their contributions to the world. #AAPIHeritageMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1961, President John F. Kennedy sent a letter to Congress recommending the U.S. participates in an international campaign to preserve ancient temples and historic monuments in the Nile Valley of Egypt. The campaign, initiated by UNESCO, was designed to save sites threatened by the construction of the Aswan High Dam.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

The American Third Army liberated the Buchenwald concentration camp on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. The camp held thousands of prisoners, mostly slave laborers. Hundreds, sometimes thousands, died monthly from disease, malnutrition, beatings, and executions.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1993, Ellen Ochoa became the first Hispanic woman in space when the ‚ÄúSpace Shuttle Discovery‚Äù lifted off from the Kennedy Space Center. She is a veteran of four space flights, logging a total of more than 40 days in space.   To learn more about Ellen Ochoa, visit the link in our bio.

Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, the husband of Queen Elizabeth II and the father of Prince Charles has passed away at the age of 99. Born on the Island of Corfu in Greece, he descended from Greek and Danish royalty. As the queen‚Äôs consort for more than six decades, he participated in the work of many organizations, particularly favoring those focused on the environment, athletics and education.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, President Franklin D. Roosevelt passed away leaving Vice President Harry Truman in charge of the country. The only American president in history to be elected four times, he led the United States through the Great Depression and World War II.
26-year-old Danica Patrick won the Indy Japan 300 at Twin Ring Motegi in Motegi, Japan, making her the first female winner in IndyCar racing history on #ThisDayInHistory in 2008.

President Abraham Lincoln was shot at Ford‚Äôs Theatre in Washington, D.C. on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865. The assassin, John Wilkes Booth, shouted, ‚ÄúSic semper tyrannis! The South is avenged,‚Äù as he jumped onto the stage and fled on horseback. Lincoln died the next day.

When World War I broke out, President Wilson proclaimed that the United States would stay neutral, and many Americans supported this policy. However, public opinion changed after the sinking of the Lusitania. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1917, the United States entered World War I.   To read more about World War I, visit the link in our bio.
Happy Easter. #DidYouKnow eggs and rabbits are both ancient symbols of fertility and new life?

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1906, an earthquake estimated at close to 8.0 on the Richter scale struck San Francisco. The quake was caused by a slip of the San Andreas Fault over a segment about 274 miles long, and shock waves could be felt from southern Oregon to Los Angeles. The city‚Äôs brick buildings and wooden Victorian structures were especially devastated.

Michael Collins, a NASA astronaut and Command Modul Pilot for Apollo 11, the first lunar landing in history, has passed away at the age of 90. Inspired to become an astronaut after watching John Glenn‚Äôs Mercury-Atlas 6 flight, he made two spaceflights and later received the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1969, Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th president of the United States and one of the most highly regarded American generals of World War II, died. To read more, visit the link in our bio.

Sandra Day O‚ÄôConnor made history as the first woman justice to serve on the nation‚Äôs highest court. As a judge, she developed a solid reputation for being firm but just. #WomensHistoryMonth   To learn more about Sandra Day O'Connor, visit the link in our bio.

Today, and every day, we celebrate women who faced challenges and triumphed to change history. From activists to politicians, their stories are heroic and brave. Here is a small collection of trailblazers and the important impact they made in women‚Äôs rights advocacy.   Image 1: Women‚Äôs Suffrage March; 1913 Image 2: Sojourner Truth Image 3: Jeanette Rankin Image 4: Fannie Lou Hamer; 1968  Image 5: Eleanor Roosevelt; 1960 Image 6: Women‚Äôs Equality March and Strike; 1970

On #ThisDayInHistory in 2011, actress Elizabeth Taylor died at the age of 79. She appeared in more than 50 films, won two Academy Awards and was synonymous with Hollywood glamour. In addition to her film career, her legacy includes her work as a pioneering activist in the fight against AIDS.   To learn more about Elizabeth Taylor, visit the link in our bio

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1889, the Eiffel Tower was dedicated in Paris in a ceremony presided over Gustave Eiffel, the tower‚Äôs designer. The Eiffel Tower was greeted with skepticism from critics who argued it would be structurally unsound.   To learn more about the Eiffel Tower, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1973, two months after the signing of the Vietnam peace agreement, the last U.S. combat troops left South Vietnam as Hanoi freed the remaining American prisoners of war held in North Vietnam.

Malala Yousafzai became an advocate for girls‚Äô education when she herself was still a child. She survived an assassination attempt by the Pakistani Taliban after she defied them demanding that girls be allowed to receive an education. #WomensHistoryMonth   To learn more about Malala, visit the link in our bio.

The last major battle of World War II began on #ThisDayInHistory in 1945. Though it resulted in an Allied victory, kamikaze fighters, rainy weather and fierce fighting on land, sea and air led to a large death toll on both sides. To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Frida Kahlo is considered to be one of Mexico‚Äôs greatest artists. After Kahlo‚Äôs death, the feminist movement of the 1970s led to renewed interest in her life and work, as she was viewed by many as an icon of female creativity. #WomensHistoryMonth   To learn more about Frida Kahlo, visit the link in our bio.

Albert Einstein was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1879. After he made his name with four scientific articles published in 1905, he went on to win worldwide fame for his general theory of relativity and the Nobel Prize in Physics for his explanation of the photoelectric effect in 1921.
In the name of Black voting rights, 3,200 civil rights demonstrators in Alabama, led by Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., began a historic march from Selma to Montgomery on #ThisDayInHistory in 1965.

President Lincoln met with Union generals Ulysses S. Grant and William T. Sherman to plot the last stages of the Civil War on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

Ruth Bader Ginsburg was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1933. She made history as the second female justice in the U.S. Supreme Court. As a lifelong advocate for gender equality, she was known for her impactful positions on many landmark cases in the court. #WomensHistoryMonth #RBG

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1888, one of the worst blizzards in American history hit the Northeast, dumping as much as 55 inches of snow in some areas. In the wake of the storm, officials realized the dangers of above-ground telegraph, water and gas lines and moved them below ground.

According to tradition, St. Patrick, the patron saint of Ireland, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 461 A.D., in Saul, Downpatrick, Ireland where he had built his first church. But for all of his prevalence in culture ‚Äì namely the holiday ‚Äì his life remains somewhat of a mystery. #StPatricksDay
Clara Barton‚Äôs life was dedicated to the care of others. She founded the American Red Cross and is one of the most recognized heroes of the American Civil War.

#DidYouKnow 1975 was recognized as International Women‚Äôs Year? That year, the United Nations General Assembly began celebrating March 8th as International Women‚Äôs Day. By 2014, it was celebrated in more than 100 countries and had been made an official holiday in more than 25. #InternationalWomensDay

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1876, Alexander Graham Bell received a patent for his revolutionary new invention ‚Äì the telephone. Three days later, Bell successfully tested his telephone for the first time in his Boston home.

Ella Fitzgerald, the ‚ÄúFirst Lady of Song‚Äù, made history as the first African American woman to win a Grammy Award. Discovered in an amateur contest, she went on to become the top female jazz singer for decades. #WomensHistoryMonth

As Black History Month draws to an end, this gallery of images helps illuminate some of the key people and turning points that have shaped Black history and our collective past. #blackhistorymonth Image 1: March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, 1963 Image 2: Emily Taft Douglas & Martin Luther King, Jr., 1965 Image 3: Freedom Riders, 1961 Image 4: Civil Rights Demonstration in Maryland, 1963 Image 5: Jesse Owens at the Berlin Olympic Games, 1936 Image 6: Fannie Lou Hamer at DNC, 1964

Amelia Earhart was a pioneering aviator who set many flying records and championed the advancement of women in aviation. She became the first woman to fly solo nonstop across the Atlantic Ocean in  1932 and the first person to fly solo from Hawaii to the U.S. mainland. #WomensHistoryMonth

Women‚Äôs History Month is a dedicated month to reflect on the often-overlooked contributions of women to United States history. To kick off this celebratory month, we want to ask all the trailblazers out there, ‚Äúhow will you create change?‚Äù #WomensHistoryMonth #ChangeHistory

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1964, a young Cassius Clay dethroned the world heavyweight boxing champ, Sonny Liston, in a seventh-round technical knockout. The fleet-footed youngster later became known as Muhammad Ali.

Junko Tabei was the first woman to reach the summit of Mount Everest and climb the Seven Summits. During her climb to the top of Everest, her expedition team was buried under an avalanche. After recovering, Tabei was determined to reach the summit. She left behind a legacy of incredible achievements and determination. #WomensHistoryMonth

For generations, Asian Americans have helped protect our nation by serving in uniform and have contributed in vital ways to American society. The recent increase in violence, racism and xenophobia against Asians, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in the U.S. is alarming. This kind of hatred should have no home here. Let's stand up for those who have stood for us. #StopAsianHate #StopAAPIHate

These women are just a few of many history-making Black women who have made an impact and influenced change in the United States. From civil rights activists to sports and science, these women are examples of Black excellence in action. #BlackHistoryMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1952, King George VI ‚Äúof Great Britain, Ireland and the British Dominions beyond the seas‚Äù died. He was an important symbolic leader for the British people during World War II. His daughter, Queen Elizabeth II, succeeded the throne.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1986, Georgia O‚ÄôKeeffe, considered ‚Äúthe mother of American modernism,‚Äù died at the age of 98. She gained worldwide fame for her austere minimalist paintings of the American Southwest.

Thurgood Marshall ‚Äîthe first African American Supreme Court justice ‚Äî played an instrumental role in promoting racial equality during the civil rights movement. During his 24-year term as a Supreme Court justice, Marshall‚Äôs support for civil rights was reflected in his decisions.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1990, Nelson Mandela was released from prison after 27 years. While in prison, Mandela remained the symbolic leader of the South African‚Äôs anti-apartheid movement.

Greta Thunberg, a Swedish youth activist, received worldwide recognition for her efforts to fight climate change. Her actions have spread and influenced millions of young people around the world to organize and protest climate change. #WomensHistoryMonth   To learn more about Greta Thunberg, visit the link in our bio.
You just had to be there.

In the earliest decades of the United States, candy was quickly recognized not just as a sweet treat, but as a valuable way to fuel troops. During the Revolutionary War, chocolate, a favorite treat of George Washington, became part of his soldier‚Äôs rations. Find out more about chocolate Sunday on #TheFoodThatBuiltAmerica on The @History Channel at 9/8c

Harriet Tubman was an escaped enslaved woman who became a ‚Äúconductor‚Äù on the Underground Railroad, leading enslaved people to freedom before the Civil War. She was also a nurse, a Union spy and a women‚Äôs suffrage supporter. She is one of the most recognized icons in American history.

The Tuskegee Airmen's bravery, courage, and impressive performance helped encourage the eventual integration of the U.S. armed forces. Don't miss their stories on the premiere of Tuskegee Airmen: Legacy of Courage tonight at 8/7c.#TuskegeeAirmen

Future President Franklin Delano Roosevelt was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1882. He served an unprecedented four terms in office leading the nation through the Great Depression and World War II, and greatly expanded the powers of the federal government with the New Deal.

All of us at A+E Networks mourn the loss of Roger Mudd.  Roger was our first on-air anchor in the early days of The HISTORY Channel. We will be forever grateful for his leadership and enormous contributions which helped build The HISTORY Channel brand.  He had a remarkable, award-winning career in television and we are very proud to be a part of his legacy.  Our deepest sympathies are with his family.

American musician, Nat King Cole, died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1965. He first came to prominence as a jazz pianist but owes most of his popular musical fame to his soft baritone voice, which he used to perform in the big band and jazz genres. #BlackHistoryMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1870, the 15th Amendment was ratified, granting African American men the right to vote. Yet discriminatory practices continued to be used to prevent Black men from voting, and full voting rights continued to be a main goal of the Civil Rights Movement through the 1960s. #BlackHistoryMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1971, Apollo 14, piloted by astronauts Alan B. Shepard Jr., Edgar D. Mitchell, and Stuart A. Roosa, was successfully launched from Cape Canaveral, FL., on a manned mission to the moon. On February 5, Shepard and Mitchell descended to the lunar surface.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1913, Rosa Parks was born in Tuskegee, Alabama. Parks became a nationally recognized symbol of dignity and strength in the struggle to end racial segregation.
Tennis champion Arthur Ashe died from complications from AIDS on #ThisDayInHistory in 1993. He was the only Black man to win Wimbledon and the U.S. and Australian opens. #BlackHistoryMonth

Robin Roberts' father was a Tuskegee Airmen, a man whose impact shaped Black history. In 1967, Kathrine Switzer became the first woman to run the Boston Marathon as a registered runner. At the time, it was considered a men‚Äôs only race and Kathrine was physically attacked while running. After completing the marathon, she went on to create more opportunities for women in running and sports. #WomensHistoryMonth

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1765, the British government passed the Stamp Act. The legislation levied a direct tax on all materials printed for commercial and legal use in the colonies, from newspapers and pamphlets to playing cards and dice.
Larry King, a broadcasting legend, has died at the age of 87. Over his 65 years in media, King earned a number of prestigious awards and conducted countless memorable interviews.

Hank Aaron, one of baseball‚Äôs greatest stars, has passed away at the age of 86. With 755 home runs, he was a legend and pioneer of the game. Aaron was a 25-time All-Star, World Series champion, and is a member of the Baseball Hall of Fame.

On #ThisDayInHistory President Joe Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris are joined by former Presidents Barack Obama, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton for the wreath-laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1945, Soviet troops entered Auschwitz, freeing the survivors of the concentration camps and finally revealing to the world the depth of the horrors perpetrated there. #HolocaustRemembranceDay #NeverForget

At 11:38 am on #ThisDayInHistory in 1986, the Space Shuttle Challenger lifted off from Cape Canaveral, FL. Seventy-three seconds later, the shuttle broke up in a forking plume of smoke and fire. There were no survivors.
These pups have made history. #NationalPuppyDay

The first Winter Olympics take off in style at Chamonix in the French Alps on #ThisDayInHistory in 1924. With a total of six events, the ‚ÄúInternational Winter Sports Week,‚Äù as it was known, was a great success.

#DidYouKnow the lawnmower was first patented in 1830 by Englishmen Edwin Beard Budding. The mower's design was to primarily cut grass on sports grounds and gardens. In the last 191 years, the lawnmower has advanced from being drawn by animals to gasoline-powered.   The advancement of the lawnmower continues on Assembly Required - premiering Tuesday, February 23 at 10/9c.
Queen Victoria died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1901. In her 63-year reign, she restored dignity to the English monarchy and ensured its survival as a ceremonial political institution.

King George III died on #ThisDayInHistory in 1820. During his 59-year reign, he pushed through a British victory in the Seven Years‚Äô War, led England‚Äôs successful resistance to the Revolutionary and Napoleonic France, and presided over the loss of the American Revolution.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1924, British archaeologist Howard Carter and his workmen uncovered one of the greatest treasures ‚Äì a stone sarcophagus containing a solid gold coffin that held the mummy of Tutankhamen.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1954, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe married New York Yankees slugger Joe DiMaggio at the San Francisco City Hall. The couple divorced in October 1954, just 286 days after they were married.

Louis Braille, the man who developed a raised-dot code that enabled blind people to read and write, was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1809. Although his system was in limited use during his lifetime, it has since been accepted globally.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1932, Hattie Wyatt Caraway, a Democrat from Arkansas, became the first woman to be elected to the U.S. Senate. Later that year, Caraway was elected for a full six-year term with the support of powerful Louisiana senator, Huey Long. And in 1938, she was reelected. Although she was the first freely elected female senator, Caraway was preceded in the Senate by Rebecca Latimer Felton of Georgia, who was appointed in 1922 to fill a vacancy but never ran for election and only served a single day in office.

Hedy Lamarr, dubbed one of the most gorgeous women in Hollywood, earned recognition in a field quite different from entertainment. She co-invented an early technique for spread spectrum communications. Lamarr died on #ThisDayInHistory in 2000.

#DidYouKnow that Americans eat an average of 100 acres of pizza a day? That‚Äôs nearly 3 billion pies a year. But pizza wasn‚Äôt always the staple it is now. Martin Luther King, Jr. was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1929 in Atlanta, Georgia. King received a doctorate degree in theology and in 1955 helped organize the first major protest of the American civil rights movement. However, there have also been gracious moments ‚Äì including a letter written to President Eisenhower from President Kennedy on his first day in office thanking him for his guidance and support.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1923, President Calvin Coolidge lit up the first national Christmas tree to grace the White House grounds. The tree was erected in conjunction with D.C.‚Äôs public schools, with electric lights added by an electrical industry trade group.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1956, a baby gorilla named Colo entered the world at the Columbus Zoo in Ohio, becoming the first-ever gorilla born in captivity.  To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.
On #ThisDayInHistory in 1890, in the final chapter of America‚Äôs long Indian wars, the U.S. Cavalry killed as many as 300 Sioux at Wounded Knee on the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota.

Since the inauguration of George Washington, many traditions around presidential inaugurations have remained the same, even as the nation has transformed and changed throughout the decades.   On #ThisDayInHistory, Joe Biden and Kamala Harris are sworn into office to become President and Vice President of the United States. Kamala Harris makes history today as the first woman and first Black and South Asian American to serve as U.S. Vice President.

Today is New Year‚Äôs Eve üéá. At midnight, the year 2020 will become history. Do you know the history of New Year's Eve in Times Square in NYC?   The world-famous celebrations dates back to 1904, when the New York Times newspaper relocated to what was then known as Longacre Square and convinced the city to rename the neighborhood in its honor. At the end of the year, the publication‚Äôs owner threw a raucous party with an elaborate firework displace. When the city banned fireworks in 1907, an electrician devised a wood-and-iron ball that weighed 700 pounds, was illuminated with 100 light bulbs and was dropped from a flagpole at midnight on New Year‚Äôs Eve.
Joan of Arc was born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1412. She lived only 19 years, but she would become a national hero of France and a Roman Catholic saint for her pivotal role in the Hundred Years‚Äô War.

On This Day in History in 1863, President Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation. The proclamation declared ‚Äúthat all persons held as slaves‚Äù within the rebellious areas ‚Äúare, and henceforward shall be free.‚Äù A critical turning point in the American Civil War, the Emancipation Proclamation turned the tide of the war as a fight for freedom and helped pave the way for the end of slavery in the United States.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1933, the dream of permanently connecting San Francisco to its northern neighbors became a reality when construction on the Golden Gate Bridge began. With its tall towers and famous trademarked ‚Äúinternational orange‚Äù paint job, the bridge quickly became a famous American landmark and a symbol of San Francisco, the 1.7-mile-long bridge.  construction on the Golden Gate Bridge began.

Grigory Efimovich Rasputin, a self-proclaimed holy man, was murdered on #ThisDayInHistory in 1916 by Russian nobles eager to end his influence over the royal family. To learn more about who Rasputin was, visit the link in our bio.

Tommy Lasorda, Hall of Fame manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers, has passed away at the age of 93. He led the Dodgers to two World Series championships and four pennants during his career. Lasorda‚Äôs lasting legacy will be one of charisma, passion, and success.
Charlie Chaplin, born on #ThisDayInHistory in 1889, became one of the most financially successful stars of early Hollywood.

Chuck Yeager, the aviation trailblazer, passed away at the age of 97. After serving as an ace fighter pilot during WWII, he made history in 1947 as the first person to break the sound barrier.

In the aftermath of the Civil War, the 13th Amendment to the U.S. Constitution was ratified on #ThisDayInHistory in 1865. This amendment officially ended the institution of slavery.   To learn more about the 13th Amendment, visit the link in our bio.

After accomplished actor John Wilkes Booth assassinated President Lincoln at Ford‚Äôs Theater, he escaped with the help of a network of Confederate sympathizers. Booth‚Äôs descendants, however, have alleged that he survived the manhunt and even went on to father children after his death was reported by authorities. From the tip of South America to the Arctic, Native Americans developed scores of innovations including kayaks, snow goggles, hammocks and cable suspension bridges. These inventions enabled them to survive and flourish wherever they lived.

In 1735 on #ThisDayInHistory, John Adams, the son of a farmer and a descendant of Mayflower pilgrims, was born. He enrolled at Harvard University at 16 and went on to teach school and study law before becoming America‚Äôs second president in 1797.   Adams did not fight in the Revolutionary War but was instrumental in crafting the foundations of the American government. In 1776, he anonymously published ‚ÄúThoughts on Government,‚Äù which proposed the three-branched system upon which the United States government is modeled.  Intelligent, patriotic, opinionated, and blunt, Adams became a critic of Great Britain‚Äôs authority in colonial America and viewed the British imposition of high taxes and tariffs as a tool of oppression. During the 1770s, he was a delegate to the Continental Congress. In the 1780s, Adams served as the diplomat in Europe and helped negotiate the Treaty of Paris which officially ended the American Revolutionary War. From 1789 to 1797, he was America‚Äôs first vice president, then he served a term as the nation's second president. His letters to his wife, Abigail, left behind a vivid portrait of his time among the Founding Fathers.   To learn more about John Adams, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1974, 32-year-old Muhammad Ali became the heavyweight champion of the world for the second time when he knocked out 25-year-old champ, George Foreman in the eighth round of the ‚ÄúRumble in the Jungle,‚Äù a match in Kinshasa, Zaire now the Democratic Republic of the Congo). Seven years before, Ali had lost his title when the government accused him of draft-dodging and the boxing commission took away his license.   The ‚ÄúRumble in the Jungle‚Äù was Africa‚Äôs first world heavyweight championship match. The government of the Central African nation staged the event - its president, Mobutu Sese Seko, personally paid each of the fighters $5 million simply for showing up. At 4:30am, 60,000 spectators gathered in the moonlight at the outdoor Stade du 20 Mai to watch the fight. They were chanting ‚ÄúAli, bomaye‚Äù (‚ÄúAli, kill him‚Äù) in the Lingala language. When the fighters entered the ring, Foreman possessed the heavyweight title, but Ali owned the hearts of the crowd. By the eighth round, the referee counted Foreman out and declared Ali the champion by knockout. Ali had become only the second heavyweight in history, behind Floyd Patterson, to regain his championship belt.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1872, 47 years before the 19th Amendment, Susan B. Anthony voted in a presidential election. This led to her arrest and trial in which she was fined $100.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1929, Black Tuesday hit Wall Street as investors traded some 16 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange in a single day. Billions of dollars were lost, wiping out thousands of investors, and stock tickers ran hours behind because the machinery could not handle the tremendous volume of trading. During the succeeding weeks, stock prices had nowhere to go but up, so there was considerable recovery.   In the aftermath of Black Tuesday, America and the rest of the industrialized world spiraled downward into the Great Depression. The stock market crash of 1929 was not the sole cause of the Great Depression, but it did accelerate the global economic collapse of which it was a symptom. By 1933, nearly half of America‚Äôs banks had failed, unemployment was approaching 15 million people or 25% of the workforce. It would take World War II, and the massive level of armaments production taken on by the United States to finally bring the country out of the Depression after a decade of suffering.   What were the warning signs? Visit the link in our bio.

In Washington, D.C. nearly 100,000 people gathered to protest the American war effort in Vietnam on #ThisDayInHistory in 1967. Around 30,000 of the protestors marched to the Pentagon to ask for an end to the conflict. The protest was the most dramatic sign of waning U.S. support for President Lyndon Johnson‚Äôs war in Vietnam. Polls taken in the summer of 1967 revealed that American support for the war had fallen below 50%.   The peace movement began to push harder for an end to the war - the march on Washington was the most powerful sign of their commitment to the cause. The protest was also important in suggesting that the domestic Cold War consensus was beginning to fracture. Many of the protestors were not simply questioning America‚Äôs conduct in Vietnam, but the very basis of the nation‚Äôs Cold War foreign policy.   To learn more about the protests against the Vietnam War, visit the link in our bio.

The USA PATRIOT Act, as it is officially known, is an acronym for ‚ÄúUniting and Strengthening America by Providing Appropriate Tools Required to Intercept and Obstruct Terrorism.‚Äù Bush hoped the bipartisan legislation would empower law enforcement and intelligence agencies to prevent future terrorist attacks on American soil.  Though the Patriot Act was modified in 2015 to help ensure the Constitutional rights of ordinary Americans, some provisions of the law remain controversial. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1931, gangster Al Capone is sentenced to 11 years in prison for tax evasion and fined $80,000, signaling the downfall of one of the most notorious criminals of the 1920s and 1930s.   Alphonse Gabriel Capone was born in Brooklyn, New York, in 1899 to Italian immigrants. Capone‚Äôs adolescence was far from innocent; he was expelled from school at 14, joined a gang, and was slashed across the cheek during a fight, prompting the nickname ‚ÄúScarface‚Äù. Shortly after he moved to Chicago in 1920, Capone became an integral piece of crime boss Johnny Torrio‚Äôs illegal enterprises which included alcohol smuggling, prostitution, and gambling. In just five years, Capone became the fearless kingpin of Chicago crime after an assassination attempt left Torrio seriously wounded. Around 1930, Capone topped the F.B.I‚Äôs ‚ÄúMost Wanted‚Äù list but avoided long stints in jail until 1931. A slew of federal tax evasion charges finally caught up to him, however, Capone served less than 8 years of his 11-year sentence. In 1939, Capone was granted early release for good behavior. In 1947, Capone died at his home in Palm Island, FL at the age of 48.  To find out what contributed to his early release and how he avoided hard time, go to the link in bio.

Pablo Picasso, one of the greatest and most influential artists of the 20th century, was born in Malaga, Spain on #ThisDayInHistory in 1881. Picasso‚Äôs father was a professor of drawing and began teaching him to draw and paint when he was a child. By the time he was 13, he had his first exhibit and his skill level had surpassed his father‚Äôs.   Picasso remained renowned for endless reinventing himself, switching between styles so radically different that his life‚Äôs work seems to be the product of five or six great artists rather than just one. His work, which comprises more than 50,000 paintings, drawings, engravings, sculptures, and ceramics produced over 80 years, is described in a series of overlapping periods - the Blue Period, the Rose Period, and the Cubist movement. After Cubism, Picasso explored classical and Mediterranean themes, and images of violence and anguish increasingly appeared in his work. He continued to produce art with undiminished force until his death in 1973.   To learn more about Pablo Picasso, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1858, future President Theodore Roosevelt was born in New York City. Roosevelt was home-schooled and then attended Harvard University, graduating in 1880. He served as New York‚Äôs governor from 1899 to 1900.   Roosevelt unexpectedly became the 26th president of the United States in September 1901 after the assassination of William McKinley. Young and physically robust, he brought a new energy to the White House, and won a second term on his own merits in 1904. Roosevelt, a Republican, confronted the bitter struggle between management and labor head-on and became known as the great ‚Äútrust buster‚Äù for his strenuous efforts to break up industrial combinations using the Sherman Antitrust Act. He was also a dedicated conservationist, setting aside some 230 million acres for national forests, reserves and wildlife refuges during his presidency. In the foreign policy arena, Roosevelt won the Nobel Peace Prize for his negotiations to end the Russo-Japanese War and spearheaded the beginning of construction on the Panama Canal. After leaving the White House and going on a yearlong safari in Africa, he returned to politics in 1912, mounting a failed run for president at the head of a new Progressive Party.   To learn more about Theodore Roosevelt‚Äôs legacies, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 2005, civil rights activist Rosa Parks died at 92. Parks helped ignite the civil rights movement when she refused to give up her seat to a white man on a Montgomery, Alabama bus in 1955.   Born Rosa Louis McCauley on February 3, 1913, in Tuskegee, Alabama, her childhood brought her early experiences with racial discrimination and activism for racial inequality. Her actions on the bus inspired the leaders of the local black community to organize the Montgomery Bus Boycott that lasted more than a year. Over the next half-century, Parks became a nationally recognized symbol of dignity and strength in the struggle to end entrenched racial segregation.   To learn more about Rosa Parks and her life, visit the link in our bio.

Mata Hari, World War I‚Äôs most notorious spy, was executed for espionage on #ThisDayInHistory in 1917. In 1905, she arrived in Paris and reached stardom as an exotic dancer. While touring Europe, she claimed she was born in a sacred Indian temple. In reality, she was born in a small town in northern Holland as Margaretha Geertruida Zelle. Her deceptive persona still packed dance halls and opera houses from Russia to France.   The details of Mata Hari‚Äôs espionage career are scarce, but it seemed to have commenced in 1915 after Karl Kroemer, the honorary German consul in Amsterdam, approached her. He offered her 20,000 francs to become a spy for the Kaiser. She accepted the money but whether she participated in the espionage remains unclear. Over the next several months, Hari continued her travels in Europe and had affairs with military officers and politicians.  In February 1917, French authorities arrested her for espionage and imprisoned her in Paris. Despite a lack of evidence concerning secrets she might have revealed to the Germans, prosecutors blamed her for the deaths of thousands of Allied soldiers and pointed to her numerous affairs as proof that she had been gathering intelligence. The true extent of her espionage may never be known for certain.  To learn more about Mata Hari, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1974, German businessman Oskar Schindler, credited with saving 1,200 Jews from the Holocaust, died at age 66.   A member of the Nazi party, Schindler ran an enamel-works factory in Krakow during the German occupation of Poland, employing workers from the nearby Jewish ghetto. Initially, Schindler hired Jewish workers because they were a less expensive Polish workforce. As the Nazi atrocities against the Jewish community increased, Schindler‚Äôs attitude changed. In 1944, most of the Jews in the region were being sent to Auschwitz, but Schindler bribed officials into allowing him to keep his workers and set up a factory in a safer location in occupied Czechoslovakia. Not wanting to contribute to the German war effort, he ordered his workers to purposefully make defective products that would fail inspection. By the war‚Äôs end, he was penniless, but he had saved 1,200 Jews.   In 1962, he was declared a Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem, Israel‚Äôs official agency for remembering the Holocaust.   To learn more about Oskar Schindler, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1968, Apollo 7, the first manned Apollo mission, was launched with astronauts, Walter M. Schirra, Jr., Donn F. Eisele, and R. Walter Cunningham aboard.  Under the command of Schirra, the crew of Apollo 7 conducted an 11-day orbit of Earth. It was the first time three men flew in space together, also the first time NASA broadcasted a television feed from space. Apollo 7 was a crucial step toward Apollo 11‚Äôs epic journey in July 1969.   But this mission brought many arguments - complaints about the food, unhappiness with spacesuits, and whether to launch at all - to learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1849, Edgar Allan Poe died in a Baltimore hospital. Despite his macabre literary genius, his life was short, and he was largely unhappy. After his young wife, Virginia, got tuberculosis in 1842 and died five years later, the already hard-drinking Poe dove deeper into the bottle.   Poe‚Äôs death left a mystery that has lingered for more than a century. No death certificates seemed to be filed, and a local newspaper reporter described Poe‚Äôs cause of death as ‚Äúcongestion of the brain,‚Äù supposed to be a euphemism for alcohol poisoning. Aside from alcoholism, historians, and biographers suggested alternative causes of death ranging from lesions on the brain, epilepsy, and tuberculosis to cholera, syphilis, and even rabies.   To learn more about Edgar Allan Poe, visit the link in our bio.

In Game 5 of the 1956 World Series, pitcher Don Larsen of the New York Yankees threw a perfect game against the Brooklyn Dodgers on #ThisDayInHistory. This is the only postseason perfect game in major league baseball history. Before this achievement, there were just five perfect games between the 1880s and the 1920s.   After he struck out Dale Mitchell, Larsen walked off the mound to celebrate with his team. The Yankees won the 1956 World Series in Game 7. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1964, Martin Luther King, Jr. won a Nobel Peace Prize for his nonviolent resistance to racial prejudice in America. At the age of 35, he was the youngest person to ever receive the award.   King received his doctorate degree in theology and in 1955 organized the first major protest of the civil rights movement: the successful Montgomery Bus Boycott. Influenced by Mohandas Gandhi, he advocated nonviolent civil disobedience to racial segregation. The peaceful protests he led through the American South were often met with violence, but King and his followers persisted, and their nonviolent movement gained momentum.   In King‚Äôs Nobel Prize acceptance speech he said, ‚Äú‚Ä¶Genuine brotherhood and peace is more precious than diamonds or silver or gold.‚Äù  To read more about Martin Luther King, Jr., visit the link in our bio.

10 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, the last of 33 miners trapped nearly half a mile underground for more than two months in a caved-in section of a mine in northern Chile, were rescued.   The miner‚Äôs ordeal began on August 5, 2010, when a portion of the San Jose gold and copper mine where they were working collapsed. The 33 men moved to an underground emergency shelter area, where they discovered just several days‚Äô worth of food rations.   On August 22, a drill sent by rescuers broke through to the area where the miners were located and the men sent back up a note saying, ‚ÄúWe are fine in the refuge, the 33.‚Äù Food, water, letters, medicine, and other supplies were soon delivered to the miners via a narrow bore hole. As engineering and mining experts from around the world collaborated on the long, complex process of devising a way to bring the 33 men up to the service, the miners maintained a system of jobs and routines in order to keep up morale.   Rescuers eventually drilled and reinforced an escape shaft wide enough to extract the men, one by one. The approximately 2,000-foot ascent to the surface in the capsule took around 15 minutes for each man. Less than 24 hours after the operation began, all 33 miners, who ranged in age from 19 to 63, had been safely rescued.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

130 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, an act of Congress established Yosemite National Park, becoming America‚Äôs third national park. Environmental trailblazer John Muir and his colleagues campaigned for the congressional action that was signed into law by President Benjamin Harrison.   Native Americans were the main residents of the Yosemite Valley until the 1849 gold rush brought thousands of non-Indian miners and settlers to the region. Tourists and damage to the Yosemite Valley‚Äôs ecosystem followed. In 1864, to ward off further commercial exploitation, conservationists convinced President Abraham Lincoln to declare Yosemite Valley and the Mariposa Grove of giant sequoias a public trust of California. This marked the first time the U.S. government protected land for public enjoyment, and it laid the foundation for the establishment of the national and state park systems.   In 1889, John Muir discovered that the vast meadows surrounding Yosemite Valley were being overrun and destroyed by domestic sheep grazing. Muir and Robert Underwood Johnson, a fellow environmentalist, lobbied for national park status for the large wilderness area around Yosemite Valley. When Yosemite National Park was established a year later, it became America‚Äôs third national park after Yellowstone and Sequoia National Parks.   To learn more about Yosemite National Park, visit the link in our bio.
Eddie Van Halen, legendary guitarist who helped define an era of rock & roll with his iconic style of playing, passed away on Tuesday after a prolonged battle with cancer. He was 65.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1939, Poland‚Äôs military leaders signed a cease-fire with the invading Nazis, setting up the surrender of 140,000 Polish troops who were taken prisoner. The Poles fought bravely but were able to hold on for only 26 days.   The Germans began a systematic program of terror, murder and cruelty. They executed members of Poland‚Äôs middle and upper classes: doctors, teachers, priests, landowners and businessmen were rounded up and killed. Hundreds of thousands more Poles were driven from their homes and relocated east.   To learn more about World War II, visit the link in our bio.

After 15 months and more than 250,00 flights, the Berlin Airlift officially ended on #ThisDayInHistory in 1949. The airlift was one of the greatest logistical feats in modern history and was one of the crucial events of the early Cold War.   In June 1948, the Soviet Union suddenly blocked all ground traffic into West Berlin, leaving the people without food, clothing, or medical supplies. It was an obvious effort to force the United States, Great Britain, and France to accept Soviet demands concerning the postwar fate of Germany. The U.S. and its allies decided to supply their sectors of the city from the air. This effort carried more than 2.3 million tons of supplies into West Berlin.   The Berlin Airlift was a tremendous Cold War victory for the United States. Without firing a shot, the Americans foiled the Soviet plan to hold West Berlin hostage.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1985, actor Rock Hudson, became the first major U.S. celebrity to die of complications from AIDS.   Hudson, born Roy Harold Scherer Jr. in Illinois, was a Hollywood heartthrob whose career in movies and TV spanned nearly three decades. With leading-man good looks, he starred in numerous dramas and romantic comedies in the 1950s and 60s, including Magnificent Obsession, Giant, and Pillow Talk. To protect his macho image, Hudson‚Äôs off-screen life as a gay man was kept secret from the public. In 1985, news that Hudson had AIDS accumulated worldwide attention and ultimately changed the public‚Äôs perception of the disease.  To learn more about Rock Hudson‚Äôs life and career, visit the link in our bio.

30 years ago, on #ThisDayInHistory, East and West Germany came together on what is known as German Unity Day. Since 1945, when Soviet forces occupied eastern Germany, and the U.S. and other Allied forces occupied the western half of the nation at the close of World War II, divided Germany had come to serve as one of the most enduring symbols of the Cold War. Evidently divided Germany became a hotbed for conflict and some of the most dramatic episodes of the Cold War transpired there ‚Äìthe 1948-49 Berlin Blockade, which banned all ground travel into West Germany, and the construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961.   Two months following the reunification, an all-German election took place and Helmut Kohl became the first chancellor of the reunified Germany.   To learn more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1928, Sir Alexander Fleming, a young bacteriologist, accidentally discovered a bacteria-destroying molecule which he would call penicillin.   When Fleming returned to his laboratory after a month away with his family, he noticed a culture of Staphylococcus aureus he had left out had become contaminated with mold. He also discovered that the colonies of the staphylococci surrounding this mold had been destroyed. At first, he called the substance, mold juice, then named it penicillin after the mold that produced it.   Fleming decided to investigate his discovery further and what he found was an antibiotic ‚Äì one of the first to be discovered. He worked with a team of scientists and in 1929, penicillin was first used to treat bacterial infections, paving the way for the use of antibiotics in modern healthcare.   To learn more about Alexander Fleming, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1918, after a 56-hour-long bombardment, Allied forces breached the so-called Hindenburg Line, the last line of German defenses on the Western Front during World War I.    Built in late 1916, the Hindenburg Line - named for the German commander in chief, Paul von Hindenburg, known to the Germans as the Siegfriedstellung - was a heavily fortified zone running 90 miles. By September 1918, the formidable system consisted of six defensive lines, though heavily fortified, its southern part was most vulnerable to attack. After the Allies‚Äô ‚ÄúHundred Days Offensive," the Allies used these vulnerabilities to their advantage. Australian, British, French, and American forces participated in the attack on the line, which began with the marathon bombardment,. The forces used 1,637 guns along a 10,000-yard-long front.    With heavy losses on both sides, the Germans were forced to retreat. With Kaiser Wilhelm II pressured by the military into accepting governmental reform and Germany‚Äôs ally, Bulgaria sued for an armistice by the end of September, the Central Powers were in disarray on the battlefield as well as the home front. Meanwhile, the Allies pressed their advantage on the Western Front throughout the following month, which would turn out to be the final full month of World War I.    To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1961, President Kennedy urged Americans to build bomb shelters to protect them from atomic fallout in the event of a nuclear exchange with the Soviet Union.   Kennedy also assured the public that the U.S. civil defense program would soon begin providing such protection for every American. Only one year later, true to Kennedy‚Äôs fear, the world hovered on the brink of a full-scale nuclear war when the Cuban Missile Crisis erupted over the USSR‚Äôs placement of nuclear missiles in Cuba. During the tense 13-day crisis, some American‚Äôs prepared for nuclear war by buying up canned goods and completing last-minute work on their backyard bomb shelters.   To learn more about the bomb shelters, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1955, Argentina President Juan Domingo Per√≥n was deposed in a military coup. Per√≥n who came to power in 1946 but became increasingly authoritarian as Argentina‚Äôs economy declined in the early 1950s. His greatest political resource was his wife, Eva ‚ÄúEvita‚Äù Per√≥n, but she died in 1952, signaling the collapse of the national coalition that had backed him. Having antagonized the Catholic Church, students, and others, he was forced into exile by the military in 1955. He settled in Spain, where he served as leader-in-exile to the ‚ÄúPeronists‚Äù- a powerful faction of Argentinians who remained loyal to him.   To learn more, visit the link in our bio.

Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg made history as the second female justice appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court. As a member of the court‚Äôs liberal wing, she was known for her progressive votes and positions on some of the most important issues of the past few decades. Born in 1933 in Brooklyn, NY, she taught at Rutgers University Law School and Columbia University, where she became its first female tenured professor. She served as the director of the Women‚Äôs Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union during the 1970s for which she argued six landmark cases on gender equality before the U.S. Supreme Court. She was appointed to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in 1980. Named to the U.S. Supreme Court in 1993 by President Bill Clinton, Ginsburg became known for her impactful positions on many landmark cases during her tenure on the court.

Their first record, ‚ÄúI Think I Love You‚Äù became a #1 pop hit in the show and rose to the top of the real-life pop charts less than two months after its television debut. On #ThisDayInHistory in 1973, in a highly publicized ‚ÄúBattle of the Sexes‚Äù tennis match, top women‚Äôs player Billie Jean King, 29, beat Bobby Riggs, 55, a former No. 1 ranked men‚Äôs player.   A self-proclaimed male chauvinist, Riggs, had boasted that women were inferior, that they couldn‚Äôt handle the pressure of the game and that even at his age he could beat any female player. King‚Äôs achievement not only helped legitimize women‚Äôs professional tennis and female athletes, but it was seen as a victory for women‚Äôs rights in general.   To read more about this moment in history, visit the link in our bio.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1780, American General Benedict Arnold met with British Major John Andre to discuss handing over West Point to the British, in return for a large sum of money and a high position in the British army. The plan failed, and Arnold became synonymous with the word ‚Äútraitor.‚Äù   When the plan was uncovered, Andre was captured and executed. Arnold fled to the enemy side and went on to lead British troops in Virginia and Connecticut. He later moved to England, though he never received all of what he was promised by the British.   To learn why Benedict Arnold betrayed America, visit the link in our bio.

President Harry Truman made the first-ever televised presidential address from the White House on #ThisDayInHistory in 1947. Truman asked the Americans to cut back on their use of grain in order to help starving Europeans.   At the time of Truman‚Äôs food-conservation speech, Europe was still recovering from World War II and suffering from famine.
