The two Missouri brothers drifted into a life of crime after serving in Confederate guerrilla forces during the Civil War. They began robbing banks in 1866. Detective magazines and pulp novels glamorized the James gang, turning them into mythical Robin Hoods who were driven to crime by unethical landowners and bankers. In reality, the James gang were ruthless killers out for themselves. After the brothers murdered two innocent men during an 1881 train robbery, the state of Missouri offered a reward of $5,000 each for the capture of Jesse and Frank. Shot down for reward money in 1882 by one of his own gang members, Jesse achieved a false but enduring reputation as a martyr in the cause of the common people against powerful interests. ‚ÄãFrank died in the room in which he was born on his family farm, in 1915.

On a clear spring day 75 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory, President Franklin D. Roosevelt sat in the living room at his Warm Springs, Georgia retreat with Lucy Mercer, two cousins and his dog Fala, while the artist Elizabeth Shoumatoff painted his portrait. Around 1 p.m. he suddenly complained of a pain in the back of his head and collapsed unconscious. ‚Äî One of the women summoned a doctor, who recognized the symptoms of a massive cerebral hemorrhage and gave the president a shot of adrenaline into the heart to  try to revive him. Mercer and Shoumatoff quickly left the house, expecting FDR‚Äôs family to arrive as soon as word got out. Another doctor phoned first lady Eleanor Roosevelt in Washington, D.C., informing her that FDR had fainted. She told the doctor she would travel to Georgia that evening after delivering a speech. By 3:30 p.m., though, doctors in Warm Springs had pronounced the president dead. ‚Äî Eleanor delivered her speech that afternoon and was listening to a piano performance when she was summoned back to the White House. In her memoirs, she recalled that ride to the White House as one of dread, as she knew in her heart that her husband had died. At 5:30 pm, she greeted Vice President Truman. A calm and quiet Eleanor said, ‚ÄúHarry, the president is dead.‚Äù He asked if there was anything he could do for her, to which she replied, ‚ÄúIs there anything we can do for you? For you are the one in trouble now.‚Äù Indeed, Truman had rather large shoes to fill. FDR had presided over the Great Depression and most of World War II, leaving an indelible stamp on American politics. ‚Äî Eleanor threw herself into FDR‚Äôs funeral preparations. Thousands of Americans lined the tracks to bid Roosevelt farewell while a slow train carried his coffin from Warm Springs to Washington, D.C. After a solemn state funeral, he was buried at his family‚Äôs home in Hyde Park, New York.

75 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1945, the American Third Army liberates the Buchenwald concentration camp, near Weimar, Germany. Jews had been brought to the camps and its many sub-camps from throughout Europe since it was opened in July 1937. Prisoners also included those who were mentally and physically disabled, political prisoners and Romanis. Hundreds and sometimes thousands of prisoners died monthly from disease, malnutrition, beatings and executions. Doctors performed medical experiments on inmates, testing the effects of viral infections and vaccines. Knowing that the U.S. forces were approaching, the Germans started to evacuate prisoners from the camp in early April. In an act of resistance, emaciated prisoners took control of the camp on April 11. U.S. forces liberated over 21,000 people from the camp. Among those saved by the Americans was Elie Wiesel, who would go on to win the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986.

HISTORY is proud to support @teamrubicon, an organization made up primarily of military veterans, as they safely and effectively help communities nationwide who are confronting COVID-19.  Check them out. Team Rubicon is Built to Serve.

Margaret Thatcher, the first female prime minister of the United Kingdom - nicknamed the Iron Lady - was credited by her admirers with championing free-market, policies that revitalized the British economy, while critics charged these initiatives hurt the nation‚Äôs poor and working class. Serving from 1979 to 1990, Thatcher was the longest-serving British prime minister of the 20th century. She curbed the power of Britain‚Äôs labor unions, privatized state-owned industries, led her nation to victory in the Falklands War and as a close ally of U.S. President Ronald Reagan played a pivotal role in ending the Cold War. When she departed 10 Downing Street, Thatcher was the longest continuously serving prime minister in more than 150 years. She went on to pen her memoirs and travel the world giving lectures. Following a series of minor strokes in the early 2000s, Thatcher largely retreated from public view. Meryl Streep earned an Oscar for her portrayal of the former prime minister in the 2011 biopic ‚ÄúThe Iron Lady,‚Äù which generated criticism from some Conservative politicians for its depiction of Thatcher‚Äôs decline into dementia during her later years.¬†¬†Margaret Thatcher died in London at age 87 from a stroke on #ThisDayinHistory 2013.

150 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1870 the Metropolitan Museum of Art is officially incorporated in New York City. The brainchild of American expatriates in Paris and a number of wealthy New Yorkers, the Met would not put on an exhibition until 1872, but it quickly blossomed into one of the world‚Äôs premier repositories of fine art, a position it holds to this day. ‚Äî The Met acquired its first object, a Roman sarcophagus, the following November. Its subsequent purchase of the Cesnola Collection of Cypriot Art, completed in 1876, made the Met North America‚Äôs premier destination for artifacts and artwork from Antiquity. Thanks in part to the outbreak of the Franco-Prussian War, Jay was able to acquire a stunning 174 pieces by the Dutch Old Masters in 1871, giving the museum a substantial collection by the time it opened at its first location in 1872. In 1880, ten years after its founding, the Met moved to its current location on Fifth Avenue at 82 Street. The Met continues to display some of the world‚Äôs largest collections of European and Antique art, and has expanded to include works from every continent and nearly every medium. Today, the Met is not only one of the leading artistic and social institutions in New York but one of the best-known and most-visited museums in the world, hosting around 7 million visitors a year. @metmuseum

On the evening of Good Friday on #ThisDayinHistory 1865, Abraham Lincoln and his wife Mary Todd attend Laura Keene‚Äôs acclaimed performance in Our American Cousin at Ford‚Äôs Theater in Washington, D.C. In the middle of act two, actor John Wilkes Booth entered Lincoln‚Äôs private theater box unnoticed, and shot the president with a single bullet in the back of his head. Booth jumped onto the stage, breaking his left leg, and shouted, ‚ÄúSic semper tyrannis! (Ever thus to tyrants!) The South is avenged,‚Äù then quickly fled on horseback and escaped Washington.  The president, mortally wounded, was carried to a lodging house opposite Ford‚Äôs Theater. An hour after dawn the next morning around 7:22 a.m., Abraham Lincoln died, becoming the first president to be assassinated. His body was taken to the White House, where it lay until April 18, at which point it was carried to the Capitol rotunda to lay in state on a catafalque. On April 21, Lincoln‚Äôs body was taken to the railroad station and boarded on a train that conveyed it to Springfield, Illinois, his home before becoming president. Tens of thousands of Americans lined the train‚Äôs railroad route and paid their respects to their fallen leader during the train‚Äôs solemn progression through the North. Lincoln was buried on May 4, 1865, at Oak Ridge Cemetery, near Springfield. ‚Äî Booth, pursued by the army and secret service forces, was finally cornered in a barn near Bowling Green, Virginia. Booth remained in the barn as it went up in flames and was then shot and killed by Corporal Boston Corbett. Of the eight other persons eventually charged with the conspiracy, four were hanged and four were jailed.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1961, President John F. Kennedy sends a letter to Congress in which he recommends the U.S. participate in an international campaign to preserve ancient temples and historic monuments in the Nile Valley of Egypt. The campaign, initiated by UNESCO, was designed to save sites threatened by the construction of the Aswan High Dam. JFK believed that America‚Äôs participation in the project would reflect ‚Äúthe interests of the United States,‚Äù as well as the country‚Äôs interest in ancient Egyptian culture ‚Äúfrom which many of our own cultural traditions have sprung‚Äù and the U.S.‚Äôs ‚Äúdeep friendship for the people who live in the valley of the Nile.‚Äù Kennedy possessed a personal interest in the sciences and history and, from the beginning of his presidency, set out to promote American scholarship in these areas. His administration also wanted to develop diplomatic ties with the Arab nations in the Middle East and North Africa. In 1961, the total cost of preserving Egypt‚Äôs historic sites was estimated at $100 million; the U.S. contributed a total of $16 million toward the effort, which was used to help protect ruins from water re-routed for the dam or to relocate antiquities. Kennedy, assassinated in 1963, did not live to see any of the precious antiquities arrive in America. His widow, however, former first lady Jacqueline Kennedy, helped arrange to have Eqypt‚Äôs Temple of Dendur brought to New York‚Äôs Metropolitan Museum of Art in 1965. The temple remains a centerpiece of the museum‚Äôs collections.

On #ThisDayInHistory in 1974, the House Judiciary Committee recommended that America‚Äôs 37th president, Richard Nixon, be impeached and removed from office. The impeachment proceedings resulted from a series of political scandals involving the Nixon administration that came to be collectively known as Watergate.   In July 1973, one of Nixon‚Äôs former staff members revealed the existence of secretly taped conversations between the president and his aides. Nixon initially refused to release the tapes, on grounds of executive privilege and national security, but a judge later ordered the president to turn them over.  The House Judiciary Committee approved three articles of impeachment against Nixon, making him the second U.S. president (after Johnson) to face a potential trial before the Senate. On August 8, Nixon announced his resignation, becoming the first president in U.S. history to voluntarily leave office early.  To learn more about #PresidentNixon and the impeachment process, visit the link in our bio.
You can only quarantine in one house. The choice is yours!

According to tradition, on #ThisDayinHistory 753 B.C., Romulus and his twin brother, Remus, found Rome on the site where they were suckled by a she-wolf as orphaned infants. Actually, the Romulus and Remus myth originated sometime in the fourth century B.C., and the exact date of Rome‚Äôs founding was set by the Roman scholar Marcus Terentius Varro in the first century B.C.Pictured here is the Colosseum, commissioned around A.D. 70-72 by Emperor Vespasian of the Flavian dynasty as a gift to the Roman people. In A.D. 80, Vespasian‚Äôs son Titus opened the Colosseum‚Äìofficially known as the Flavian Amphitheater‚Äìwith 100 days of games, including gladiatorial combats and wild animal fights. After four centuries of active use, the magnificent arena fell into neglect, and up until the 18th century it was used as a source of building materials. Though two-thirds of the original Colosseum has been destroyed over time, the amphitheater remains a popular tourist destination, as well as an iconic symbol of Rome and its long, tumultuous history.

Do you know a lot about the 12th President of the United States? Ten-year-old Presidential expert and frequent @theellenshow guest, Macey Hensley, is here to teach you about some of the most obscure presidents in America‚Äôs history!  Complete the activity plan with your family and share your work with us. We'd love to see it. Tag us using @HISTORY or the hashtag #HISTORYAtHome. Find more HISTORY At Home videos and activity plans by visiting the link in our bio.

Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th president of the United States and one of the most highly regarded American generals of World War II. Born in Denison, Texas, in 1890, Eisenhower graduated from the United States Military Academy in 1915, and after World War I he steadily rose in the peacetime ranks of the U.S. Army. After the U.S. entrance into World War II, he was appointed commanding general of the European theater of operations and oversaw U.S. troops massing in Great Britain. As supreme commander of a mixed force of Allied nationalities, services, and equipment, Eisenhower designed a system of unified command and rapidly won the respect of his British and Canadian subordinates. From North Africa, he successfully directed the invasions of Tunisia, Sicily, and Italy, and in January 1944 was appointed supreme Allied commander of Operation Overlord, the Allied invasion of northwestern Europe.  After the war, he briefly served as president of Columbia University before returning to military service in 1951 as supreme commander of the combined land and air forces of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). Pressure on Eisenhower to run for U.S. president was great, however, and in the spring of 1952 he relinquished his NATO command to run for president on the Republican ticket. In November 1952, ‚ÄúIke‚Äù won a resounding victory in the presidential elections and in 1956 was reelected in a landslide. A popular president, he oversaw a period of great economic growth in the United States and deftly navigated the country through increasing Cold War tension on the world stage. In 1961, he retired with his wife, Mamie Doud Eisenhower, to his farm in Gettysburg, Pennsylvania. He died on #ThisDayinHistory 1969 and was buried on a family plot in Abilene, Kansas.

Thank you to all of the doctors and those on the front lines in healthcare who are helping us during this time. Pictured here is Dr. Charles Drew. Drew was an African American surgeon who developed methods of storing blood plasma for transfusion and organized the first large-scale blood bank in the U.S.  He directed the blood plasma programs of the U.S. and Great Britain in WWII which saved the lives of countless servicemen. Drew protested against the segregation of blood based on race during WWII and broke barriers for African Americans in the healthcare field. He passed away in 1950 and is remembered as one of the pioneers of 20th century medicine. #NationalDoctorsDay #WeAreHereWithYou

President Harry S. Truman signs the Economic Assistance Act, commonly known as the Marshall Plan, on #ThisDayinHistory 1948, which authorized the creation of a program that would help the nations of Europe recover and rebuild after the devastation wrought by World War II.¬†The plan aimed to stabilize Europe economically and politically so that European nations would not be tempted by the appeal of communist parties. U.S. Secretary of State George C. Marshall made his famous call for American assistance to Europe in a speech at Harvard University on June 5, 1947. He proposed that the European states themselves draw up a program for economic recovery, which the United States would help fund. Marshall himself said, ‚ÄúOur policy is not directed against any country, but against hunger, poverty, desperation and chaos." Under the Marshall Plan, the Economic Cooperation Administration (ECA) distributed $13 billion in aid over four years (1948-51). Most of the funds were given in direct grants, and the rest in loans. The Marshall Plan is also considered a key catalyst for the formation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), a military alliance between North American and European countries established in 1949.

Two months after the signing of the Vietnam peace agreement, the last U.S. combat troops leave South Vietnam as Hanoi frees the remaining American prisoners of war held in North Vietnam. America‚Äôs direct eight-year intervention in the Vietnam War was at an end. In Saigon, some 7,000 U.S. Department of Defense civilian employees remained behind to aid South Vietnam in conducting what looked to be a fierce and ongoing war with communist North Vietnam. In January 1973, representatives of the United States, North and South Vietnam, and the Vietcong signed a peace agreement in Paris, ending the direct U.S. military involvement in the Vietnam War. Its key provisions included a cease-fire throughout Vietnam, the withdrawal of U.S. forces, the release of prisoners of war, and the reunification of North and South Vietnam through peaceful means. The South Vietnamese government was to remain in place until new elections were held, and North Vietnamese forces in the South were not to advance further nor be reinforced. In reality, however, the agreement was little more than a face-saving gesture by the U.S. government. Even before the last American troops departed on #ThisDayinHistory 1973, the communists violated the cease-fire, and by early 1974 full-scale war had resumed. At the end of 1974, South Vietnamese authorities reported that 80,000 of their soldiers and civilians had been killed in fighting during the year, making it the most costly of the Vietnam War.

90 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1930, James A. Dewar created the Twinkie. A manager of the Continental Baking plant in Schiller Park, Illinois, Dewar baked up a fulfilling idea: a snack-able shortcake filled with a banana flavored cream mixture - the original flavor. The name of this new invention was based on an advertisement for ‚ÄúTwinkle Toe Shoes.‚Äù Due to food rations during WWII, the Twinkie was forced to switch their flavor to vanilla.

Pope John Paul II, history‚Äôs most well-traveled pope and the first non-Italian to hold the position since the 16th century, dies at his home in the Vatican on #ThisDayinHistory 2005. Six days later, two million people packed Vatican City for his funeral. A conservative pontiff, John Paul II's papacy was marked by his opposition to communism and war, as well as abortion, contraception, capital punishment and homosexual sex. He later voiced opposition to euthanasia, human cloning and stem cell research. He traveled widely as pope, using the eight languages he spoke (Polish, Italian, French, German, English, Spanish, Portuguese and Latin) and his well-known personal charm, to connect with the Catholic faithful, as well as many outside the fold. Pope John Paul II is remembered for his successful efforts to end communism, as well as for building bridges with peoples of other faiths, and issuing the Catholic Church's first apology for its actions during World War II. He was succeeded by Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, who became Pope Benedict XVI. Pope Francis, who succeeded Pope Benedict in March 2013, canonized John Paul II in April 2014.

The Battle of Okinawa was the last major battle of World War II, and one of the bloodiest. 75 years ago, on #ThisDayinHistory 1945‚ÄîEaster Sunday‚Äîthe Navy‚Äôs Fifth Fleet and more than 180,000 U.S. Army and U.S. Marine Corps troops descended on the Pacific island of Okinawa for a final push towards Japan. The invasion was part of Operation Iceberg, a complex plan to invade and occupy the Ryukyu Islands, including Okinawa. Though it resulted in an Allied victory, kamikaze fighters, rainy weather and fierce fighting on land, sea and air led to a large death toll on both sides. Winning the Battle of Okinawa put Allied forces within striking distance of Japan. But wanting to bring the war to a swift end, and knowing over 2 million Japanese troops were awaiting battle-weary American soldiers, Harry S. Truman chose to drop an atomic bomb on Hiroshima on August 6. Japan didn‚Äôt give in immediately, so Truman ordered the bombing of Nagasaki on August 9. Finally, Japan had had enough. On August, 14, 1945, Emperor Hirohito announced Japan‚Äôs surrender, marking the end of World War II.

The ‚ÄúTwin Towers‚Äù of the World Trade Center officially open in New York City on #ThisDayinHistory 1973. The buildings replaced the Empire State Building as the world‚Äôs tallest building. The towers‚Äô construction ended the Empire State Building‚Äôs 41-year run as the tallest building in the world, and quickly replaced by Chicago‚Äôs Sears Tower the following year, an indication of the rising trend of super-tall construction. The World Trade Center dramatically altered the New York skyline and the cityscape of Lower Manhattan. Though most of the World Trade Center was occupied by office space, the Top of the World Observation Deck on the South Tower became a popular tourist destination, as did the North Tower‚Äôs Windows on the World restaurant, which featured its own wine school. The Twin Towers remained a dominant feature of the city‚Äôs skyline and were recognizable the world over long before they were destroyed in a terrorist attack on September 11, 2001.

President Franklin D. Roosevelt established the Civilian Conservation Corps, or CCC, with an executive order on #ThisDayinHistorhy 1933. The CCC was part of his New Deal legislation, combating high unemployment during the Great Depression by putting millions of young men  to work on environmental conservation projects. Considered by many to be one of the most successful of Roosevelt‚Äôs New Deal programs, the CCC planted more than three billion trees and constructed trails and shelters in more than 800 parks nationwide during its nine years of existence. The CCC helped to shape the modern national and state park systems we enjoy today.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1889, the Eiffel Tower is dedicated in Paris in a ceremony presided over by Gustave Eiffel, the tower‚Äôs designer, and attended by French Prime Minister Pierre Tirard, a handful of other dignitaries, and 200 construction workers. In 1889, to honor of the centenary of the French Revolution, the French government planned an international exposition and announced a design competition for a monument to be built on the Champ-de-Mars in central Paris. The Centennial Committee chose Eiffel‚Äôs plan of an open-lattice wrought-iron tower that would reach almost 1,000 feet above Paris and be the world‚Äôs tallest man-made structure. Eiffel, a noted bridge builder, was a master of metal construction and designed the framework of the Statue of Liberty that had recently been erected in New York Harbor. Eiffel‚Äôs tower was greeted with skepticism from critics who argued that it would be structurally unsound, and indignation from others who thought it would be an eyesore in the heart of Paris. Unperturbed, Eiffel completed his great tower under budget in just two years. Only one worker lost his life during construction, which at the time was a remarkably low casualty number for a project of that magnitude. The light, airy structure was by all accounts a technological wonder. The Eiffel Tower remained the world‚Äôs tallest man-made structure until the completion of the Chrysler Building in New York in 1930. The Eiffel Tower was almost demolished when the International Exposition‚Äôs 20-year lease on the land expired in 1909, but its value as an antenna for radio transmission saved it. It remains largely unchanged today and is one of the world‚Äôs premier tourist attractions.

Just after 6 p.m. on #ThisDayinHistory 1968, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. is fatally shot while standing on the balcony outside his second-story room at the Lorraine Motel in Memphis, Tennessee. The civil rights leader was in Memphis to support a sanitation workers‚Äô strike and was on his way to dinner when an assassin's bullet struck him. King was pronounced dead after his arrival at a Memphis hospital. He was 39 years old. ‚Äî In the months before his assassination, Martin Luther King became increasingly concerned with the problem of economic inequality in America. He organized a Poor People‚Äôs Campaign to focus on the issue, including a march on Washington, and in March 1968 traveled to Memphis in support of poorly treated African-American sanitation workers. On March 28, a workers‚Äô protest march led by King ended in violence and the death of an African-American teenager. King left the city but vowed to return in early April to lead another demonstration. ‚Äî On April 3, back in Memphis, King gave his last sermon, saying, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve got some difficult days ahead. But it really doesn‚Äôt matter with me now, because I‚Äôve been to the mountaintop ‚Ä¶ And He‚Äôs allowed me to go up to the mountain. And I‚Äôve looked over, and I‚Äôve seen the Promised Land. I may not get there with you. But I want you to know tonight that we, as a people, will get to the promised land.‚Äù ‚Äî One day after speaking those words, Dr. King was shot and killed by a sniper. As word of the assassination spread, riots broke out in cities all across the United States and National Guard troops were deployed in Memphis and Washington, D.C. On April 9, King was laid to rest in his hometown of Atlanta, Georgia.

25 years ago, shortly after 9:00 a.m. on #ThisDayinHistory 1995, a Ryder rental truck exploded with terrifying force in front of the nine-story Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in downtown Oklahoma City. The powerful explosion blew off the building‚Äôs entire north wall. Emergency crews raced to Oklahoma from across the country, and when the rescue effort finally ended two weeks later, the death toll stood at 168 people. The list of the deceased included 19 young children who were in the building‚Äôs day care center at the time of the blast. More than 650 other people were injured in the bombing, which damaged or destroyed over 300 buildings in the immediate area. -- The blast was set off by anti-government militant Timothy McVeigh, who in 2001 was executed for his crimes. His co-conspirator Terry Nichols was sentenced to life in prison. The Oklahoma City bombing was the worst terrorist attack to take place on U.S. soil until the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001. Church bells still ring just after 9 a.m. every April 19 in Oklahoma City. And some people still pull over their cars, or stop their meetings, to bow their heads for 168 seconds of silence‚Äîone second for each of the children and adults who died on that date in 1995. The Oklahoma City National Memorial was created to honor the victims, survivors, and rescuers affected by the bombing. It was dedicated on the fifth anniversary of the bombing and opened the following year. The memorial includes a field of 168 chairs representing the lives tragically lost.
All of us at HISTORY are #HereForYou. Please stay safe. Stay healthy. And, stay home. For more info, visit the link in our bio.

One of the worst oil spills in U.S. territory begins when the supertanker Exxon Valdez, owned and operated by the Exxon Corporation, runs aground on a reef in Prince William Sound in southern Alaska on #ThisDayinHistory 1989. An estimated 11 million gallons of oil eventually spilled into the water. Attempts to contain the massive spill were unsuccessful, and wind and currents spread the oil more than 100 miles from its source, eventually polluting more than 700 miles of coastline. Hundreds of thousands of birds and animals were adversely affected by the environmental disaster. After litigation and investigations, Exxon eventually paid over $2 billion for habitat restoration and damages related to the spill. One of the outcomes of the spill was to shed light on the importance of preventing environmental disaster and of preserving ocean ecosystems. In 1990, Congress passed the Oil Pollution Act to help safeguard against future disasters.
Visit our bio for a glimpse into how military rations have changed over the centuries and don‚Äôt miss the series premiere of Eating History TONIGHT at 10/9c!

On #ThisDayinHistory 1953, American medical researcher Dr. Jonas Salk announces on a national radio show that he has successfully tested a vaccine against poliomyelitis, the virus that causes the crippling disease of polio. In 1952‚Äîan epidemic year for polio‚Äîthere were 58,000 new cases reported in the U.S., and more than 3,000 died from the disease. Salk first conducted research on viruses in the 1930s when he was a medical student, and during WWII helped develop flu vaccines. In 1947, he became head of a research laboratory at the University of Pittsburgh and in 1948 was awarded a grant to study the polio virus and develop a possible vaccine. By 1950, he had an early version of his vaccine. In 1954, clinical trials using the Salk vaccine and a placebo began on nearly two million American schoolchildren. In April 1955, it was announced that the vaccine was effective and safe. A nationwide inoculation campaign began. New polio cases dropped to under 6,000 in 1957, the first year after the vaccine was widely available. Among other honors, Jonas Salk was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 1977. He passed in 1995.

Happy National Puppy Day! Today we salute these famous pups from History. ‚Äî‚Äî Toto: Toto became one of the most famous canines in the world after his 1939 debut in The Wizard of Oz. ‚Äî‚Äî Sergeant Stubby‚ÄîThe Most Decorated Dog of World War I, Stubby was a lost pup who was adopted by U.S. Infantrymen and smuggled to the trenches in France. ‚Äî‚Äî American Fox Hound: The American Kennel Club recognizes George Washington as the father of the American foxhound who actively bred hunting dogs. ‚Äî‚Äî Owney‚ÄîThe U.S. Postal Pup: Adopted in 1888 by post office workers at a branch in Albany, New York, after his previous owner abandoned him, Owney became an unofficial mascot of the U.S. Postal Service. ‚Äî‚Äî Rin Tin Tin: The most famous dog to emerge from World War I was Rin Tin Tin, an abandoned puppy of German war dogs found in France in 1918 and taken to the United States, where he made his film debut in the 1922 silent film debut and became a bona fide animal movie star. ‚Äî‚Äî Laika: On November 3, 1957, Laika (which means ‚Äúbarker‚Äù in Russian) become the first animal to orbit Earth when she traveled aboard the Soviet spacecraft Sputnik 2. ‚Äî‚Äî Balto: In January 1925, the children of Nome, Alaska, were dying of diphtheria. With the harbors filled with impenetrable ice and the subzero temperatures too extreme for open-cockpit airplanes to fly, the stage was set for the heroism of sled dogs. The ‚ÄúGreat Race of Mercy‚Äù covered 674-miles, took five-and-a-half days and involved more than 150 dogs and 20 drivers, but it was the black-and-white Siberian husky, Balto, who emerged as a national superstar. ‚Äî‚Äî Lassie: Perhaps the most famous canine character in entertainment history is Lassie. The loyal collie originated in a 1938 short story by Eric Knight, about a boy whose faithful companion is sold after his family falls on hard times. Sinbad: A mixed-breed canine, Sinbad served 11 years aboard the United States Coast Guard Cutter George W. Campbell and remained aboard during its entire World War II tour, during which it sank the German submarine U-606. ‚Äî‚Äî Continued below. üëá

In the name of African American voting rights, 3,200 civil rights demonstrators in Alabama, led by Martin Luther King, Jr., begin a historic march from Selma to Montgomery, the state‚Äôs capital. Federalized Alabama National Guardsmen and FBI agents were on hand to provide safe passage for the march, which twice had been turned back by Alabama state police at Selma‚Äôs Edmund Pettus Bridge. On #ThisDayinHistory 1965, U.S. Army troops and federalized Alabama National Guardsmen escorted the marchers across Edmund Pettus Bridge and down Highway 80. When the highway narrowed to two lanes, only 300 marchers were permitted, but thousands more rejoined the Alabama Freedom March as it came into Montgomery on March 25. On the steps of the Alabama State Capitol, King addressed live television cameras and a crowd of 25,000, just a few hundred feet from the Dexter Avenue Baptist Church, where he got his start as a minister in 1954.

After John Lennon and Yoko Ono wed in Gibraltar on March 20, 1969, the couple traveled to Amsterdam for their honeymoon. ‚ÄúWe sent out a card: ‚ÄòCome to John and Yoko‚Äôs honeymoon: a bed-in, Amsterdam Hotel,‚Äù recalled Lennon while recording The Beatles Anthology. Lennon was under the impression that the press thought they would ‚Äúmake love in public,‚Äù however, the couples intention was to bring attention the the on-going peace talks in Paris between he U.S., South Vietnam, North Vietnam, and the National Liberation Front. Lennon added, ‚ÄúIn Paris, the Vietnam peace talks have got about as far as sorting out the shape of the table they are going to sit round. Those talks have been going on for months. In one week in bed, we achieved a lot more." The press was invited to their hotel room on #ThisDayinHistory 1969, from 9:00am to 9:00pm for six full days. It was during another week-long bed-in in Montreal two months later that Lennon was inspired to pen his famous ant-war song, "Give Peace a Chance". At her 2015 Museum of Modern Art solo art exhibition in New York, Ono recalled, ‚ÄúJohn and I thought after Bed-In, ‚ÄòThe war is going to end.‚Äô How na√Øve we were, you know? But the thing is, things take time. I think it‚Äôs going to happen. I mean, that I think we‚Äôre going to have a peaceful world. But it‚Äôs just taking a little bit more time than we thought then.‚Äù

On #ThisDayinHistory 2011, actress Elizabeth Taylor, who appeared in more than 50 films, won two Academy Awards and was synonymous with Hollywood glamour, dies of complications from congestive heart failure at a Los Angeles hospital at age 79. The violet-eyed Taylor began her acting career as a child and spent most of her life in the spotlight. Known for her striking beauty, she was married eight times and later in life became a prominent HIV/AIDS activist.

Today is #NationalMedalofHonorDay. The first Medals of Honor were awarded on #ThisDayinHistory 1863. Abraham Lincoln created the Medal of Honor during the American Civil War to honor soldiers who exhibited gallantry in action. Pictured here is Audie Murphy, one of the most decorated combat soldiers of World War II. Murphy rose to the rank of 2nd lieutenant in the U.S. Army. He was wounded three times and fought in nine major campaigns. ‚ÄúBravery is just determination to do a job that you know has to be done,‚Äù he told reporters upon returning home in 1945. ‚ÄúI just fought to stay alive, like anyone else, I guess.‚Äù The battle that earned Murphy the Medal of Honor occurred during the last stages of the Allied victory over Germans in France. Murphy acted as cover for infantrymen during a last desperate German tank attack. Climbing atop a U.S. tank destroyer, he took control of its .50-caliber machine gun, stopping the advance and suffering a leg wound. Upon his return, Murphy was invited to Hollywood by Jimmy Cagney, who saw the war hero‚Äôs picture on the cover of Life magazine. By 1950, Murphy had an acting contract with Universal Pictures. In his most famous role, he played himself in the monumentally successful To Hell and Back. Today, many soldiers continue to serve with valor around the world. We thank them and all first responders on the front lines today. #WeAreHereWithYou

In Ripon, Wisconsin, on #ThisDayinHistory 1854, former members of the Whig Party meet to establish a new party to oppose the spread of slavery into the western territories. The Whig Party, which was formed in 1834 to oppose the ‚Äútyranny‚Äù of President Andrew Jackson, had shown itself incapable of coping with the national crisis over slavery. The Civil War firmly identified the Republican Party as the party of the victorious North, and after the war the Republican-dominated Congress forced a ‚ÄúRadical Reconstruction‚Äù policy on the South, which saw the passage of the 13th, 14th, and 15th amendments to the Constitution and the granting of equal rights to all Southern citizens. By 1876, the Republican Party had lost control of the South, but it continued to dominate the presidency until the election of Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933.

In an effort to raise funds to pay off debts and defend the vast new American territories won from the French in the Seven Years‚Äô War (1756-1763), the British government passes the Stamp Act on #ThisDayinHistory 1765. The legislation levied a direct tax on all materials printed for commercial and legal use in the colonies, from newspapers and pamphlets to playing cards and dice. Though the Stamp Act employed a strategy that was a common fundraising vehicle in England, it stirred a storm of protest in the colonies. The colonists had recently been hit with three major taxes: the Sugar Act (1764), which levied new duties on imports of textiles, wines, coffee and sugar; the Currency Act (1764), which caused a major decline in the value of the paper money used by colonists; and the Quartering Act (1765), which required colonists to provide food and lodging to British troops. By October of that year, nine of the 13 colonies sent representatives to the Stamp Act Congress, at which the colonists drafted the ‚ÄúDeclaration of Rights and Grievances,‚Äù a document that railed against the autocratic policies of the mercantilist British empire. The fracas over the Stamp Act, though, helped plant seeds for a far larger movement against the British government and the eventual battle for independence. Most important of these was the formation of the Sons of Liberty‚Äìa group of tradesmen who led anti-British protests in Boston and other seaboard cities‚Äìand other groups of wealthy landowners who came together from the across the colonies. Out of their meetings, a growing nationalism emerged that would culminate in the fighting of the American Revolution only a decade later.

"A person who never made a mistake never tried anything new," observed Albert Einstein. In 1905‚Äîseen by many as a "miracle year" for the theorist‚ÄîEinstein proposed the equation E=MC2: the energy of a body (E) is equal to the mass (M) of that body times the speed of light squared (C2). This equation suggested that tiny particles of matter could be converted into huge amounts of energy, a discovery that heralded atomic power. Einstein went on to win worldwide fame for his general theory of relativity and a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the phenomenon known as the photoelectric effect. An outspoken pacifist, Einstein emigrated from Germany to the United States when the Nazis took power before World War II. He lived and worked in Princeton, New Jersey, for the remainder of his life. Albert Einstein was born on #ThisDayinHistory 1879.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1942, the War Relocation Authority is created to ‚ÄúTake all people of Japanese descent into custody, surround them with troops, prevent them from buying land, and return them to their former homes at the close of the war.‚Äù Anger toward and fear of Japanese Americans began shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941.  On February 19, 1942, President Franklin D. Roosevelt ordered that German, Italian, and Japanese nationals‚Äîas well as Japanese Americans‚Äîbe barred from certain areas deemed sensitive militarily. While roughly 2,000 people of German and Italian ancestry were interned during this period, Americans of Japanese ancestry suffered most egregiously. The War Relocation Authority was aimed at Japanese specifically: 120,000 men, women, and children were rounded up on the West Coast. In 1990, reparations were made to surviving internees and their heirs in the form of a formal apology by the U.S. government and a check for $20,000.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1933, eight days after his inauguration, President Franklin D. Roosevelt gives his first national radio address‚Äîor ‚Äúfireside chat‚Äù‚Äîbroadcast directly from the White House. Roosevelt began that first address simply: ‚ÄúI want to talk for a few minutes with the people of the United States about banking.‚Äù He went on to explain his recent decision to close the nation‚Äôs banks in order to stop a surge in mass withdrawals by panicked investors worried about possible bank failures. At the time, the U.S. was at the lowest point of the Great Depression, with between 25 and 33 percent of the workforce unemployed. The nation was worried, and Roosevelt‚Äôs address was designed to ease fears and to inspire confidence in his leadership. Roosevelt went on to deliver 30 more of these broadcasts between March 1933 and June 1944. They reached an astonishing number of American households, 90 percent of which owned a radio at the time.

Fifty years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1970, a propane gas explosion rocked the South Tower of the World Trade Center injuring six construction workers. Though the explosion was accidental, tensions were high after authorities had received a telephone warning of a bomb threat at the site of the two developing 110-story structures earlier that day.  Construction resumed and later in the year, on October 19, the World Trade Center officially became the tallest building in the world, topping the Empire State Building by four feet. Nine workers were killed during the construction of the World Trade Center by the time the towers were dedicated in April 1973.

We know this is a challenging time for everyone, and we sincerely thank you for being responsible and socially distancing yourselves. We also want to extend thanks to the healthcare professionals and first responders for their efforts on the front lines. While the isolation is difficult, we know it‚Äôs crucial, and HISTORY will continue to be #HereForYou with documentaries, shows and learning materials for you and your family.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1959, the first Barbie doll goes on display at the American Toy Fair in New York City. Barbie was the first mass-produced toy doll in the United States with adult features. The woman behind Barbie was Ruth Handler, who co-founded Mattel, Inc. with her husband in 1945. Over the years, Barbie generated huge sales‚Äîand a lot of controversy. On the positive side, many women saw Barbie as providing an alternative to traditional 1950s gender roles. It was Barbie‚Äôs appearance that caused the most controversy, however. Many claimed that Barbie provided little girls with an unrealistic and harmful example and fostered negative body image. Despite the criticism, sales of Barbie-related merchandise continued to soar, topping 1 billion dollars annually by 1993. The line of Barbies has also diversified, with many different backgrounds and body types represented. Since 1959, over one billion dolls in the Barbie family have been sold around the world.

On #ThisDayinHistory 2003, the United States, along with coalition forces primarily from the United Kingdom, initiates war on Iraq. Just after explosions began to rock Baghdad, Iraq‚Äôs capital, U.S. President George W. Bush announced in a televised address, ‚ÄúAt this hour, American and coalition forces are in the early stages of military operations to disarm Iraq, to free its people and to defend the world from grave danger.‚Äù President Bush and his advisors built much of their case for war on the idea that Iraq, under dictator Saddam Hussein, possessed or was in the process of building weapons of mass destruction. Hostilities began about 90 minutes after the U.S.-imposed deadline for Saddam Hussein to leave Iraq or face war passed. The first targets, which Bush said were ‚Äúof military importance,‚Äù were hit with Tomahawk cruise missiles from U.S. fighter-bombers and warships stationed in the Persian Gulf. No weapons of mass destruction were found in Iraq. The U.S. declared an end to the war in Iraq on December 15, 2011, nearly ten years after the fighting began.

Long considered a harbinger of bad luck, Friday the 13th has inspired a late 19th-century secret society, an early 20th-century novel, a horror film franchise and not one but two unwieldy terms‚Äîparaskavedekatriaphobia and friggatriskaidekaphobia‚Äîthat describe fear of this supposedly unlucky day. Walking under a ladder, crossing paths with a black cat or breaking a mirror: many people hold fast to the belief that Friday the 13th brings bad luck. Though it‚Äôs uncertain exactly when this particular tradition began, negative superstitions have swirled around the number 13 for centuries.

St. Patrick was born in Britain‚Äînot Ireland‚Äîto wealthy parents near the end of the fourth century. After studying for the priesthood, Patrick was ordained a bishop. Familiar with the Irish language and culture, Patrick chose to incorporate traditional ritual into his lessons of Christianity instead of attempting to eradicate native Irish beliefs when he began preaching the Gospel in 433 A.D., converting many thousands of Irish and building churches around the country. After 40 years of living in poverty, teaching, traveling and working tirelessly, Patrick died on #ThisDayinHistory 461 A.D. in Saul, Downpatrick, Ireland where he had built his first church. Since that time, countless legends have grown up around Patrick, including that he banished all the snakes from Ireland, baptized hundreds of people on a single day, and used a three-leaf clover‚Äìthe famous shamrock‚Äìto describe the Holy Trinity.

Just before breakfast on #ThisDayinHistory 1918, Private Albert Gitchell of the U.S. Army reports to the hospital at Fort Riley, Kansas, complaining of the cold-like symptoms of sore throat, fever and headache. By noon, over 100 of his fellow soldiers had reported similar symptoms, marking what are believed to be the first cases in the historic influenza epidemic of 1918. The flu would eventually kill 675,000 Americans and more than 20 million people (some believe the total may be closer to 40 million) around the world, proving to be a far deadlier force than even the First World War.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1864, President Abraham Lincoln signs a brief document officially promoting then-Major General Ulysses S. Grant to the rank of lieutenant general of the U.S. Army, tasking the future president with the job of leading all Union troops against the Confederate Army. Lincoln was reluctant to promote Grant and risk boosting the general‚Äôs popularity; at the time Washington was abuzz with rumors that many northern senators were considering nominating Grant instead of Lincoln at the 1864 Republican National Convention. After Grant publicly dismissed the idea of running for the presidency, Lincoln submitted to Congress‚Äô choice and agreed to give Grant the revived rank. As lieutenant general of the U.S. Army, Grant was answerable only to Lincoln. Well-respected by troops and civilians, Grant earned Lincoln‚Äôs trust and went on to force the South‚Äôs surrender in 1865.

In 1975, recognized as International Women‚Äôs Year, the United Nations General Assembly began celebrating March 8 as International Women‚Äôs Day. By 2014, it was celebrated in more than 100 countries, and had been made an official holiday in more than 25. Over the years, however, many celebrations strayed far from the holiday‚Äôs political roots. The concept of a ‚Äúwoman‚Äôs day‚Äù caught on in Europe. On March 19, 1911 (the 40th anniversary of the Paris Commune, a radical socialist government that briefly ruled France in 1871), the first International Woman‚Äôs Day was held, drawing more than 1 million people to rallies worldwide. Most dramatically, a massive demonstration led by Russian feminist Alexandra Kollontai that began on March 8, 1917 proved to be a link in the chain of events that led to the abdication of Czar Nicholas II and the Russian Revolution. After the czar‚Äôs abdication, the provisional government formed until a constituent assembly could be elected became the first government of a major power to grant women the right to vote.

Moments before he was shot to death by a soldier of the Bolivian government, the revolutionary Ernesto ‚ÄúChe‚Äù Guevara told his executioner, ‚ÄúShoot, coward! You are only going to kill a man!‚Äù Guevara died a short time later, on October 9, 1967 at the age of 39, but he was correct in his assertion that this would not be the end of his legacy. Today, that legacy almost always takes the form of a single photograph, Guerrillero Heroico, which some have called the most famous photograph in the world. That photo was taken 60 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1960, at a funeral for workers killed in an explosion in a Cuban port that Fidel Castro‚Äôs revolutionary government blamed on the Americans. Guevara, a general in the revolution and the intellectual heavyweight of Castro‚Äôs regime, looked on as Castro delivered his fiery funeral oration. In addition to being held aloft at protests or hung in the homes of his admirers, Guevara's image has become popular as a fashion statement, adorning t-shirts and posters wherever counterculture is revered.

Tensions ran high in Boston in early 1770. More than 2,000 British soldiers occupied the city of 16,000 colonists and tried to enforce Britain‚Äôs tax laws, like the Stamp Act and Townshend Acts. American colonists rebelled against the taxes they found repressive, rallying around the cry, ‚Äúno taxation without representation.‚Äù On the frigid, snowy evening 250 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1770, Private Hugh White was the only soldier guarding the King‚Äôs money stored inside the Custom House on King Street. It wasn‚Äôt long before angry colonists joined him and insulted him and threatened violence. At some point, White fought back and struck a colonist with his bayonet. In retaliation, the colonists pelted him with snowballs, ice and stones. Bells started ringing throughout the town‚Äîusually a warning of fire‚Äîsending a mass of male colonists into the streets. As the assault on White continued, he eventually fell and called for reinforcements. The violence escalated, and the colonists struck the soldiers with clubs and sticks. Reports differ of exactly what happened next, but after someone supposedly said the word ‚Äúfire,‚Äù a soldier fired his gun, although it‚Äôs unclear if the discharge was intentional. Once the first shot rang out, other soldiers opened fire, killing five colonists‚Äìincluding Crispus Attucks, a local dockworker of mixed racial heritage‚Äìand wounding six. The event became known as The Boston Massacre which further incensed colonists already weary of British rule and unfair taxation and roused them to fight for independence.

Hardtack was a staple of military rations during the Civil War. Soldiers found it so inedible that they'd rather eat the bugs that had infested these dry biscuits than the hardtack itself. Don't miss Josh and Oldsmokey trying this and other historic foods during the premiere of Eating History at 10/9c on March 25th!

‚ÄúMr. Watson, come here, I need you‚Äù were the first words spoken on the telephone by inventor Alexander Graham Bell. After becoming interested in the possibility of transmitting speech over wires, Bell sought to improve upon Samuel F.B. Morse‚Äôs invention of the telegraph in 1843. The drawback of the telegraph, however, was that it still required hand-delivery of messages between telegraph stations and recipients, and only one message could be transmitted at a time. With the help of Thomas A. Watson, a Boston machine shop employee, Bell developed a prototype. In this first telephone, sound waves caused an electric current to vary in intensity and frequency, causing a thin, soft iron plate‚Äìcalled the diaphragm‚Äìto vibrate. These vibrations were transferred magnetically to another wire connected to a diaphragm in another, distant instrument. Alexander Graham Bell received a patent for his revolutionary new invention‚Äìthe telephone on #ThisDayinHistory 1876.

On #ThisDayinHistory in 1931, President Herbert Hoover signs a congressional act making ‚ÄúThe Star-Spangled Banner‚Äù the official national anthem of the United States. On September 14, 1814, Francis Scott Key composed the lyrics to ‚ÄúThe Star-Spangled Banner‚Äù after witnessing the massive overnight British bombardment of Fort McHenry during the War of 1812. Key, an American lawyer, watched the siege while detained on a British ship. He penned the famous words after observing with awe that Fort McHenry‚Äôs flag survived the 1,800-bomb assault. The original "Star-Spangled Banner" that inspired Key's poem was displayed at the Boston Navy Yard until 1907, and has been at the Smithsonian Institution ever since. In the late 1990s, fashion designer Ralph Lauren funded the restoration of the iconic flag, a process that was completed in 2006.

This Women‚Äôs History Month we celebrate 100 years of women exercising their right to vote. The 1920 passage of the 19th Amendment, which granted women's suffrage, stands as the single largest extension of voting rights in U.S. history. It took nearly a century of peaceful protest and planning from women around the nation. #WomensHistoryMonth

San Francisco‚Äôs Golden Gate Bridge, a stunning technological and artistic achievement, opens to the public after five years of construction on #ThisDayinHistory 1937. On opening day‚Äì‚ÄúPedestrian Day‚Äù‚Äìsome 200,000 bridge walkers marveled at the 4,200-foot-long suspension bridge, which spans the Golden Gate Strait at the entrance to San Francisco Bay and connects San Francisco and Marin County. The next day, on May 28, the Golden Gate Bridge opened to vehicular traffic.  The concept of bridging the nearly mile-wide Golden Gate Strait was proposed as early as 1872, but it was not until the early 1920s that public opinion in San Francisco began to favor such an undertaking. In 1921, Cincinnati-born bridge engineer Joseph Strauss submitted a preliminary proposal. During the next few years, Strauss‚Äô design evolved rapidly, thanks to the contributions of consulting engineer Leon S. Moisseiff, architect Irving F. Morrow, and others. Moisseiff‚Äôs concept of a simple suspension bridge was accepted by Strauss, and Morrow, along with his wife, Gertrude, developed the Golden Gate Bridge‚Äôs elegant Art Deco design. Morrow would later help choose the bridge‚Äôs trademark color: ‚Äúinternational orange,‚Äù a brilliant vermilion color that resists rust and fading and suits the natural beauty of San Francisco and its picturesque sunsets. In 1929, Strauss was selected as chief engineer.  Construction began on January 5, 1933, at the depths of the Great Depression. Strauss and his workers overcame many difficulties: strong tides, frequent storms and fogs, and the problem of blasting rock 65 feet below the water to plant earthquake-proof foundations. Eleven men died during construction. At 4,200 feet, it was the longest bridge in the world until the completion of New York City‚Äôs Verrazano-Narrows Bridge in 1964. Today, the Golden Gate Bridge remains one of the world‚Äôs most recognizable architectural structures.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1836, after 13 days of intermittent fighting, the Battle of the Alamo comes to a gruesome end, capping off a pivotal moment in the Texas Revolution. The final attack came before dawn as Mexican troops breached the north wall and flooded into the compound, awakening many of the Texans inside. The fighting lasted 90 minutes, some of it hand-to-hand combat. Alamo co-commanders James Bowie and William Travis were killed, as was legendary frontiersman Davy Crockett, although reports differ as to exactly how and when. Several Texans reportedly surrendered, but Mexican General Santa Anna ordered all prisoners be executed. Only a handful survived, mostly women and children. Historians estimate several hundred Mexicans died. The defense of the Alamo remains a symbol of resistance to oppression and revolutionary spirit.
Thank you to all the panelists who inspired us with their amazing conversations about legacy and leadership at #HISTORYTalks and especially we thank those who came to be inspired.

Ulysses S. Grant was inaugurated as the 18th president of the United States on #ThisDayinHistory 1869. Grant entered the White House in the middle of the Reconstruction era, a tumultuous period in which the 11 Southern states that seceded before or at the start of the Civil War were brought back into the Union. As president, Grant tried to foster a peaceful reconciliation between the North and South and he enacted measures to curb the terrorist actions of the Ku Klux Klan. In addition to focusing on Reconstruction, Grant signed legislation establishing the Department of Justice, the Weather Bureau (now known as the National Weather Service) and Yellowstone National Park, America‚Äôs first national park. He also tried, with limited success, to improve conditions for Native Americans.
Let‚Äôs be civil, gentlemen.

In one of the most dramatic upsets in Olympic history, the underdog U.S. hockey team, made up of college players, defeats the four-time defending gold-medal winning Soviet team forty years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1980 at the XIII Olympic Winter Games in Lake Placid, New York. The Soviet squad, previously regarded as the finest in the world, fell to the youthful American team 4-3 before a frenzied crowd of 10,000 spectators. Two days later, the Americans defeated Finland 4-2 to clinch the hockey gold.

The Battle of Iwo Jima was an epic military campaign between U.S. Marines and the Imperial Army of Japan in early 1945. American forces invaded the Western Pacific island on February 19, 1945, and the ensuing battle lasted five weeks. During the bloody fight, U.S. Marines from the 3rd Platoon, E Company, 2nd Battalion, 28th Regiment of the 5th Division took the crest of Mount Suribachi, the island‚Äôs highest peak and most strategic position, and raised the U.S. flag. Joe Rosenthal, a photographer with the Associated Press, met them along the way and recorded the raising of the second flag, 75 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory. Many of these men, including three of the six Marines seen raising the flag in the famous Rosenthal photo, were killed before the conclusion of the Battle for Iwo Jima in late March.

A physicist, space scientist and mathematician, Katherine Johnson was one of NASA‚Äôs ‚ÄúHidden Figures‚Äù ‚Äì a pioneer in the space race. She passed away yesterday at the age of 101.  Johnson provided the calculations for Alan Shepherd‚Äôs historic 1961 flight into space, John Glenn‚Äôs ground-breaking orbit of the earth in 1962 and the trajectory for Apollo 11‚Äôs moon landing, among other contributions. She was honored with the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015. #hiddenfigures

The Democratic National Convention in July of 1972 was historic for many reasons. Among the most striking was that, for the first time, one of the candidates to unseat then-President Nixon was a black woman. Shirley Chisholm had long been known for breaking barriers. Four years before, she‚Äôd become the first black U.S. Congresswoman in history as a Representative of her New York district. When she launched her primary campaign, she became the first black person to seek the presidential nomination from one of the two major parties. Her slogan was: ‚ÄúUnbought and Unbossed.‚Äù #BlackHistoryMonth

80 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1940, Gone with the Wind is honored with eight Oscars by the American Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. The most momentous award that night, however, undoubtedly went to Hattie McDaniel for her portrayal of ‚ÄúMammy,‚Äù a housemaid and former slave. McDaniel, who won the Best Supporting Actress Academy Award, was the first African American actress or actor ever to be honored with an Oscar. McDaniel‚Äôs film career declined in the late 1940s, and in 1947 she returned to radio as the star of a national broadcast. In 1951, while filming the first episodes of a television version of the popular show, she had a heart attack. She recovered to do a few more radio programs but in 1952 died of breast cancer at the age of 57.

A brilliant scholar and influential proponent of civil rights, W.E.B. DuBois was an African American writer, teacher, sociologist and activist whose work transformed the way that black citizens were seen in American society. Considered ahead of his time, Du Bois was an early champion of using data to solve social issues for the black community, and his writing‚Äîincluding his groundbreaking The Souls of Black Folk‚Äîbecame required reading in African American studies. W.E.B. DuBois was born on #ThisDayinHistory 1868.

Thurgood Marshall ‚Äî perhaps best known as the first African American Supreme Court justice ‚Äî played an instrumental role in promoting racial equality during the civil rights movement. Marshall argued a record-breaking 32 cases before the Supreme Court, winning 29 of them, more than any other person who argued cases against the high court. During his 24-year term as Supreme Court justice, Marshall‚Äôs passionate support for individual and civil rights guided his policies and decisions. Most historians regard him as an influential figure in shaping social policies and upholding laws to protect people of color. #BlackHistoryMonth

James Armistead was born into slavery in Virginia around 1748. With the permission of his master, Armistead enlisted in the Revolutionary War under the Marquis de Lafayette. Working as a spy, Armistead gained the trust of General Cornwallis and Benedict Arnold, providing information that allowed American forces to prevail at the Battle of Yorktown. Armistead died in 1830, having successfully petitioned for his freedom in 1787 with the aid of the Marquis de Lafayette. Armistead added "Lafayatte" to his last name. Learn more about James Armistead in Black Patriots: Heroes of the Revolution premiering this Wednesday, February 19 at 10/9c.

Mardi Gras is a tradition that dates back thousands of years to pagan celebrations of spring and fertility. Also known as Carnival or Carnaval, it‚Äôs celebrated in many countries around the world‚Äîmainly those with large Roman Catholic populations‚Äîon the day before the religious season of Lent begins. Brazil, Venice and New Orleans play host to some of the holiday‚Äôs most famous public festivities, drawing thousands of tourists and revelers every year.

George Washington needed the strongest soldiers possible to face the powerful British army. Disciplining his army by weeding out the weak was necessary in this fight or all hope for independence is lost.

It‚Äôs been said that journalists write the first draft of history. In these times of information overload, late night television hosts have joined nightly news anchors and newsroom editors as our purveyors of truth and justice in a complicated world ‚Äì cutting through the onslaught of information, exposing abuses of power and doggedly pressing for the truth. This panel discussion brings these powerful news forces together to shed light on the ever-evolving power dynamic between the media and the presidency. Nat King Cole was an American musician who first came to prominence as a jazz pianist. He owes most of his popular musical fame to his soft baritone voice, which he used to perform in big band and jazz genres. In 1956, Cole became the first African American performer to host a variety television series, and for many white families, he was the first black man welcomed into their living rooms each night. He has maintained worldwide popularity since his death on #ThisDayinHistory 1965. His daughter Natalie continued his legacy as a singer-songwriter. She passed away on December 31, 2015.
It was the most decisive victory by the Americans over the British when they clashed at the Battle of Saratoga. Learn more about the fallout when WASHINGTON continues tonight at 8/7c on HISTORY.
You have no reason to miss the epic miniseries event, WASHINGTON, now streaming at your convenience on HISTORY.com.

Phillis Wheatley was a revolutionary intellectual who waged a war for freedom with her words. Captured as a child in West Africa, then taken to North America and enslaved, Wheatley had an unusual experience in bondage. Her masters allowed her her to read and to pursue writing.  In 1773, at around age 20, Wheatley became the first African American and third woman to publish a book of poetry in the young nation. Shortly after, she was freed from enslavement. She is one of several African Americans who shaped America during the Revolutionary era. Black Patriots: Heroes of the Revolution premieres tonight at 10/9c on HISTORY.

Malcolm X was an African American leader in the civil rights movement who became an advocate of black nationalism. He urged black Americans to protect themselves against white aggression ‚Äúby any means necessary,‚Äù a stance that often put him at odds with the non-violent teachings of Martin Luther King, Jr. and other civil rights leaders. His charisma and oratory skills helped him achieve national prominence in the Nation of Islam, a religious and political movement he had joined after converting to Islam in prison. He later broke with the Nation of Islam and founded other organizations. After Malcolm X‚Äôs assassination on #ThisDayinHistory 1965, his bestselling book, The Autobiography of Malcolm X, popularized his ideas and helped inspire the Black Power movement.

The NAACP was founded on #ThisDayinHistory 1909, coinciding with the 100th anniversary of Abraham Lincoln's birth. A group that included African American leaders such as W.E.B. Du Bois and Ida B. Wells-Barnett announced the formation of a new organization called the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The organization would have a profound effect on the struggle for civil rights and the course of 20th Century American history. Due to its prominent members, landmark legal victories, and lobbying for laws like the Civil Rights Act and Voting Rights Act, the NAACP holds a place of distinction in the history of the Civil Rights Movement. It remains the largest and oldest active civil rights group in the nation, and its emphasis on voter registration, legal defense and activism have set an example for subsequent groups to follow.

75 years ago on this #ThisDayinHistory 1945, hundreds of Allied bombers descended on Dresden in two waves, dropping their lethal cargo indiscriminately over the city. By February 15, the city was a smoldering ruin and an unknown number of civilians‚Äîestimated at somewhere between 22,700 to 25,000 ‚Äìwere dead. Before World War II, Dresden was called ‚Äúthe Florence of the Elbe‚Äù and was regarded as one the world‚Äôs most beautiful cities for its architecture and museums. American author Kurt Vonnegut (1922-2007), who was a prisoner of war in Dresden during the Allied attack and tackled the controversial event in his book ‚ÄúSlaughterhouse-Five,‚Äù said of postwar Dresden, ‚ÄúIt looked a lot like Dayton, Ohio, more open spaces than Dayton has. There must be tons of human bone meal in the ground.‚Äù

Barely a month before the United States enters World War I, President Woodrow Wilson signs the Jones-Shafroth Act on #ThisDayinHistory 1917, granting U.S. citizenship to the inhabitants of Puerto Rico. As citizens, Puerto Ricans could now join the U.S. Army, but few chose to do so. After Wilson signed a compulsory military service act two months later, however, 20,000 Puerto Ricans were eventually drafted to serve during World War I. Puerto Rican soldiers were sent to guard the Panama Canal, the important waterway linking the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, in operation since 1914. Though nationalist agitation for the island‚Äôs complete independence from the U.S. was a constant‚Äîas were calls for Puerto Rico to become a state‚Äîsubsequent referendums confirmed the decision to remain a commonwealth.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1964, 22-year-old Cassius Clay, who would later become known as Muhammed Ali, shocked the odds-makers by dethroning world heavyweight boxing champ Sonny Liston in a seventh-round technical knockout. The dreaded Liston, who had twice demolished former champ Floyd Patterson in one round, was an 8-to-1 favorite. However, Clay predicted victory, boasting that he would ‚Äúfloat like a butterfly, sting like a bee‚Äù and knock out Liston in the eighth round.

The events of the past few decades have transformed our society and our world‚Äîand women have been on the front lines every step of the way. From the legacy of Title IX to major transformations in media and entertainment to efforts to achieve equity across fields, women have made an indelible impact. Moderated by @ronanfarrow , this panel featuring @billiejeanking @padmalakshmi @gloriasteinem will highlight the ways women from all backgrounds have catalyzed conversation and forged the course of recent history in sports, popular culture and beyond. The strength of his mother helped shaped the man & leader George Washington became. WASHINGTON premieres Sunday as part of a three-night miniseries event at 8/7c on HISTORY.

The Tuskegee Airmen were the first black military aviators in the U.S. Army Air Corps (AAC), a precursor of the U.S. Air Force. The program‚Äôs trainees, nearly all of them college graduates or undergraduates, came from all over the country and trained at the Tuskegee Army Air Field in Alabama. They flew more than 15,000 individual sorties in Europe and North Africa during World War II. Their impressive performance earned them more than 150 Distinguished Flying Crosses, and helped encourage the eventual integration of the U.S. armed forces. After their brave service, the Tuskegee Airmen returned home to a country where they continued to face systematic racism and prejudice.

Susan B. Anthony, a pioneer in the women‚Äôs suffrage movement in the United States was president of the National American Woman Suffrage Association, which she founded with Elizabeth Cady Stanton. Anthony‚Äôs work helped pave the way for the Nineteenth Amendment (1920) to the Constitution, giving women the right to vote. The nineteenth amendment was known as the ‚ÄúSusan B. Anthony Amendment‚Äù to honor her work on behalf of women‚Äôs rights, and on July 2, 1979, she became the first woman to be featured on a circulating coin from the U.S. mint. Susan B. Anthony was born 200 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1820.
‚ÄúWhere do you see yourself in five years?" George Washington‚Äôs resume showed his range as a leader and businessman.

Before they were dubbed vinegar valentines, these sassy cards were known as mocking or comic valentines. Their tone ranged from a gentle jab to downright aggressiveness. There was an insulting card for just about every person someone might dislike‚Äîfrom annoying salespeople and landlords to overbearing employers and adversaries of all kinds. Some cards mocked specific professions or were used to critique social movements like the effort among women to win the right to vote.

Frederick Augustus Washington Bailey was born around 1818 into slavery in Talbot County, Maryland.¬†¬†As was often the case with enslaved people, the exact year and date of Douglass' birth are unknown, though later in life he chose to celebrate it on #ThisDayinHistory February 14. Douglass escaped enslavement and became a prominent activist, author and public speaker. He was a leader in the abolitionist movement. His 1845 autobiography, Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass, an American Slave, became an important clarion call for ending slavery. It was one of several books he penned, along with dozens of noteworthy speeches, despite receiving minimal formal education. An advocate for women‚Äôs rights, and specifically the right of women to vote, Douglass‚Äô legacy as an author and leader lives on. His work served as an inspiration to the civil rights movement of the 1960s, and his legacy continues to shape your world.
A President and his one true love. #ValentinesDay

The New York City neighborhood of Harlem was the center of a cultural explosion from late 1910s through the mid-1930s. During the Great Migration, Harlem became a destination neighborhood, particularly for African Americans who had left the south in search of new opportunities. At this time, the Harlem section of Manhattan drew nearly 175,000 African Americans to its neighborhood of just three square miles. The influx of people to the area led to a period of groundbreaking contributions in what became known as a the Harlem Renaissance. #BlackHistoryMonth

"Get up, stand up, Stand up for your rights. Get up, stand up, Don‚Äôt give up the fight." Bob Marley famously sang on his 1973 album, Burnin'. Marley achieved several great accomplishments during his lifetime, including serving as a world ambassador for reggae music, earning induction into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1994, and selling more than 20 million records‚Äîmaking him the first international superstar to emerge from the so-called Third World. Decades after his passing, Marley's music remains widely acclaimed. Bob Marley was born 75 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1945. @biography

William Tecumseh Sherman was a Union general during the Civil War, becoming one of the most famous military leaders in U.S. history. The logistical brilliance on fiery display during Sherman‚Äôs March to the Sea from Atlanta to Savannah, Georgia, then north into the Carolinas, helped end the bloody war. Sherman was born 200 years ago on #ThisDayinHistory 1820.
A lover AND a fighter.
What doesn't kill you, makes you stronger.

On #ThisDayinHistory 1934, Henry Louis Aaron Jr., the baseball slugger who broke Babe Ruth‚Äôs legendary record of 714 homers, is born in Mobile, Alabama. Hank Aaron began his baseball career in 1952 in the Negro League and joined the Milwaukee Braves in 1954, eight years after Jackie Robinson integrated baseball. Aaron was the last Negro League player to compete in the majors. When he retired in 1976, he left the game with 755 career home runs, a record that stood until August 2007. He was inducted into the Baseball Hall of Fame in 1982. #blackhistorymonth

Josephine Baker spent her youth in poverty before learning to dance and finding success in the Harlem Renaissance. Baker landed a role in the musical Shuffle Along as a member of the chorus, and the special touch that she brought to the part made her popular with Broadway audiences. In 1925, at the peak of France‚Äôs obsession with American jazz and all things exotic, Baker traveled to Paris and became wildly popular. Baker was soon among the highest-paid performers in Europe, having the admiration of cultural figures like Pablo Picasso, Ernest Hemingway and E. E. Among those killed by the British during the Boston Massacre of 1770, the first victim was a sailor of mixed African American and Native American descent named Crispus Attucks. Samuel Adams organized a procession to transport Attucks‚Äô casket to Boston‚Äôs Faneuil Hall, where Attucks lay in state for three days before the his public funeral. According to historians, an estimated 10,000 to 12,000 people‚Äîmore than half of Boston‚Äôs population‚Äîjoined in the procession that carried the caskets of Attucks and the other Boston Massacre victims to the graveyard. Today is #nationalpizzaday. One of the first documented pizzerias in the U.S. was G. Lombardi‚Äôs on Spring Street in NYC, licensed to sell pizza in 1905. Here the owner and cook at Vince's Spaghetti House in Lake City, Seattle, tosses fresh pizza dough in 1959. Flatbreads with toppings were eaten by ancient Greeks, Egyptians and Romans. But the modern birthplace of pizza is the Italian city of Naples, located in the Campania region. When King Umberto I and Queen Margherita visited Naples in 1889, legend has it that they had become bored by French cuisine and requested pizzas from the pizzeria now known as Pizzeria Brandi. The queen‚Äòs favorite was topped with soft white cheese, red tomatoes and basil. As the story goes, that particular topping combo became known as pizza Margherita. Though some purport different Margherita origin stories, this one has become part of pizza lore. Pizza was not widely known throughout Italy until the 1940s, but immigrants from Naples brought their pizza recipes to New York and other American cities and it became popularized in the 20th century. Today, it is beloved throughout the world. #nationalpizzaday
